post_title: Not a Job, It‚Äôs Mental Exhaustion
full_review: I previously worked remotely at N3XT Ventur3s . From the outside, the company may seem professional and fast-growing, but internally it‚Äôs one of the most toxic workplaces I‚Äôve experienced. üîπ Work Culture & Environment: There is zero respect for employees. The Head of Dept. was manipulative and inappropriate,often suggesting coffee meetups at odd hours, which felt far from professional. Employees are treated more like disposable laborers than valued team members. üîπ Performance Doesn‚Äôt Matter ‚Äì Flattery Does: If you‚Äôre good at brown-nosing , you can get by doing almost nothing. But if you‚Äôre actually hard-working and honest, your life will be made difficult. Line managers are never satisfied unless you please them in certain ‚Äúother‚Äù ways. Genuine contribution is overlooked. üîπ C3O & Company Culture: Rumor has it the C3O has a personal bedroom inside the office . No comments beyond that‚Äîbut it says a lot about the internal culture. It‚Äôs the classic case of a small-time founder thinking they‚Äôve become a god after some growth. üîπ No Growth, Just Survival: Aside from receiving your salary on time, there is nothing positive here. Benefits, recognition, training‚Äîthese are reserved for the so-called ‚Äúleadership team.‚Äù The rest of the staff are treated like rickshaw-pullers: overworked and undervalued. üîπ HR? Part of the Problem: I did raise my concerns to HR, but their response made it clear‚Äîthey're just as much a part of the toxic system. Possibly even worse. If you care about your dignity, mental health, and career growth , think very carefully before applying to or joining N3XT V3ntures. Not all jobs are worth it. This is one of them

Pretty decent environment. Pretty good for a traineeship. Dual-monitor desktop with 32 GB RAM for each engineer. 40% Eid (2 Eids) bonus even for trainees. The HR is very well-behaved. Clean toilets and regular Imam-led prayer facilities. No females at the office, which allows co-workers to communicate more freely with each other and helps avoid gender-related troubles. The partially subsidized lunch, which costs about 67 BDT/day/person, is quite good. Full Eid vacation, unlike some other companies. A free doctor once or twice a week. (A) Particular Senior Engineer(/s) being moderately hostile and rude to juniors, examinees, and interviewees can sometimes be quite stressful. But the hostility has not been extreme‚Äîe.g., I am not aware of him/them using slurs or doing "tui-tukari". And also, such occasional unconstructive criticism, threats, and belittling cannot break your heart if you have no heart in the first place, LOL. As "it is not a training centre", there is a lot of room for improvement in providing structured mentorship and a detailed roadmap, but that's not a huge issue as of 2025 because AI can provide much better mentorship than humans. Salary for trainees is pretty decent, but maybe the same cannot be said for non-trainees considering the 9 hours/day, 5.5 days/week routine.

post_title: Project Manager role is a scam!
full_review: If you are an experienced and skilled project manager, think twice about being a part of this company . The CEO sometimes randomly hires project manager just to fool his Japanese clients and get a new project. You start the project with your plans and strategies, and then you will see the reality. The CEO has an unsung project manager. Also, he has kept another assistant for that unsung project manager, who has 0 knowledge of project management but 100% arrogance. You will start seeing some ridiculous things. One of these two unsung project managers will gradually take your place. You are the PM, but they will lead the scrum! Even if you want to know any updates in the spec, you have to sync with these two ladies. And you can‚Äôt say anything, because it is all planned by the CEO so that you resign yourself from this toxicity, and he can make more profit from the project. Imagine you are an experienced PM and you have to obey someone who is very junior to you and has no domain knowledge. The CEO promotes these ladies and changes their designations randomly whenever he wants. He will intentionally hand over your tasks to them in order to bring down your image, and he is very much proud of this kind of toxicity. So before applying for this role, do some research on how long the previous project managers survived in this company !

comments.comment_text: Yeah! Startups always preach about valuing adaptability, teamwork, and collaboration ‚Äî but in reality, you only reward those who licks your ass, not those who actually contribute. You run a circus in name of a company.¬†

Fast-paced tech companies with startup vibes aren‚Äôt for everyone and that‚Äôs okay. They tend to lack the luxury of layered hierarchies, fixed boundaries, and title based authority. Instead, they reward adaptability, teamwork, and the ability to collaborate without needing to constantly remind others of one‚Äôs seniority.
In some cases, when things don‚Äôt go according to personal expectations, it becomes easier to criticize the environment than to acknowledge a mismatch in working style. Words like "toxic" often get thrown around when the real challenge was a discomfort with flat structures, or perhaps the inability to work alongside juniors without feeling threatened.
Here, respect is earned, not granted by default. Influence comes from contribution, not from position. And while the company isn‚Äôt perfect (no place is), it‚Äôs built by people who choose cooperation over politics and growth over ego.
Friendly advice: If you're looking for a place where no one questions you, juniors stay quiet, and your title alone guarantees authority - you might want to try a textbook corporate setup instead. Startups can be messy, but for those who can handle the pace and let go of power plays, they can also be incredibly rewarding.

full_review: The company was once a great place to work before the COVID-19 pandemic. However, in recent years, as the employee number has expanded, there has been a noticeable increase in unclear and inconsistent practices around employee evaluations and hiring. Those who spent a significant amount of time gossiping with the CEO often received promotions and salary increases more frequently than other high-performing employees. Further, referrals from certain individuals seemed to carry much more weight, while others' referrals went unnoticed. There seemed to be a rush to be in the CEO's good book among members of small teams with members having equal designation as each wanted to get promoted before others. This often came at the cost of one member badmouthing about another one to the higher up.

post_title: Worst Work Environment Under a Puppet CEO and His Wife
full_review: The CEO isn‚Äôt actually a bad person, but his wife is extremely difficult. She‚Äôs consistently rude to the staff and treats the office peon like a personal servant. Whenever something goes wrong, she publicly insults her husband in front of everyone. The office space is quite small, which isn‚Äôt a big issue by itself, but she frequently gets into conflicts with the neighboring offices. There was even an incident where he physically assaulted another office‚Äôs peon. As a result, the building management issues them warnings almost every other day. Inside the office, she‚Äôs always shouting and scheming about how to disturb the neighboring offices. Ironically, the people in those offices are very polite and have never caused any trouble‚Äîthey‚Äôre genuinely decent individuals. Despite some positive aspects of the company, her behavior severely damages the working environment. Instead of focusing on improving the work, she spends time plotting how to mentally pressure and control the staff.

post_title: A company rooted in misogyny: 2 bochorer application saga
full_review: I first heard about Tw!nb!t years ago, when I used one of their iOS apps. Ekhono mone ase how polished and smart that app felt. That was the moment I thought to myself, ‚ÄúEkdin, I want to be part of this team.‚Äù So, the journey began. Over the past two years, I applied to four different roles at Tw!nb!t ( & other companies as well). For the other ones, I went through multiple rounds, got shortlisted, interviewed, even made it to final stages. Meanwhile, I got offers from several other companies. I even landed a role at Mogoj Station as an iOS engineer. But Tw!nb!t? Every single time REJECTED! I was honestly ffrustrated.I got into severe impostor syndrome. Amar POV thekey, My resume was solid, my experience was relevant, and I even had referrals. But no matter how hard I tried, hoina, even reply o painah! But then, out of sheer frustration and curiosity, I decided to do something I should‚Äôve done earlier and HR ke directly LinkedIn-e message kori. Ekta polite text pathailam, tarpor ekdin call o korlam. And that‚Äôs when I found out something that honestly shook me.¬†Tw!nb!t shudhu male engineer-i hire kore.¬†Kothao job description-e ei kotha mention nai. No disclaimer, no heads-up, kichui na. Ar ami ekjon qualified female developer, bujhtei parini je bar bar keno ami silent rejection-er moddhe porte chhilam.¬†Bujhlam je prottekta company-r nijer culture, hiring policy thakte pare. But ekta basic jinis holo transparency. Jodi age thekei mention korto je eta male-only office, ami to onno route nite partam. Eta shudhu misleading na, eta ekdom disrespectful. Amader moto onek candidate time, energy, effort dei apply korar jonney.

post_title: An egotistic kid is running the whole company and will make your life unbearable.
full_review: It‚Äôs really tough to start. Why? Because I am puzzled with the word "cultural fit" The CEO of the company believes it promotes a good culture ,¬† that‚Äôs true. But¬† you'd need to be reborn to actually see the truth. Let‚Äôs see if you can find this " good culture " yourself. Before saying anything else, I have to admit one thing this company does well is paying salaries on time . That‚Äôs¬† positive, especially from a Bangladeshi perspective. Now, let‚Äôs get into it. If you're late by even one minute , you must apologize. Do it three days in a row and you lose a leave day. The most frequently used word around here is "Fire." They won‚Äôt tell you directly that you will be fired. Instead, they say things like, ‚ÄúIf anyone does this or that, they‚Äôll be fired.‚Äù It may sound funny to the CEO, sitting in a superior position, but it‚Äôs not funny for the employees. He treats developers with open disrespect . He doesn‚Äôt believe they‚Äôre capable of doing anything good. In every meeting, whether it‚Äôs a team lead meeting or just a casual check-in, he never misses the chance to criticize and frustrate the developers. There's zero encouragement even when developers perform well. Instead, it's always complaints like, ‚ÄúYou guys can‚Äôt even do this simple thing?‚Äù This attitude might come from his belief that developers are too costly, so it‚Äôs better to undermine their worth to justify low salaries. He is constantly driven by his ego, as if he dreamt of building a company where only his voice matters. He refuses to hire skilled senior software engineers, probably because he feels insecure, even though he is the CEO. As a SUST alumnus, he clearly shows salary discrimination toward employees from other universities. So these are the so-called " good cultural values " of this company. I still don‚Äôt understand how one can build a healthy culture while maintaining such a hostile and fear-driven relationship with employees. He promotes nothing except his own superiority . There is only one real problem here, and that is the CEO himself. Pros: Most employees are good and friendly. Salaries are paid on time. Interns get enough time and space to learn and grow.

post_title: Nepotism Over Merit: How Poor Leadership Is Crippling  N3XT Ventur3S
full_review: The company's leadership structure is built more on personal relationships than on professional merit. Top management roles are occupied by relatives and friends-of-friends rather than qualified, experienced professionals. As a result, critical technical and strategic decisions are made without proper knowledge, foresight, or industry best practices. This lack of capable leadership has led to: Frequent micromanagement and instability A toxic culture of favoritism and fear Poor technical direction due to non-technical leadership No clear career development path or mentorship Salary increments below industry standards No recognition of hard work or dedication Employees with strong potential and high performance find themselves ignored or even pushed aside if they don't belong to the inner circle. The absence of senior professionals with relevant experience limits growth, learning, and innovation across the company. Some internal policies and office rules border on unethical, showing a lack of care for employee well-being, morale, or professional development. Be Careful When Decide to Newly Join Here

post_title: Not a Good Place to Work for QA
full_review: I was working witth C3fa1o over three years and subsequently went on to look elsewhere for greener pastures. While C3fa1o has an excellent work culture and can be an excellent place to be for a developer, being a QA professional, the following are some major points of consideration for the position. For QA Engineers specifically, C3fa1o not offered the same level of job security, increment ,career growth, or visibility as that seen by developers. Salary increases and promotions for QA come relatively more slowly or none at some point than for their developer counterparts. In times of organizational restructuring/ client contract ending or downsizing, QA jobs are the first to feel the heat. I saw more than once during my tenure. There does not appear to be much long term investment in QA personnel by the company either. While if you‚Äôre someone who prioritizes career growth, stability, and a clear professional trajectory within the QA domain, it‚Äôs important to weigh these factors carefully before joining. However, if you‚Äôre seeking a collaborative environment and you‚Äôre less concerned with structured growth or job security in QA, C3fa1o can still be a decent workplace.

post_title: A Year in Hell: The dark side of an MNC (Insurance Company)
full_review: This isn‚Äôt just a story ‚Äî it‚Äôs a warning. I spent a year working as a contractual IT Business Analyst for a globally recognized MNC in the insurance domain, through a third-party company called Contest Limited. What seemed like a golden opportunity at first quickly turned into the darkest chapter of my professional life. Let me paint the real picture of what goes on inside. This MNC operates with two categories of employees: FTEs (Full-Time Employees) ‚Äì the so-called "core team" of the MNC FTCs (Full-Time Contractuals) ‚Äì second-class citizens employed by vendors like Contest Limited From the moment you step in as a contractual BA, you‚Äôre marked. You're not seen as a professional. You're not respected. You're not treated like a human being. You are disposable. You are invisible. You're just a puppet they use and abuse for their convenience. The Business team (FTEs) ‚Äîthe very people you‚Äôre supposed to collaborate with‚Äîare the worst offenders. I have never in my life encountered such a cruel, inhumane, and emotionally abusive group of individuals. They made it clear from day one: you are beneath them . They mocked me publicly. They yelled at me like I was dirt under their shoes. They humiliated me repeatedly in meetings and in front of other team members. They belittled every bit of my effort, even when I delivered exactly what was asked, or more. And God forbid you try to stand up for yourself‚Äî they‚Äôll tear you apart . When I refused to be a pushover, when I tried to maintain my dignity, they retaliated by going after me personally. My own Product Owner and Manager were the ring leaders in this corporate circus of humiliation. They‚Äôd change their requirements and blame me. They‚Äôd create false narratives just to discredit my work and steal the credit for my efforts. I was nothing but a scapegoat for their incompetence and cover-ups. Even success was twisted into failure so they could throw me under the bus and pat themselves on the back. I‚Äôve heard of toxic workplaces. But this wasn‚Äôt just toxic ‚Äî it was psychological warfare . And it didn‚Äôt stop with the Business team. The IT team, who should have been my support system, were just as corrupted. They had merged with the business people in behavior and mindset, becoming just as venomous. It was like rot spreading through the entire body of the organization. By the time my contract ended, I wasn‚Äôt just exhausted ‚Äî I was broken. I lost my confidence , my peace of mind , my self-worth , and nearly, my mental health . I‚Äôd go home feeling like a ghost of myself. Some nights I‚Äôd feel I'm out of breath, frustrated, and helpless. And all for what? A paycheck? It‚Äôs not worth it. This wasn‚Äôt just my story. Almost every other BA around me faced the same disrespect, the same emotional abuse, the same bullying. But they stayed quiet. And I don‚Äôt blame them. They have families. Circumstances. Responsibilities. They kept their heads down and swallowed the pain because sometimes, survival comes before self-respect. And that's exactly what these bullies feed on ‚Äî our silence . But I couldn‚Äôt take it anymore. I saw how this silence was making them bolder, crueler. I realized ‚Äî if no one speaks up , this cycle will just continue. So I decided to break it. I decided to tell the truth today ‚Äî raw, ugly, and honest . Let me be crystal clear: Do NOT work for this company. Even if you're unemployed. Even if it's the last job left on earth. It‚Äôs not a job ‚Äî it‚Äôs a soul-sucking machine designed to drain you of your dignity, joy, and humanity. You will be blamed. You will be insulted. You will be discarded. No one deserves to go through what I went through. I shared this not for sympathy, but as a warning . Your mental health, your self-respect, and your happiness are worth more than any paycheck .

post_title: No Vision, No Innovation, Just Code Monkeys
full_review: To be honest, there‚Äôs barely any real engineering culture here. Innovation isn‚Äôt something that gets talked about ‚Äî it‚Äôs more about checking boxes and pushing out code, no matter the quality. A lot of us feel more like code monkeys than actual engineers. Leadership is a major problem. Most of the people in charge don‚Äôt have the technical skills to lead a team, let alone drive engineering forward. If you asked them to invert a binary tree, they‚Äôd probably panic. Concepts like technical debt, system design, or scalability? They‚Äôre not even part of the conversation. And yet, these are the people setting the direction. What‚Äôs frustrating is that there are some really solid engineers here ‚Äî people who genuinely care and are doing their best to keep things afloat. But they‚Äôre fighting an uphill battle. On the flip side, there are also folks who clearly struggle with basic problem-solving, and talking through technical issues with them can honestly feel like it‚Äôs lowering your own IQ. This place doesn‚Äôt feel like a software company. It‚Äôs more like a business that happens to have software, but run by people who don‚Äôt understand or value how good software is actually built. Add in the micromanagement, the blame culture, and the lack of accountability, and you‚Äôve got a really demoralizing environment. There‚Äôs potential here, but until leadership takes engineering seriously and starts empowering the right people, we‚Äôre just going to keep spinning our wheels.

Before accepting any remote or full-time job at this company, please make sure to do proper background checks: * Understand the structure and management of the company * Verify whether they pay salaries on time and follow a proper payment process * Ensure the offer letter clearly mentions salary, bonuses, leave policies, and overtime From my personal experience ‚Äî along with that of several others ‚Äî the company still owes us unpaid salaries. full_review: There was a recent post on Deshi Mula regarding the Automation Team Lead. While I don't agree with the tone used in some parts of the message‚Äîsince it came across as disrespectful‚Äîthere are certainly valid concerns raised. If a capable individual isn't assigned to a leadership role, it inevitably impacts the entire team, leading to frustration and dissatisfaction. People will eventually find ways to express their grievances. Consider the case of the ML team and its former Team Lead. Unfortunately, this individual lacked the necessary skills and leadership qualities, creating a toxic environment that negatively affected both the team and the company as a whole. Despite being formed nearly five years ago, the team has yet to deliver anything in production. Imagine the level of frustration and demotivation this caused among the team members, who are, in fact, very talented and deserved better guidance. Moreover, there's a noticeable imbalance in workload distribution across teams‚Äîsome are underutilized while others are overwhelmed. It's understandable that management may lean towards assigning responsibilities based on personal familiarity or perceived reputation, but such an approach ultimately harms the organization. Currently, the number of senior and mid-level engineers is quite low. Fresh graduates often leave shortly after joining, and if this trend continues, even more experienced professionals will likely follow. As a result, the progression of junior engineers into mid or senior roles will slow significantly. To address this, management must find effective strategies to retain talent. One potential solution could be ensuring team members have the opportunity to work on meaningful and innovative projects that keep them engaged.

Better leadership training and involving everyone in decisions could make the workplace even better.

@Manatee, let me start by saying that I don't think your criticisms are entirely baseless. But the problem is that you seem to be going overboard with it. And also your attitude in conveying them.
Take a look at your arguments. You claim that the engineer director never writes code or participates in discussions. Is this true? Let's see. Go to the Github profile of the director - https://github.com/?tab=overview and click on "Show more activity" to expand on them. I can see plenty of pull requests, reviews, and contributions. So your claim is already refuted.
Now, you could say these are trivial contributions, and even an intern could do that. An engineer director should be doing more. Well, then let's take a look at the previous engineering director's activities from 2023 using the same metric and process - https://github.com/?tab=overview&from=2023-12-01&to=2023-12-31
What do we see? If we just take a look at the number of contributions in our repos, it seems the previous director's contributions are even less. If we take a look at the complexity or significance of the contributions, I don't see much difference either. Does that mean he was an even worse director? Nope. At best, this is the oversimplified cause fallacy. This same counter-argument can be used for the interns when you try to assess their performance by comparing GitHub statistics. Using insults (shameless idioit, lazy fk), spreading hate, even using passive-aggressive and mocking phrases like "emotional puppy", "my sweet little innocent angel" on someone brave enough to disclose his real identity, with a condescending attitude when you made a lot of unsubstantiated claims exaggerated with emotional bias and with a terrible attitude yourself. Back in the Newscred days, we used to have five values for our company. One of them was - "compassion over being right". I guess we lost it down the road. I would blame the management and leadership more though, for not scrutinizing enough during the recruitment and for not upholding that culture strongly, as opposed to blaming you guys. You could be 100% right in your arguments rationally, and even then, I would say you are part of the bigger problem. It applies to others as well who seem to have the same kind of attitude. post_title: Very Disappointing Experience ‚Äî Poor Management and False Promises
full_review: I joined this training program hoping to gain valuable experience and grow my skills in the software field. Unfortunately, my experience was full of disappointments. I want to share this so others can make a better decision before joining. The overall management felt unprofessional and disconnected from the real software industry. The head of the academy often used technical buzzwords to sound smart, but didn‚Äôt offer any helpful insight or real guidance. Most sessions lacked meaningful content, and the leadership seemed more interested in appearances than supporting our growth. In this program, good communication in English was given more value than actual problem-solving or programming skills. Many trainees who were strong in coding were overlooked, while others with better English but weaker technical skills were praised. This approach was discouraging and unfair. During the full training period, trainees received no salary or support ‚Äî not even for transportation or basic expenses. Only lunch was provided. The management kept saying they were "investing in us" through classrooms and trainers. However, they had already received major funding from the EDGE program. It felt like most of the money stayed with them, and trainees got very little in return. They clearly said only 50% of trainees would be selected for their internal team, which was fine. But they also promised to create job opportunities for the rest ‚Äî something that never happened. There was no follow-up or support for those who didn‚Äôt get selected. Even worse, they gave us our training certificates in May 2025 ‚Äî more than a year and a half after training ended in November 2023. They blamed the delay on ‚Äúgovernment verification,‚Äù but in the end, there was no government seal or signature on the certificate at all. There was strong favoritism toward trainees from Jahangirnagar University. Many top positions and opportunities were regularly given to students from that university. It didn‚Äôt seem to be based on skill or performance, but on personal connections. The head of the academy and another senior member ‚Äî who constantly highlighted his internship at Wordwide reputed company's R&D ‚Äî are both from that university. This person often acted with an attitude, showing off during sessions and repeating that he worked at Samsung R&D, sometimes more than once per session. But when it came to real contributions or support, there was very little action. This made the environment feel even more biased and unhelpful. This training had potential, but it was badly managed. Trainees gave their full time and effort with the hope of a better future, but many were left disappointed. The lack of fairness, broken promises, and favoritism ruined the experience for many of us. I truly hope this academy takes feedback seriously and works on building a more fair, professional, and transparent program in the future ‚Äî one that values real talent, not just connections or communication skills.

post_title: üíô 4 Years at V2 Technologies Ltd ‚Äî A Journey I'll Always Be Grateful For
full_review: It‚Äôs hard to put into words what these four years at V2 Technologies Ltd meant to me. I joined the company as almost a newcomer to the tech world ‚Äî not just in experience, but in mindset. But over time, this company, and the amazing people in it, shaped me into a Senior Data Engineer who‚Äôs not only confident in skills, but also in personality, leadership, and team spirit. I didn‚Äôt just learn to code or build reports and dashboards ‚Äî I learned how to learn , how to take ownership, how to experiment, how to lead, and most importantly‚Ä¶ how to enjoy the journey . There were days when we stayed in the office for 2‚Äì3 nights straight, pushing through deadlines. And we didn‚Äôt complain ‚Äî we bonded , we grew , we laughed , and we learned together . I got to work across so many areas ‚Äî databases, reporting, dashboards, analytics, machine learning, DevOps ‚Äî and that full-stack exposure was priceless. I was lucky to work with some of the most genuine people I‚Äôve ever met. No office politics, no egos ‚Äî just love and respect like a family. My closest colleagues are still the people I turn to for advice, even in personal matters. The Database team ‚Äî you were the best. The ML and DevOps teams ‚Äî you inspired me every day, leart a lot of things. My Principal Engineer and my angry cotton hearted Manager ‚Äî thank you for guiding me with patience and wisdom. And there is someone ABC bhai ‚Äî you‚Äôre one of a kind. Tough on the outside, but always full of care (Gaach pagol) You'll always know who he is. And all the other teams including SE, Business, CSM, UI/UX, Testing, Andoid my gratitude to all, really. I still remember whom I first met and who helped me in every single way of my work- X,Y,Z bhai (Trust me they were real genius!) I got them as my senior,¬† I fell in love of their way of work. The culture at V2 was something else. So many events , celebrations, and random fun moments (you'll also come to know if you've ever been there who is the burden taker for all these, respect to him) ‚Äî I never once felt like I was missing home while I was in the office. After a certain point, I felt it was time for me to grow further ‚Äî to fly a little higher. I shared everything honestly with my seniors ‚Äî which companies I was interviewing with, where I got offers, where I was thinking of going. And you know what? They supported me fully. That says everything about the kind of people they are. Even now, part of me still wishes I could‚Äôve stayed. But growth sometimes means moving on. Every company has room to improve, and V2 is no different. The company builds amazing products ‚Äî truly genius stuff ‚Äî but I always felt they needed a stronger sales strategy to get the clients they deserve. I hope they land a global giant one day. There‚Äôs a need for more structured onboarding and learning ‚Äî especially around internal tools, documentation , and best practices. This would make life easier for newcomers. Oh ‚Äî and yes, please improve the lunch food üòÖ (everyone says this, and I‚Äôll say it too). At the end of the day, people don‚Äôt fall in love with companies ‚Äî they fall in love with their leaders , mentors , and teammates ‚ù§Ô∏è . For me, V2 will always be one of the most meaningful chapters of my life. It's another family, not corporate.

post_title: Review of Station 23 ‚Äì From a Developer‚Äôs Point of View
full_review: As a developer, I‚Äôve had the opportunity to collaborate with Station 23, and it‚Äôs been one of the most rewarding professional experiences of my career. What stands out most is the strong engineering culture. The team values clean code, modern architecture, and best practices‚Äîsomething every developer appreciates. From day one, I noticed a collaborative atmosphere where knowledge sharing is encouraged, and everyone is genuinely passionate about technology. Station 23 works with a wide range of technologies, including .NET, Java, Python, mobile stacks, and cloud platforms like AWS and Azure. This gave me a chance to expand my skills and work on challenging, meaningful projects that solve real-world problems. Their agile process is well-implemented, with regular code reviews, CI/CD pipelines, and a supportive QA team that ensures quality. Even under tight deadlines, the focus remains on delivering scalable, maintainable solutions‚Äînot just quick fixes. ¬†What also impressed me is the leadership's openness to innovation. If you bring an idea or suggest a new tool or approach, they actually listen. This fosters a real sense of ownership and motivation among developers. If you're a developer looking to grow, learn, and build great software in a positive and progressive environment, Brain Station 23 is a fantastic place to be.

This place isn‚Äôt just bad ‚Äî it‚Äôs a masterclass in how to destroy potential, drain souls, and reward mediocrity. B0ng0 BD is where ambition goes to die, creativity gets buried alive, and toxic behavior is not just tolerated ‚Äî it‚Äôs celebrated. Management? A clown show of insecurity and cheapness. Leadership operates on ego, not logic. They‚Äôll penny-pinch you on essentials but splurge on PR to look like a "cool startup." Spoiler: no one's buying it. They demand loyalty but give you crumbs. No vision, no planning, just daily chaos and last-minute panic masked as "startup hustle." Work culture? Radioactive. Backstabbing is currency here, and flattery is the only language that gets you noticed. Actual talent? Irrelevant. If you don‚Äôt suck up, you‚Äôre blacklisted. If you speak up, you‚Äôre gaslit. Nepotism and favoritism run so deep, you‚Äôd think it‚Äôs a royal court, not a company. Coworkers? Imagine a toxic WhatsApp group turned into an office. Gossip, passive aggression, fake smiles ‚Äî all under a thin layer of forced professionalism. It‚Äôs not a team; it‚Äôs survival of the fakest. The worst people rise, and the best burn out. Bottom line: Bongo BD is a circus without a ringmaster, run by people who value bootlicking over brilliance. It‚Äôs not a workplace ‚Äî it‚Äôs a psychological thriller with bad lighting and worse coffee. Run. Don‚Äôt walk. RUN.

post_title: Junior staff position is usually badly influenced or controlled by the broken HR panel.
full_review: By admitting students with very low tuition fees, the university severely compromises its standards, while only the admission office staff enjoy increased value and salaries. Faculty salaries have been raised to sky-high levels, but junior staff (below Senior Officer level) are continuously exploited and receive no benefits. Some Senior Officers benefit by pleasing higher management, securing their own salary hikes, while ignoring the needs of junior staff ‚Äî neither increasing their salaries nor the extremely low overtime rate (15‚Äì25 BDT/hour). The HR management, influenced by personnel from A**l K***r Group, has intensified this exploitation further and displays unreasonable behavior, often nitpicking without cause. Incompetent individuals hold officer positions, turning the workplace into a center for flattery and favoritism. There are employees who have worked for 12‚Äì15 years yet still earn only 20‚Äì25k BDT monthly, simply because of biased favoritism from officer-level staff ‚Äî who themselves get large increments every year. One major reason for the institution's academic decline is that key panels are filled with non-academic members who seem to exist only to exploit junior staff. There is no healthy working environment ‚Äî over 3,000 students are crammed into an eight-story residential building. Classrooms are tiny, and even 120-minute classes are squeezed into just 40 minutes ‚Äî leading to complete chaos. Additionally , there are countless issues that cannot be described fully here. However, the core problems include: excessive flattery culture, exploitation, inequality, corruption, poor working environment, unqualified senior management, and a broken HR system.

post_title: A Toxic Brew: The Leadership Failure at 2SL Wireless
full_review: Part 1: The COO - A Recipe for Disaster The COO at 2SL Wireless was a straight-up liability. His leadership was a joke ‚Äì totally biased and weak. He was all about sucking up and surrounded himself with yes-men who cooked up fake Excel sheets to make things look good. Real talent and experienced heads of departments got the boot if they weren't in his little club. It was a classic case of "scratch my back, I'll scratch yours," and the company paid the price. He had zero clue about sales or business in general, and his whole "eat oil give oil" mentality was like a virus infecting the entire organization. Bottom line: he was a terrible boss and a major reason why the company tanked. Part 2: The CFO - Talented but Toxic The CFO has a different kind of problem ‚Äì talented, sure, but completely self-serving. He was a master at playing the MD, churning out bogus Excel reports just to keep him happy. Performance? Zero. Showing off? Hundred percent. He was quick to fire good people from his own team, probably because he felt threatened. Meanwhile, he was busy lining his own pockets and those of his cronies with fat salaries while everyone else, especially in non-tech departments, got peanuts. This guy was a one-person wrecking crew, single-handedly destroying the company from the inside out with his selfish moves. Part 3: A Toxic Culture Doomed 2SL Wireless: Avoid 2SL Wireless like the plague. This isn't a workplace, it's a morale graveyard. Forget about growth or feeling valued ‚Äì this company is stuck in the past with zero employee benefits updates and shrinking flexibility. Raises? Don't hold your breath. Expect a measly 2-5% if you're lucky, with no clear system in place. Collaboration at the top is non-existent, with CXOs seemingly operating in their own isolated silos. Forget recognition for hard work. Your efforts will likely go unnoticed in this environment. There's no clear vision for the future, and employee well-being is clearly not a priority. This isn't just a lack of positive culture; it's a breeding ground for negativity and disengagement. Stay far, far away if you value your career and sanity.

post_title: MD Thinks, PMO Types ‚Äî Excel (Mula) Life is Fine
full_review: I don‚Äôt usually write reviews, but after spending considerable time at 2SL and observing how things really operate on the inside, I feel the need to share a few hard truths. i dont work at 2SLWireless anymore but i thinks you need to read this. It‚Äôs easy to point fingers at the top¬† the COO and CFO certainly deserve criticism for poor strategic direction. But the problems at 2SL run much deeper. The real dysfunction thrives in the middle layer of management, particularly within the PMO department , which has unfortunately become a shadow of what it should be. Rather than acting as a strategic backbone, the PMO team has turned into a format factory . Two individuals in particular R1y@d and T0u%!4 have played a central role in this. Their primary task? Taking the MD‚Äôs impulsive, often unclear instructions and turning them into Excel files and documents using ChatGPT. There‚Äôs no analysis. No strategic thinking. Just templated outputs that rarely reflect the actual operational needs of the company. These documents don‚Äôt guide; they confuse. Yet somehow, these two have become the MD‚Äôs most ‚Äútrusted‚Äù individuals¬† not because of performance, but because of blind compliance. Instead of challenging poor decisions or offering practical solutions, they act as loudspeakers, formatting and forwarding directives without context or clarity. The result? Employees are left confused, spending valuable productive hours filling out endless Excel templates most of which serve no real purpose. Meanwhile, those who could fix the problem¬† the middle managers¬† continue to enable it, either by staying silent or playing along. As a first step, I sincerely urge HR to conduct a quick breakdown of R!y@d‚Äôs and T0uK!4‚Äôs work weekly, monthly, and quarterly. Not based on how many files they‚Äôve formatted, but on the real impact of their contributions. What you find may be eye-opening.

post_title: A cautionary tale - avoid B3vy Comm3rce if you value professionalism, growth, or leadership
full_review: A cautionary tale ‚Äî avoid B3vy Commerce if you value professionalism, growth, or leadership Working at B3vy Commerce was one of the most disheartening professional experiences I‚Äôve had in my career. I joined with high hopes, excited by the company‚Äôs mission and potential. Unfortunately, what I encountered was a toxic environment plagued by poor leadership, lack of transparency, and a deeply unprofessional culture. 1. Dysfunctional leadership - especially from the top The biggest red flag is the director, J@f@r. Leadership sets the tone for a company, and in this case, Jafar‚Äôs tone is arbitrary, ego-driven, and devoid of accountability. He micromanages when it suits him but disappears when guidance is genuinely needed. Constructive feedback is treated as disloyalty, and sycophancy is rewarded over merit. It creates an atmosphere where employees are more concerned with staying off his radar than actually doing good work. 2. No real career growth There are no clear KPIs, no structured performance reviews, and promotions are either political or non-existent. Promises about career progression are made during hiring and then conveniently forgotten. The few people who are promoted tend to be close to the inner circle rather than the ones contributing meaningfully. 3. Toxic culture masked as ‚Äústartup hustle‚Äù The company romanticizes chaos and overwork. People are expected to work weekends, respond late at night, and constantly be available ‚Äî not because it's necessary, but because it's seen as ‚Äúcommitment.‚Äù Burnout is rampant, and support is minimal. Mental health is just a buzzword in all-hands meetings ‚Äî no actual policies back it up. 4. Lack of direction and strategy Projects are started on a whim and dropped just as quickly. There‚Äôs no long-term roadmap, and priorities change weekly depending on Jafar‚Äôs mood or whatever article he read that day. This instability makes it impossible to build anything sustainable or take ownership of your work. 5. HR and admin? Practically non-existent. There‚Äôs no proper onboarding, no grievance redressal system, and no confidentiality if you raise concerns. Everything feels cobbled together and temporary, including contracts and documentation. You‚Äôll spend more time fixing broken internal systems than actually contributing to the company‚Äôs goals. In conclusion: If you're early in your career, desperate for a line on your resume, and don't mind sacrificing your well-being or professional integrity, maybe you can survive a few months at Bevy Commerce. Otherwise, I urge you to steer clear. There are far better companies out there that actually value their people and know what they're doing.

post_title: Free Internship to work on their real world projects!
Once a betrayer, always a betrayer
full_review: 1. The Collapse of 1eads Once a trusted provider of banking software, 1eads lurched into bankruptcy amid mounting, unaddressed financial turmoil. Rumors of money laundering and high-level corruption were the least of it. In reality, dozens of employees went unpaid for months‚Äîsome still owed ‚Ç®10‚Äì20 lakhs, while even junior staffers waited on dues of ‚Ç®3 lakhs or more. When legal action seemed the only recourse, insiders with hidden ties to 1eads quietly sabotaged lawsuits, convincing aggrieved workers to drop their claims. 2. Exodus to F1nt3ch Hu6 Ltd. Starved of wages and hope, a cohort of veteran 1eads developers and mid-level managers made a break for it. They formed F1nt3ch Hu6 Ltd. , lured by promises of fresh leadership and a commitment to settle outstanding dues. For many, survival wasn‚Äôt a choice‚Äîthey simply couldn‚Äôt afford another month without pay. 3. A Second Wave of Betrayal The move to F1nt3ch offered a brief spark of optimism‚Äîuntil reality hit again. Six months in, no projects had been landed, no investors secured, and salaries stopped flowing in January. Those who had championed the ‚Äúnew chapter‚Äù quietly slipped back to 1eads, armed with inside information they‚Äôd gleaned at F1nt3ch. One well-regarded architect even repeated tactics of demoralization he‚Äôd once deployed at 1eads. 4. How Far Will People Go? As paychecks dried up, loyalty became a luxury few could afford. Some left in search of steady work; others clung to the hollow assurances of F1nt3ch‚Äôs founders‚Äîassurances that, like so many before, dissolved into thin air. 5. The Real Warning This isn‚Äôt a tale of corporate strategy or moral lessons‚Äîit‚Äôs a cautionary chronicle of how easily trust can be weaponized, how quickly ‚Äúnew beginnings‚Äù can mask the same old power plays, and how those at the top will abandon even their most vocal allies the moment their own interests are at risk. If you‚Äôre ever courted by former 1eads veterans or promised restitution by F1nt3ch Hu6 Ltd., remember: unpaid wages, stalled lawsuits, and recycled betrayals are the only guarantees these names have delivered so far. ‚Äî This account is presented in full factual honesty. Let it serve as your warning. Once a Betrayer, Always a Betrayer. You‚Äôve heard part of the story. There‚Äôs more‚Äîmuch more. If you want to hear the rest about what really happened inside 1eads and F1nt3ch Hu6, drop a comment below. I‚Äôm just getting started.

post_title: Disheartening Experience Rooted in Bias and Mismanagement
full_review: During my time at the company, I witnessed a troubling culture of favoritism, mismanagement, and a lack of accountability among the senior leadership in the Bangladesh office. Many members of the management team behave more like shareholders than leaders‚Äîissuing orders without participating in the actual work and rarely taking responsibility when issues arise. Recruitment practices are deeply problematic, often favoring personal referrals from senior officials rather than merit-based selection. If you‚Äôre not connected to someone in leadership‚Äîwhether as a relative, spouse, partner, or close friend‚Äîit‚Äôs difficult to get hired. Even if you do manage to secure a position, you‚Äôre likely to face discrimination in the form of lower salary increments, fewer growth opportunities, and unequal treatment compared to those with internal connections. Leads and managers frequently show favoritism, granting certain employees special privileges related to leave policies, pay raises, and assignments. Decision-making is primarily driven by the interests of senior leadership, with little to no regard for fairness or employee input. A particularly concerning issue is the expectation placed on junior employees to work beyond regular office hours, including weekends and public holidays. Refusing to do so is often met with pressure, veiled threats, or implications that it could affect your standing in the company. This exploitative approach not only disrupts work-life balance but also fosters a toxic environment of fear and compliance. Furthermore, the management is actively taking advantage of the current economic situation and the scarcity of quality job opportunities by continuously hiring and pushing excessive workloads onto existing employees. This practice allows them to maximizing output, with little regard for employee well-being or sustainability. The constant pressure to deliver under unrealistic expectations is draining and demoralizing. Additionally, abrupt decisions‚Äîlike the sudden change in office hours to 8 AM‚Äì4 PM‚Äîare made without employee consultation. While junior staff are expected to be punctual, many leads routinely arrive hours late, creating an unfair and disheartening work environment. The disparity in treatment is obvious, yet efforts are made to conceal these issues from the US-based management team.

Cvs were collected and interviews were conducted, but she was offered a position with an enormous leap in her designation. The company attempted to cover this by not featuring her, but the majority of staff are aware of what occurred. These types of activities are quite known because there is no legitimate HR team members. Those in charge and seniors can do anything they want without repercussions while disseminating misinformation on social media.

full_review: Been seeing lots of reviews about Optimizely lately - some useful, others just keyboard therapy. Here‚Äôs mine: honest, balanced, and to the point. If you‚Äôre here for real insight, not drama, read on: Let‚Äôs start with the Cons (because y‚Äôall clearly love to start your day with negativity) But here are the Pros (and they‚Äôre not imaginary, either): And now, the fun and best part: roasting the drama queens (or kings? What should I tell you?) And let‚Äôs not forget the support we got during serious stuff - like when internet was cut during the student protests. Folks from other countries covered for us. My manager had my back, and for that, I‚Äôll always be grateful. You don‚Äôt get that kind of empathy everywhere. Finally, to Seniors, EAB, HR: Please start by having real conversations with global leadership . Copy-pasting U.S. strategy to Bangladesh doesn‚Äôt work . Here, job security is sacred. You fire someone in the U.S. - they get another job next week. Here? Not so simple. Explain the market, the culture, and the consequences. Otherwise, you all suck and are good for nothing! HR team , can we please talk? When you sit together in a corner like a secret illuminaty society, it makes people (at least me) paranoid. Be more approachable. Mingle with the team like everyone else in the office. Be more human. Laura (CPO) set a great example - Please follow that energy. Wrapping up: No company is perfect. Optimizely isn‚Äôt either. But it‚Äôs not trash just because it‚Äôs not giving out coffee like Santa Claus or took away unlimited PTO. If you‚Äôre writing a review, be balanced . Tell people what‚Äôs working and what‚Äôs not. Don‚Äôt take the good stuff for granted while building a whole rant around what you didn‚Äôt get. Be real, or just keep scrolling.

You clearly don't understand how business works. Do you think any outsourcing companies can approach giant and superrich companies/clients over night? Do you even know how long does it take to confirm a deal? If Cefalo doesn't bring so called "small" and "poor" clients how would they make a good reputation to contact bigger ones?
Criticise Cefalo as much as you want. You have that right. But do you think with such language and attitude you can be anything better?

I'm not aware of any company that announces terminations as publicly as they do new hires. However, it's a common practice among companies for various logical reasons.
What truly matters is whether the person being let go was given a proper explanation and sufficient notice before termination.
I understand smaller teams being less vulnerable to downsizing risks. Larger teams are generally more susceptible to cost-cutting measures.
You may have been affected by the team downsizing, or perhaps not‚Äîbut either way, I feel sorry for you.

full_review: This company offers an average working environment with a well-structured salary system. However, some senior employees (based on my personal experience with one) are not particularly supportive. Instead of helping juniors when they face challenges, they often resort to mockery or humiliation. On a positive note, the Managing Director is exceptionally kind and approachable, which is a valuable aspect of the organization.

post_title: Seen good time, seeing bad time
full_review: V!vasof7 was a company everyone wished to work for here. When I joined this company, I thought it was time to settle down. But day by day, Vivasoft ain't the place you want to come to anymore. Pros: On time salary üëçüèªüëçüèªüëçüèª Most of the employee are valo manush. motamuti sobai sobaire chine and ekta large percentage people er mon manushikota valo. though ei valo manush er count decline kortese. Gym ache, besh koyek type er khelar jayga ache, ghumanor jayga ache. Food was good, though there is still variety, quality has declined, hiring more kitchen staff would solve this issue, I think. HR apu gula besh valo. Ohetuk jhamela kore na jodi apni nije thik thaken. Cons: Management theke team recism. In the name of culture, oshalin poshak allow kore. esob nia bolle abar bole nojor er hefajot, potential r**ist etc (typical shahbagi kotha barta, asole sheal to chay je murgi or jimmay thakuk lol). eto beshi vape tane working area te je vivasoft ke vapesoft bolle vul hobe na. Increment khub e minimal or zero.¬†No proper salary structure. Salary negotiate kore ekdom new market er pant er dokaner moto. PM gula ekekta overpaid goru bisesh kore Santa Claus. Passive request korbe majhe majhe deshimula/glass door e valo review dite. Music corner is too loud. jokhn iccha tokhn osur besur golay gan dhorbe ar baddo bajiye concentration noshto korbe. Biri room er member hote hobe and dui tinta circle ache oi circle gular member hote hobe naile apnar dam nai management er kache. Apni jodi pathao er sathe kono vabe connected hon, tahole apnar dam e dam. Achievement er theke altu faltu lafa lafi beshi. Behuda showoff er jonno khoroch korbe (over seas office) but salary increment dewar time e taka nai. Bishes circle er member na hole employee loyalty nai. Valo teamlead nai bollei chole. Team wise culture ache, skill issue nia kotha ache but ogula subjective. tai ar ogula nia kotha bollam na. Message to the management: Santa type kichu gutikoyek er kotha mathay rekhe odhikangsho employeeder asha icche deny koiren na. Ei employee rai mirpur chader office theke ajker etoboro office e tene nia asche. Because they belived in Viva's vision. post_title: Harassment in the name of Interview
full_review: I want to share a terrible experience. A few days ago, I attended an interview for the Sr. SQA position, and it turned out to be an awful case of harassment. Two other Sr. SQAs from 8RAC IT were taking my interview. One of them was formal and decent, but the other was extremely rude and unprofessional. That rude person didn‚Äôt follow even the minimum level of professional behavior. He started misbehaving right from the beginning. When he made a mistake, he tried to prove that I was wrong instead. At one point, I even considered walking out of the interview. I held myself back twice but stayed, hoping it would end soon. But it didn‚Äôt end. Instead, he started asking unclear questions and kept talking on his phone during the interview. He didn‚Äôt let me properly answer and interrupted constantly. When I gave a different opinion on something, he became even more disrespectful. Eventually, the interview ended and I left. On my way home, I kept thinking ‚Äî why did I even go for the 8RAC IT interview after seeing so many bad reviews? Also, I don‚Äôt understand why 8RAC IT management would send someone like him to take interviews. After coming home, I searched on LinkedIn and found his name ‚Äî P****z H*****n . He has only around 3.5 to 4 years of experience and has already switched 3‚Äì4 companies. This is the situation. My humble request: If anyone plans to attend an interview at 8RAC IT, please be mentally strong and prepared beforehand.

post_title: The Real Price of Cha1da1 Engineering's High Salary
full_review: Pros: Competitive Compensation: The salary is among the highest in the Bangladeshi software industry. Talented Colleagues: You will work alongside some of the nicest and smartest individuals in the Chaldal Engineering team. Engaging Work: Opportunities to take on significant and interesting projects arise from a very early stage. Knowledgeable CTO: The CTO possesses deep technical knowledge and expertise. Meritocratic Environment: Performance is the primary basis for judgment, and credit for your work is duly given. No Office Politics: The workplace is generally free from office politics. Cons: Compensation and Working Hours: Delayed Salary Payment: Salaries are typically disbursed around the 20th-25th of the following month. High Hours, Lower Effective Rate: While the monthly salary is high, the effective hourly rate can be significantly lower due to the extensive hours required compared to other companies in Bangladesh. There are no fixed work hours; you are expected to work until tasks are completed. Pervasive Overtime: Employees are frequently pushed to work overtime, including on weekends. This is the norm rather than the exception, and there is no additional compensation for these extra hours. Some individuals may even be required to work on Eid day without compensation if critical issues ("alarms") arise. Eid Bonus Structure: The Eid bonus is divided, with half paid before Eid and the other half after. (consider this a feature, so you don't spend all your money before Eid) Work-Life Balance and Leave Policies: Non-Existent Work-Life Balance: Achieving a healthy work-life balance is extremely challenging and not a recognized priority. Restrictive HR Policies: HR policies are notably poor. New employees receive no paid leave (including sick leave or for Eid/Puja celebrations) during their first six months. Any time off for Eid or Puja during this initial period is unpaid. Limited Holiday and Leave Access: Public holidays are not formally observed. Instead, employees receive a fixed number of leave days per year, but obtaining approval for this leave can be very difficult. Employees are often discouraged from taking their entitled leave. Management, Culture, and Work Environment: Intense Work Pressure: Work pressure is immense, with expectations set so high that maintaining a personal life while attempting to meet them becomes nearly impossible. Unrealistic Deadlines: Engineers are often subjected to overly tight or unrealistic deadlines, which are frequently imposed without their consultation or consent. Centralized Decision-Making: The CTO holds a virtual monopoly on decision-making. Team leads are often hesitant to voice dissenting opinions or challenge decisions, even if they perceive the CTO to be mistaken. CTO's Expectation Discrepancy: While highly knowledgeable, the CTO sometimes seems to overlook that not all team members possess his extensive (e.g., 20 years) experience. This can make it challenging to explain why tasks may take longer than he anticipates, as complex issues might appear simpler from his perspective. Limited Authority for Team Leads: Team leads often have more theoretical than practical authority, with minimal input in significant decision-making processes. Excessive Micromanagement: There is a significant degree of micromanagement. Higher management frequently bypasses team leads and direct managers to request updates directly from individual employees. Misaligned Management Focus: Overall management practices appear to be more focused on micromanaging employees rather than proactively addressing their concerns or solving systemic problems. Perceived Favoritism: Management may exhibit bias towards certain favored individuals, who tend to receive greater flexibility regarding work-from-home arrangements, work hours, and leave requests. Job Security Concerns: There is a risk of sudden termination without adequate prior warning or proper compensation. Over-reliance on Technological Solutions: Higher management appears to operate under the conviction that every problem can and should be solved primarily with a technological solution, sometimes overlooking other viable approaches. Negative Public Perception: Cha1da1's brand image is perceived quite negatively among the public, which can sometimes make it uncomfortable for employees to identify themselves with the company. This public sentiment appears to be significantly fueled by issues such as repetitive unsolicited calls. Misaligned Project Motivations: There's a perception that some features and tasks are prioritized more to impress investors rather than to genuinely improve the core business or address customer needs.

post_title: The good, the improving and why I still enjoy being here
full_review: In my 4+ years with the company, I've experienced a healthy and collaborative work environment. It's a place where a Head of Department and a junior developer can sit side by side without ego‚Äîleaders are friendly and approachable. Salaries are always on time (only delayed once due to a holiday), and the hybrid work option adds great flexibility. The company recently increased sick leave to 12 days alongside 15 annual leave days. The diverse mix of junior, mid, and senior team members creates a solid ground for learning and career growth. Some of the business team members are genuinely dedicated and work hand-in-hand with Devs and QAs to keep things running. You‚Äôll find flexibility and a healthy work-life balance here if you're skilled and can manage your time. Areas for improvement? Eid bonus, better New Year gifts, slightly higher salary increments, and more investment in research would be appreciated. Every experience can vary by department, but unless you‚Äôre extremely unlucky, this is a genuinely great place to work. No place is perfect, but today, I choose to stay positive. Life goes on‚Äîand so does good work.

Once a company known for its culture and ability to attract the best talent in the market, now turned into a ticking time bomb about to go off. Every day someone somewhere around the globe is leaving or is getting fired, management has no idea what to do, has been this way ever since.¬† A big big reason high level directors, managers and team leads worth their salt are leaving before going down with the ship. This is a big no-no for anyone in their mid/high level career because this company can neither provide the growth nor the stability you need, and no it's not something you can overturn with your performance or vigor. There is subtle racism when working with foreign teams, perks of being a low-cost labor from 3rd third-world country, you would never get an invitation to attend the high-level decision making meetings, just a worker assigned to follow orders once they are revealed. All that being said, it is the perfect company for Gen Z peeps in their early career, hardly any micromanagement, insane level of flexibility, salary is really good compared to the country median. Basically anyone who wants to add a few months of job experience in their cv while preparing for abroad, you cannot ask for anything better but beware do fall under the comfort zone trap, before you know it you will either lose chance at a good career or get kicked out randomly and become a floater.

Positive Side 1. CEO is very friendly and good human being. 2. Job Security. 3. Low office politics. Negative Side. 1. No privacy you will be monitored by CCTV 2. If you work in sales team your life is gone. 3. Sales meeting after office hour for 30-40 minutes. 4. You can't take leave easily. 5. No evening snacks. 6. For emergency you can't go out durning office hour.

The positive reviews you see on Glassdoor are written by employees under pressure from management. This is a third-party company that asks people to leave their permanent jobs with promises of quick placement opportunities. But once you join, they often fail to place you with any client. Later, they‚Äôll terminate your contract without any notice or valid reason, using lame excuses. They have no regard for people‚Äôs careers and make decisions carelessly. This company won‚Äôt hesitate to dismiss you without valid explanation, acting clueless about the damage they‚Äôre doing to people‚Äôs careers while pretending everything is fine. When it‚Äôs time to let you go, the COO will casually say ‚ÄúI feel very ashamed‚Äù and then wave you off with a ‚Äúbye bye‚Äù ‚Äî honestly, they should be the ones feeling truly ashamed. Think twice before getting involved with them. Worst experience ever.

post_title: Some good colleagues. Good work life balance. Terrible HR. But I guess you can only pick two in this triangle.
full_review: The people here are truly one of the company‚Äôs biggest assets. The engineering talent is top-notch, with colleagues who are not only highly skilled but also supportive and approachable. Whether you're a fresher just starting out or a senior engineer with years of experience, you'll find the environment inclusive and empowering. There‚Äôs a strong emphasis on continuous learning, and the company as a whole is filled with industry thought leaders. If you know 10 incredible level engineers, there is a good chance 4 of them work at opti now. In 10 years I feel people at opti will be considered mafia of leadership in bd same like paypal people. However, not everything is as bright as it used to be. Over the past year or so, many of the great benefits that once set the company apart and attracted the best talent in the country are gradually being scaled back. In the name of cost-cutting and budget management, some perks that made a real difference to employee morale are being removed. For instance, the company used to offer unlimited paid time off (PTO), a rare and generous policy that helped employees truly disconnect and recharge. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs no longer available ‚Äî now replaced with a capped PTO policy that feels more traditional and restrictive. What used to be great food now has limits on how many you can eat or even runs out of food (yep, you heard me right). What used to be flexible internet benefits is now cancelled. What used to be great office goodies is now non existent. What used to be great coffee culture now has a machine that needs to rest like it has arthritis. What used to be great budget for team outings now has depreciated like 50% with no adjustment so now its not enough for a team outing. What used to be great company after office hours is now being vilified online by radical religious people that the company somehow hired itself (so its the companys fault not to hire people who are culture fit here). Basically lots of new kamla people who misuse company benefits and speak ill of everything here, but still chakri charbe na because they know there is no better place than this. Sad that the hiring bar is low these days and they will hire literally anybody. This is what happens when there is no HR leadership in place and its run by people in other countries who have no idea of how things work here. You can't have remote HR leadership in a company same as how you can't have remote cleaners. Just doesn't make sense. On the other hand, the frequent firing of staff is also very bad in terms of morale and long term growth. Its safe to say no Japanese company would approve of this, and every US company would love this. If you know, you know. The physical office space is also beginning to show signs of strain. While remote work is common and usually prevents overcrowding, there are certain days when many people come in ‚Äî and that‚Äôs when the limitations become clear. The office isn‚Äôt large enough to comfortably accommodate everyone at once, and some employees find themselves without a proper place to sit or have a meeting or simply find some time to think about what is at hand. I read someone commenting that the infrastructure hasn‚Äôt kept up with the growth of the company and its very true. In summary, this is still a great place to work, especially for those who value strong engineering culture, flexibility, and a community of talented peers. But it‚Äôs hard to ignore the fact that some of the elements that made it truly exceptional are fading. The hope is that leadership recognizes this trend and takes steps to preserve what made the company special in the first place. You can't cost cut your way out of everything. Good culture and good people make a real difference, and they aren't cheap. Also, please stop hiring people who clearly have no respect for people who dont prescribe to the same religious views and aren't a culture fit in an international company.

comments.comment_text: A good review. I agree with the points mentioned about hiring individuals who are not culturally fit.

full_review: In terms of the office environment, work-life balance, and available resources, there is hardly any room for dissatisfaction. One of the best parts of working here is the team culture‚Äîwe often share food, enjoy casual gossip together, and even participate in sports and other fun activities, which makes the workplace lively and enjoyable. However, the company has been facing a persistent issue‚Äî salary delays for the past three years ‚Äîwhich is increasingly becoming a source of frustration for many of the employees. It‚Äôs a concern that affects overall motivation and morale. Hope that the management takes this issue seriously and addresses it soon for the well-being and retention of its talented team.

full_review: Mogoj Station 23 might look like a tech powerhouse from the outside ‚Äî big name, many projects, global clients, and a cool vibe. But once you step inside, you realize it‚Äôs less of a unified company and more of a bunch of SBUs ( small business units) stitched together with a fancy logo. Each one runs like its own little startup, with its own rules, leadership, and chaos level. To be fair, not all SBUs are bad. Some are‚Ä¶ fine. Not toxic, not great ‚Äî just average. You do your tasks, survive your meetings, and go home. No one yells, but no one really helps either. You float. You exist. But here‚Äôs the real issue: across the board, there‚Äôs very little focus on actual growth . No real mentorship No proper career path No structured learning No recognition unless you're part of the " oil club" And bonuses/ promotions? Let‚Äôs just say, don‚Äôt hold your breath In some SBUs, it gets worse ‚Äî with seniors who act like juniors are here to serve them, not learn. Their main job? Blame downwards, praise upwards, and pretend to be busy only when the boss shows up. You‚Äôll often see people running around with open laptops like they‚Äôre hacking into NASA, but the second the manager leaves, it‚Äôs back to chilling and blaming juniors for literally everything ‚Äî even bugs they never touched. So, if you're thinking of joining BS23: You might land in a tolerable team and just‚Ä¶ coast Or, you might find yourself stuck in a loop of thankless work, minimal learning, and zero recognition Either way, don‚Äôt expect to grow much . You‚Äôll get tasks, but not direction. Work, but not wisdom. Deadlines, but not development. It‚Äôs not a horror story ‚Äî just a slow burn where your motivation quietly disappears, and one day you realize‚Ä¶ your career hasn‚Äôt moved at all.

post_title: A Cautionary Tale for Interns and Developers
full_review: A Harsh Reality ‚Äì More Like¬† "Intern Solutions" I want to highlight some of the major issues I‚Äôve witnessed: Exploitation of Interns: The management often hires interns and places them under immense pressure to meet tight client deadlines. In many cases, entire projects are handed over to interns with little to no senior oversight. After 3-4 months of overwork, these interns are dismissed without any real consideration or offer of permanent employment. It‚Äôs no surprise that many people now refer to the company as "Intern Solutions". Unethical Work Culture: Interns are led to believe that good performance might lead to permanent roles. However, under the leadership of PM, this turns out to be a false hope. Interns are routinely forced to work 12‚Äì15 hours per day, often handling the responsibilities of full-time developers. Despite this, they are paid only 6000 BDT, with no overtime compensation or weekend pay. Lack of Accountability Among Senior Staff: Senior developers, particularly Frontend Lead, frequently avoid their responsibilities. Common excuses like "no electricity" are used to skip workdays, while in reality, they go shopping or take naps during working hours. This behavior leaves junior developers and interns to carry the workload. When deliverables are delayed, CEO blames the remaining developers instead of addressing the root of the problem. Toxic Team Dynamics: Developers like frontend lead, involved in component development, often waste significant time without producing results. Their inefficiency causes delays that impact the whole team. Yet, they escape accountability while others are pressured to clean up the mess. Final Thoughts: company needs to seriously rethink its values and treatment of interns and junior developers. If you're considering joining this company, especially as an intern, be very cautious. Don‚Äôt be fooled by empty promises. The management‚Äôs lack of ethics and the senior staff‚Äôs irresponsibility create an extremely unfair and demotivating work environment.

Some Departments are very royal in their own terms. They have got decent flexibility, salary, bonus and monthly incentives. The CEO had no tech background but insisted he was a ‚Äúvisionary.‚Äù He constantly changed the company‚Äôs direction‚Äîfrom AI to crypto to something called ‚Äúquantum wellness‚Äù‚Äîusually based on whatever podcast he listened to that morning. He fired and rehired people weekly, often by accident. HR who treated serious complaints like a joke and believed ‚Äústartup life‚Äù meant no boundaries and no accountability. Confidential issues were routinely shared in company-wide Slack threads, usually with memes. Previous CTO hadn‚Äôt touched code in years. She blocked progress with endless meetings, confusing jargon, and feedback like ‚Äúmake it more scalable‚Ä¶ vibes-wise.‚Äù The product barely worked and crashed if more than 10 users logged in. 2atiq finally collapsed after burning millions in funding with nothing to show but a broken app, a toxic culture, and a farewell email accidentally sent to investors with a poop emoji.

post_title: Good Culture with Lots of Injustice and Deception
full_review: Stable and timely salary, good amount (100-300k BDT) Generous yearly profit-sharing (approximately ‚Çπ2 lakh). Two festival bonuses per year. All government holidays off, plus two-day weekends. Free office lunch and transportation. Government-approved sick and casual leave, along with 10 cashable vacation days. Modern and luxurious office space located in Gulshan 1. Ethical concern: According to some Islamic scholars, the income may be considered non-compliant due to involvement in the US healthcare insurance sector, which is linked to interest-based (usury) models. Recruitment transparency is lacking: Highly qualified candidates are often hired under one job title but assigned to unrelated and less meaningful roles, which can negatively impact career growth. You might be hired for a Python role but the work might end up being AWS cloud management. <DANGEROUS> Internal politics and conflict: There is a noticeable divide between junior and senior employees, creating a hostile work environment. Poor managerial oversight: Due to weak supervision from US-based leadership, local managers may misuse authority, leading to toxic interactions‚Äîthough company policy does not permit outright abuse. Unprofessional culture: Expect unkind or rude behavior from some senior staff. Time-off challenges: Vacation days are difficult to utilize in full, with approvals being rare/toxic beyond sick leaves. No job security: Salaries are routed through a third-party entity not clearly tied to the parent company (Veradigm), raising legal and stability concerns. Absence of a dedicated HR team makes it hard to address misconduct or improve workplace culture effectively. The company offers solid compensation and benefits, along with a modern workplace. However, serious concerns exist regarding ethical alignment, role clarity, internal conflicts, and managerial accountability. Great culture potential‚Äîbut undermined by poor leadership and toxic individuals.

They even use cheap tactics like: Threatening to hold back your salary for being late, while pretending to forget you‚Äôve worked countless late nights for their clients. post_title: A Toxic Family-Run Circus Disguised as a Company
full_review: This isn‚Äôt a company‚Äîit‚Äôs a family-run disaster. Nearly every employee is a cousin, sibling, or distant relative. If you're not part of their bloodline, you're nothing more than disposable labor. The so-called CEO operates remotely from the UK, pretending to lead a global business merger while exploiting cheap Bangladeshi workers who carry the entire workload without fair compensation, appreciation, or timely pay. Salaries are constantly delayed with recycled excuses, and raises are a fantasy unless you're a relative or a shameless bootlicker. Promotions aren‚Äôt based on performance or skill‚Äîthey‚Äôre based on who you're related to or how well you can suck up to management. The hiring process is laughable. Interviews exist only to maintain a facade. If you're not already ‚Äúin‚Äù with the family or one of their minions, you‚Äôre wasting your time. Most decisions are made behind closed doors with zero transparency or fairness. The company is infested with toxic employees whose only talent is flattery. These leeches secure permanent positions while hardworking, talented staff are ignored, mistreated, or pushed out. There‚Äôs constant verbal abuse, public humiliation, and no HR accountability‚Äîbecause HR is just another family puppet who makes and breaks rules on a whim. The company‚Äôs leadership is a complete farce. Two brothers act as co-owners, but their incompetence and lack of integrity are glaring. They preach about professionalism, but their actions reflect pure hypocrisy. They create strict policies only to break them for themselves and their favorites. Recently, they promoted another unqualified cousin to the role of C00. This individual lacks basic manners, education, or leadership qualities‚Äîbut got the job solely through nepotism. He now walks around barking orders with no clue how to lead. Employee benefits? Another joke. ‚ÄúUnlimited coffee‚Äù turns into monthly salary deductions if you drink more than two cups a day. Lunch? Controlled with petty rules. Time off? If you‚Äôre family, you get it without question. If not, good luck getting approved. If a relative called G4ND00 leaves and goes abroad, they can return months later and be reinstated immediately. But for others, even a one-week gap means :D¬† no chance of return. This company operates on favoritism, manipulation, and exploitation. There's no clear vision, no ethical foundation, and absolutely no long-term potential. It's a classic example of how nepotism in business creates a toxic, demoralizing, and completely broken workplace‚Äîwhere real talent is ignored and incompetence rises to the top.

They act as if not doing overtime means your performance is bad. They continuously bug you on weekends to work. Almost all the external projects have failed. Very poor at project estimation, which leads to unbearable overtime. If you are a fresher, mid-level, or even a senior engineer ‚Äî just avoid it.
