Since joining Nerddevs in January 2025, my experience has been genuinely positive. Although it‚Äôs a small company, Nerddevs follows professional-level policies and practices, making it an ideal workplace for Software Engineers and Developers. On-Time Salary ‚Äì Always received before the end of the month. Flexible Working Hours ‚Äì Promotes a healthy work-life balance. Positive Work Environment ‚Äì Respectful, friendly, and free from toxicity. Office Comforts ‚Äì Snacks and indoor games to refresh during breaks. Power Nap Option ‚Äì Encouraged to take short naps if feeling sleepy or unwell. Company Activities ‚Äì Annual tour and dinner (looking forward to the upcoming one!), Eid gifts. Supportive Leadership ‚Äì Friendly, accessible, and genuinely understanding management. Empathetic Ownership ‚Äì The company owners are not only professional but also super friendly, approachable, and deeply understanding. They lead with empathy and support, making the work culture even more positive. Remote Work Flexibility ‚Äì 5 to 7 days of home office before and after Eid. Emergency Remote Access ‚Äì Option to work from home during urgent needs. Paid Leave ‚Äì 15 days annually, with the option to carry forward up to 5 unused days. Oh, and sick leaves they don't even touch those 15üòé. Like any workplace, there may be challenges, but here, the pros outweigh and even eliminate the cons . Nerddevs may be a small team, but it offers everything a professional developer needs to grow, thrive, and stay motivated . A sincere dua from my heart for the continued success and growth of Nerddevs.

If you're someone looking to build a long-term career in a structured, growth-oriented, and employee-friendly environment, Pr!yoSh0p may not be the ideal place for you. 1) Despite being a tech-driven organization, employees, even those in technical roles, are often treated like sales personnel. The company enforces a strict office entry time but does not maintain a consistent exit time policy. Working 11‚Äì12 hours a day is quite common. The workload can feel like you‚Äôre expected to perform the job of five people simultaneously. 2) Mistakes, even minor ones, are treated disproportionately harshly. Personal life often takes a back seat, and taking leave, especially for significant life events like marriage, can be extremely difficult. While most companies offer a week or more for marital leave, at Pr!yoSh0p, getting more than three days off can feel like a battle. 3) The physical work environment also leaves much to be desired. The office building lacks an elevator, requiring employees to climb to the 4th or 5th floor daily. 4) Nepotism is a notable issue. Long-time employees who joined from their university days are often given undue preference and influence, creating a clear divide between them and newer team members. 5) Lastly, leadership appears to be more focused on external recognition than internal development. The CEO frequently travels to international events to receive awards, which raises questions about the credibility and impact of these accolades on actual organizational health. In summary, Pr!yoSh0p may not be suitable for professionals who value work-life balance, fair treatment, structured growth, and a supportive work culture. Proceed with caution if you're considering building your career there.

post_title: A Candid Look Inside Truck Dorkar ‚Äì From a Once-Thriving Tech Hub to a Company in Decline
full_review: Rcently, I noticed that Truck Dorkar h as received some negative attention on platforms like *Deshi Mula*. In response, it seems the company is attempting to counter that criticism with a series of overly positive‚Äîand possibly fabricated‚Äîreviews on Glassdoor. I believe it‚Äôs important to share an honest and balanced perspective of the actual situation within the company. The Golden Days of the Tech Team There was a time when Truck Dorkar was a vibrant hub for talented engineers and product thinkers. The tech team, composed of passionate, curious, and hard-working individuals, built a unique culture from the ground up. Many were fresh graduates who quickly grew through hands-on experience, learning from one another and pushing the boundaries of what a small team could achieve. Under the leadership of the CTO, the team thrived in an environment that felt more like a family than a workplace. Though there were few additional perks, the regular salary payments, team outings, and in-office celebrations helped form strong bonds among colleagues. The CTO‚Äôs open-door policy fostered trust and encouraged individuals to voice ideas and concerns. This culture of collaboration made Truck Dorkar a standout place to work for many engineers. One of the best practices during those times was the annual salary increment for the tech team. While not always perfect, the process‚Äîdriven by the tech leads and ‚Äîensured that contributions were recognized, making it one of the more rewarding tech workplaces compared to others in the industry. The Beginning of the Decline Unfortunately, things began to change with the arrival of a new Head of HR. His management approach introduced rigid and demotivating policies, despite the company offering no additional facilities beyond the monthly salary. He disrupted the previously smooth salary increment process, often delaying reviews and responding unprofessionally to employees who raised concerns. Telling valued team members to ‚Äúfind another job‚Äù simply for seeking fair compensation was not only disrespectful but deeply damaging to morale. This marked the beginning of the breakdown of a once-solid culture. Product Leadership Shift and Disconnect The departure of the former VP of Product further accelerated the decline. Under her leadership, the product and tech teams worked closely and harmoniously. After she left, the relationship between the two teams deteriorated, and the company saw a series of unsuccessful product launches. The lack of strategic direction and synergy hurt the tech team‚Äôs momentum and motivation. Final Downfall and Talent Exodus In recent months, the situation has worsened. The CEO consistently failed to deliver on promises regarding salary revisions and increments, leading to a growing mistrust among the employees. Morale plummeted, and many talented individuals began to question their future with the company. One defining moment was when the lead of the app team took a stand over unfulfilled commitments. Instead of engaging constructively, management responded harshly‚Äîdespite her significant contributions. This led to a wave of resignations, including that of the CTO, marking the end of an era. Today, the remaining team members are disillusioned, actively seeking better opportunities. It‚Äôs heartbreaking to see such a once-promising and inspiring workplace decline so sharply due to poor HR practices, non-technical decision-making, and a lack of appreciation for the tech team‚Äôs efforts. A Word to Future Employers and Current Management To anyone hiring‚Äîif you come across former Truck Dorkar engineers, know that you‚Äôre looking at smart, hard-working, and genuinely collaborative people. They deserve better environments and will surely add great value wherever they go. To the current management‚Äîthere may still be time to turn things around. But that requires humility, a return to people-first leadership, and a commitment to rebuild trust with the remaining employees. If things continue as they are, it‚Äôs only a matter of time before W e the last of the committed employees decide to leave as well.

post_title: This is not a company it's a Circus
full_review: I joined this company over two years ago, and here‚Äôs my honest experience. Pros: 1. Salary is always on time. 2. You can learn skills for yourself‚Äîonly for your personal growth. That‚Äôs it. Now let‚Äôs talk about the Cons, which honestly feel endless. So here it comes: 1. The Managers ‚Äì Completely unqualified, unprofessional, and have no idea what they‚Äôre doing. Every developer here knows how outdated and clueless they are. They just throw random tasks around without understanding anything. Total joke. 2. The Management ‚Äì Another level of disaster. Outdated mindset, zero professionalism. One of them has random mood swings and starts shouting over the most trivial stuff. Tho the CTO as a person is quite nice, but in terms of leadership? Meh. Now this one deserves a drumroll ‚Äì the most corrupted department in the company ‚Äì 3. üó£Ô∏èüéôÔ∏è THE SQA DEPARTMENT. They literally have a full floor to themselves. And trust me, most of them joined with only one qualification: their face. That‚Äôs it. No skills, no brains ‚Äì nothing. I know some of them personally and they don‚Äôt even have this. And skills? Don‚Äôt even ask. They don‚Äôt know jack about automation. Half of them don‚Äôt even understand how software works. Over 50 people in that department doing God knows what. Full-on circus. 4. IT Department ‚Äì They walk around like they're some tech gods. Reality? Skills so basic that if they didn‚Äôt have this job, they‚Äôd probably be fixing Wi-Fi routers or working as local mechanics. No respect, no manners‚Äînothing. 5. HR Department ‚Äì I don't want to start, but thak mukh ta kharap na kori. No brains. If they ask you for a document, be prepared to submit it 5-6 times and they‚Äôll still come asking. Unbelievably unprofessional. They delay increments, they forget things constantly. And recruitment? Clueless. The accountant acts like he‚Äôs some high-level government babu. Full-on garbage attitude. Talking about increment? These guys only look at the years of experience. I have no idea how they hire. 6. DevOps Team ‚Äì If they think they‚Äôre DevOps, then trust me, I could be their team lead with one hand tied. They're stuck in 1990s technology. Every time you suggest something new‚Äî"Security issue", "too expensive", "too modern", bla bla bla. They are so outdated it's embarrassing. Honestly, I have serious doubts if the CDO even studied anything related to tech. 7. If you actually have skills‚Äîyou‚Äôll be ignored. Every year, a pity 10K increment. But if you‚Äôre good at licking boots, congratulations again‚Äîyou‚Äôre climbing up the ladder fast. No need for skills, just chaapar jor. I've seen so-called ‚ÄúSenior Software Engineers‚Äù who barely have the skills of a trainee. Still, I‚Äôll be fair‚Äîthere are a few genuinely talented people here. And honestly, they are the only reason this company is still standing. So yeah, if you want to grow for yourself, learn some tech for your own future, then maybe it's worth staying. But if you‚Äôre expecting decent salary, good leadership, or even basic professionalism‚Äîbhule jao. You ain‚Äôt getting any of that here.

full_review: I had a very disappointing experience working at this company. The HR, Admin, and Accounts departments lack basic professionalism. Most of them don‚Äôt even know how to properly do their jobs. HR has no decision-making power and simply follows whatever Accounts says. The Admin team is always focused on cutting employee benefits to reduce company expenses. The Accounts department spends more time pointing fingers at others than doing their own work. There is only one day off per week, and even that doesn‚Äôt feel like proper rest. There are no benefits, no extra allowances, and nothing that supports employee well-being. Management lacks planning, coordination, and vision. The overall work culture is toxic and inhumane.

The company has seen a significant decline following the resignation or reassignment of several changemakers, largely due to persistent internal politics. The current management in Bangladesh demonstrates a lack of empathy. For example, public holidays declared during Eid and Buddha Purnima were not honored. Employees were required to work from home on these days without any form of compensation. Furthermore, although Tuesdays are typically work-from-home days, employees are compelled to work from the office if there's a public holiday that week. Certain senior employees ‚Äî including some in top management ‚Äî consistently avoid taking ownership of their mistakes and tend to shift blame onto others. Some workaholic employees create a toxic atmosphere by imposing their intense work habits on others, making it extremely difficult to collaborate effectively. Members of the top management have been disconnected from hands-on development for over a decade. One individual in particular is notably resistant to new ideas or technologies and insists on giving opinions on topics outside his expertise, often hindering progress. The HR processes are outdated. The company does not provide pay slips, promotion letters, or formal documentation of salary revisions, which is surprising for an organization of this size. While food is often cited as a company perk, the quality is consistently poor. Many employees have reported stomach issues or illness after eating in the office cafeteria. Overall, the work environment lacks the positivity and support needed for employee well-being. The culture contributes to stress, burnout, and low morale, leaving little motivation to come into the office.

post_title: A Real Look Inside BRAC IT: What Many Won‚Äôt Say Out Loud
full_review: 1. Hiring and Promotion Aren‚Äôt Always Fair Despite what the official statement says, many people inside BRAC IT feel that hiring and promotions often depend more on personal connections than merit. Teams, especially under certain leaders, are filled with friends and past colleagues. There‚Äôs no proper performance review system, so it‚Äôs hard to understand how promotions are actually decided. 2. Religious Bias May Not Be ‚ÄúOfficial,‚Äù But It‚Äôs There BRAC IT claims to be secular, but some leadership members have openly shown atheist views, and a few have even shared anti-Islamic comments in the past. While personal beliefs are private, the way they influence team culture can make others feel uncomfortable or excluded. 3. Speaking Up Isn‚Äôt Always Safe or Easy The company encourages using ‚Äúproper channels‚Äù to raise concerns, but what are those, really? Many employees feel there‚Äôs no trusted space to talk about internal problems. Management is aware of these issues but seems unwilling to make changes, and that‚Äôs frustrating when people‚Äôs careers and livelihoods are at stake. To make things worse, firing people without explanation happens often. We live in constant fear of being let go for no clear reason, and the abuse of power feels like a normal part of the culture. 4. Impact Is Mostly Through BRAC, Not Independent Innovation BRAC IT often talks about making a difference in Bangladesh, but most of that impact comes from being tied to BRAC. Outside of that, there's little innovation happening. The microfinance project, its main offering- is based on interest, which many employees see as conflicting with ethical or religious values. 5. Criticism Shouldn‚Äôt Be Dismissed as Hate Yes, no one should spread hate or attack others based on faith. But calling all criticism ‚Äúhate speech‚Äù is a way to shut down real issues. People just want honesty, fairness, and a healthy work culture, things every organization should take seriously.

We always welcome constructive criticism and use it as a tool for growth. However, we find it necessary to respond when a review contains misleading, generalized, and borderline defamatory statements aimed at discrediting the hard work of hundreds of professionals who contribute to the success of this company every day.
Let us address the points made with transparency:
No Real Pros
Let‚Äôs start with the obvious: salary is paid timely every month, and our employees receive free meals, generous leave, and a stable work environment‚Äîsomething many companies in the industry struggle to guarantee. Calling this ‚Äúzero benefits‚Äù is simply dishonest.
Inherited Bg!T Culture & Random Promotions
This is a false narrative. Our company has developed its own identity, structure, and work culture over the years. Promotions go through a standardized, performance-based review process and are approved after review by multiple stakeholders. Individuals are promoted based on KPIs, skill contributions, and behavior‚Äînot favoritism.
If someone misunderstood a designation or someone‚Äôs title, that‚Äôs a lack of awareness‚Äînot the company‚Äôs failure.
Two CTOs Contribute Nothing
We won‚Äôt entertain vague attacks on leadership based on assumptions. Our CTOs are responsible for key decision-making on infrastructure, client solutions, and technical architecture. They may not be visible in day-to-day stand-ups, but their impact is very much reflected in our delivery success and growth.
Managers are Unqualified & Promote Insecurity
This kind of blanket statement is both offensive and untrue. Our managers are hired through stringent screening‚Äîmany with 5‚Äì10+ years of experience across local and international projects. If someone had personal friction with a manager, they had the option to escalate it. But public slander is not how professionals resolve conflict.
Unpaid Overtime, Labor Law Violation
We do not mandate overtime‚Äîteams manage their own delivery timelines. In tech companies, occasional stretches happen before releases. To generalize this as labor law violation is misleading.
Our working hours are aligned with industry norms, and we‚Äôre continuously improving work-life balance across teams.
HR is a Constant Disaster
While we acknowledge some process delays in the past (especially during transitions like ERP migration), we have already made significant improvements‚Äîdigital onboarding, automated documentation, and trackable increment cycles.
Filling out a form multiple times usually stems from incomplete submission, not HR inefficiency.
Office Conditions Are Bad
We‚Äôve invested in a new workspace, and any infrastructure issue (e.g., AC installation, seating, etc.) is being addressed. We take employee health and hygiene very seriously, and multiple teams (Admin, Facilities) are working on feedback shared during this transition.
Firing Without Reason
This is categorically false. Every termination is backed by documentation‚Äîbe it performance issues, code of conduct violations, or contractual non-compliance. We also provide warnings and PIPs (Performance Improvement Plans) where applicable.
Dismissals are not based on someone ‚Äúnot liking an idea.‚Äù That‚Äôs not how we operate.
DevOps, BA, Designers, Security = All Bad?
Attacking every tech and support team with generic accusations and insults shows more about the reviewer's mindset than our departments.


DevOps: Our deployment pipelines are containerized, CI/CD integrated, and aligned with cloud best practices.


BA Team: They define business flow, handle documentation, and are crucial in ensuring client satisfaction.


Design Team: Our work has been delivered across global clients, appreciated for both UI/UX and innovation.


Security: Awareness sessions are for user education. Real security policies, WAF rules, and code-level scans are handled internally‚Äînot on public display.


No Recognition or Reward
Recognition exists‚Äîand many employees have received bonuses, performance-based increments, promotions, international opportunities, and training access. But recognition doesn‚Äôt mean giving in to every demand or tolerating disruptive behavior.
Final Words
We respect freedom of expression, but malicious, baseless, and exaggerated reviews damage not just company reputation but also demotivate the hardworking teams you‚Äôve unfairly criticized.
We are proud of our employees, and we will not stay silent when they are misrepresented.
If you had real issues, the door to HR and senior leadership was always open. Choosing anonymous defamation over resolution is not the mark of professionalism.
We remain focused on continuous improvement‚Äîand on building a company where merit, respect, and accountability are the foundations of success.

post_title: Why BRAC IT Becoming Selies 2.0 ‚Äì A Comedy Show in IT World
reviewer_role: SOMEONE FROM HIRING TEAM OF BRAC IT
full_review: BRAC IT is not just an IT company anymore. It‚Äôs turning into Selies 2.0 , aka "Revenge of the Nerds ‚Äì Bangladesh Edition." Why? Because their CTO, Mr. T**u, came from Selies. And guess what? He brought half the Selies IT team with him ‚Äì like it‚Äôs a picnic, not a company. No qualification check, no skill check ‚Äì just ‚ÄúBro, come join!‚Äù It‚Äôs not hiring, it‚Äôs ‚Äúbring your friends to work‚Äù day ‚Äì every day . Rumor says T**u had some drama with Selies before. So now he‚Äôs turning BRAC IT into a Selies clone, maybe to show ‚Äúwho‚Äôs boss now.‚Äù It's not IT, it's IT-vengers: Endgame . Also, interviews? What‚Äôs that? BRAC IT doesn‚Äôt do interviews if you're from Selies. Just say ‚ÄúSelies‚Äù and they open the gate like you're VIP. So now, BRAC IT is not ‚ÄúBetter IT,‚Äù it‚Äôs ‚Äú Budget Selies with extra drama .‚Äù How to Fix BRAC IT Turning into Selies 2.0 ‚Äì The Rescue Plan Okay BRAC IT, don‚Äôt panic. You can still stop the ‚ÄúSelies Invasion.‚Äù Here's how to fix it before it becomes a full-blown IT soap opera: Stop Hiring Like It's a Family Picnic Just because someone worked in Selies doesn't mean they‚Äôre an IT ninja. Use interviews. Real ones. Not ‚ÄúHey bro, you free from Selies? Join BRAC IT!‚Äù Check Skills, Not Friend List Want to build a strong team? Try checking CVs and skills, not just if someone was in T**u Bhai‚Äôs old gang. A company is not a reunion party. Create a Real Hiring Process Interviews should have questions, not coffee and gossip. HR should be HR, not ‚ÄúOld Selies Club President.‚Äù Build BRAC IT Identity, Not Selies Reloaded BRAC IT needs its own culture, not a Selies remix. Make it unique, not ‚ÄúSelies with a new logo.‚Äù Keep Emotions Out of Business If T**u Bhai wants revenge, tell him to play PUBG, not run a company like a revenge drama. Business needs logic, not serial plot twists. Bring Diversity in Team Mix it up! Get fresh minds, from other companies, even new grads. BRAC IT should look like a tech team, not a Selies reunion photo.

post_title: A Cautionary Tale from a Current SQA Engineer - Proceed with Extreme Caution
full_review: A Cautionary Tale from a Current SQA Engineer - Proceed with Extreme Caution As an SQA Engineer at Allgentech, I feel compelled to share a brutally honest account of my experience for the sake of transparency. While I joined with hope and ambition, it has become increasingly clear that this company is plagued by deep-rooted issues that make it a toxic and unstable place to work. 1. Lack of Leadership & Guidance The team lead's absence of direction has been a major hurdle. There‚Äôs no mentorship, no structured feedback, and no clear roadmap. Junior team members are often left to fend for themselves, resulting in confusion, inefficiency, and a massive dent in morale. This isn‚Äôt just mismanagement‚Äîit‚Äôs outright neglect. 2. Job Security is Nonexistent One of the most distressing aspects of working here is the constant cloud of uncertainty. Decisions are made arbitrarily, and there's zero transparency from upper management. Several capable engineers have been let go without explanation or due process. If you're looking for a stable, growth-oriented role‚Äîlook elsewhere. 3. Unacceptable Behavior from Leadership Perhaps the most disturbing issue has been the unprofessional and borderline sexually inappropriate behavior from the Principal. What makes it worse is that these actions go unchecked. The company's inaction in the face of such misconduct reflects an appalling lack of integrity and accountability. No one should feel unsafe or degraded in their workplace, and yet, that is exactly what‚Äôs happening here. In conclusion, Allgentech might offer you a job, but it won‚Äôt offer you respect, safety, or growth. For your career‚Äôs sake‚Äîand mental well-being‚Äîplease think twice before joining.

full_review: 1. Abusive Leadership: MD verbally abuses and sometimes physically assaults employees. 2. Favoritism: DMD and CEO reward flattery over skills; HR supports this culture. 3. Unfair Salary Policies: 9-hour work rule; even 1-minute lateness leads to salary cuts. 4. Poor Dining Facilities: Low-quality food causing health issues. 5. Unsafe for Women: Reports of inappropriate behavior from top management. 6. Disrespectful Communication: Management uses abusive language. 8. No Value for Talent: Skills are ignored, and flatterers are promoted.

Review for All Generations Tech: My experience working at All Generations Tech has been deeply disappointing and professionally damaging. The environment is severely mismanaged, starting with the complete lack of leadership from the team lead. There is no vision, no structure, and no real support for engineers to grow or succeed. Guidance is non-existent ‚Äî you're expected to figure out complex tasks entirely on your own, often with zero context or documentation, and then blamed when things go wrong. The lack of job security is another major concern. Roles and responsibilities are constantly shifting without notice, and firings happen abruptly with little to no justification. Benefits are minimal to none, and the company makes no effort to create a sustainable or motivating work culture. But most concerning of all ‚Äî and something that needs to be publicly addressed ‚Äî is the inappropriate and borderline predatory behavior exhibited by the Principal SQA Engineer. Repeated instances of uncomfortable comments, unsolicited personal inquiries, and unprofessional conduct have been tolerated and brushed under the rug. Reporting such issues is a dead end due to the lack of a proper HR structure and the culture of silence within leadership. If you value your career, mental health, and professional dignity, I strongly advise against joining this company. The red flags here are not just warning signs ‚Äî they‚Äôre sirens.

COO: Comes across more like a clown than an operations leader. CEO & MD: They are the root cause of the toxic culture. Unprofessional HR: Some HR personnel, especially the female staff, lack basic professionalism and interpersonal skills. Unfair Work Distribution: You'll often do the same work as senior team members but with less pay and zero recognition. Some seniors behave like they are your boss without offering help or guidance.

As a colleague who has worked closely with M******, I feel compelled to speak up after seeing the recent false and damaging claims being spread about him. These allegations are completely untrue and clearly stem from personal frustration by individuals who were let go due to serious breaches of company policy‚Äîincluding stealing source code, unprofessional conduct, and lack of necessary skills. I won‚Äôt mention their names here, but if anyone wants to know, I can share. In contrast, M****** has always been a committed, talented, and highly respected leader in our Engineering Department. Without his guidance and effort, the company would not have been able to grow into such a well-organized and large team. He is one of the most skilled individuals in this company. From problem-solving to management decisions, everything he contributes is thoughtful and impactful. I don‚Äôt understand why some people are jealous of him‚Äîperhaps because he advanced his career quickly by consistently proving himself to the Japanese management. He has received multiple awards, represented the company internationally (including visits to Japan), and consistently delivers high-quality work. His efforts have been publicly recognized by our CEO Nakamura-san, as well as the Managing Director, Chairman, and other senior leaders, which speaks volumes about his integrity and contributions. I understand how easily misinformation can spread online, but as someone who has witnessed his work ethic and character firsthand, I can confidently say these accusations are baseless. Our company takes workplace conduct very seriously, and if there were ever any real concerns, they would be addressed through proper internal channels‚Äînot through anonymous and defamatory posts. Let‚Äôs not allow the actions of a few disgruntled individuals to overshadow the hard work and dedication of someone who truly adds value to our organization.

post_title: DS! is a good place to work
full_review: DS! is a classic software company in Bangladesh with a flexible work environment. You can grow fast if you push yourself, or work comfortably at your own pace. The company has great learning resources and expert engineers, and knowledge sharing is a big part of the culture. The top three leaders are highly skilled software engineers, making the whole environment very developer-friendly. Recently, DS! introduced an engineering manager layer, so the management side is growing and improving. While there were some management gaps before, they‚Äôre being addressed now. Other facilities are being added, though snacks, lunch are a bit expensive. Salaries are always on time. Like any company, DS! has had ups and downs, but the last five years showed strong growth, and now it‚Äôs in a stable phase‚Äîsoon expected to grow again, InshaAllah. It‚Äôs a fresher-friendly approach and gives newcomers flexibility early on. Overall, DS! is a good place to work in the Bangladeshi tech scene

Salaries are significantly below industry standards. Extremely long working hours (often 14‚Äì15 hours/day), with minimal respect for personal time. Employees are expected to work during major life events (e.g., weddings, emergencies), including holidays like Eid. There is no true work-life balance; employees must wait for higher-ups to leave even after completing daily hours. Internal politics dominate decisions, limiting merit-based growth. Technical skills are undervalued‚Äîmanagement often claims that only 20% of growth is based on skills, and 80% on "communication" (a proxy for favoritism). Favoritism and gender bias are common in promotions and rewards. Employees focusing on technical excellence are often overlooked in favor of those who engage in personal networking. Contributions by employees are frequently unrecognized, with higher-ups taking credit. Mistakes due to vague instructions are blamed on juniors. Employees are at times told to log work under someone else's account, hiding their contributions. Opportunities for growth, skill development, or exposure to new technologies are severely limited. Conversations and communications are heavily monitored. Cross-team collaboration is discouraged. Trust and autonomy are lacking, creating a suffocating work atmosphere. Employees are pressured to attend expensive company trips at their own expense. Non-participation is unofficially frowned upon and seen as career-damaging. Tasks are often beyond job descriptions and pay grades, with no compensation or recognition. Work-from-home flexibility is advertised but reserved for management. Overtime and weekend work are common and unpaid, despite earlier promises of compensatory leave. HR plays a disproportionately large role in technical decisions and employee management. Initiatives to learn or grow are suppressed. Developers are often stuck with repetitive tasks with no exposure to modern tools or frameworks. The environment is not developer-friendly; developers are undervalued compared to non-technical staff. The quality of product delivery is not a major concern. The workload resembles a garments factory's more than a professional tech company. Management practices are inefficient, chaotic, and demotivating. Hard work goes unappreciated.

full_review: Working at XpeedStudio has been a great journey for me. The environment is friendly and supportive, and I‚Äôve always felt like a valued part of the team. Whether it was during exams or when I was sick, the leadership‚Äîespecially our CEO, CTO, and HR‚Äîgave me the flexibility and care I needed. They genuinely treat us like family, not just employees. I‚Äôve had many opportunities to grow and develop my skills, and I‚Äôm truly grateful for that.

The current management at Therap has been treating employees unfairly. Despite Buddha Purnima falling on Sunday, 11th May ‚Äî a recognized public holiday ‚Äî the office will remain open without any form of compensation. A similar situation occurred during the recent Eid holidays. Although the government declared April 3rd as an Eid holiday and our director initially stated in the company workspace that we would observe it, the plan was later changed. Instead, we were informally told to work from home, likely to avoid leaving a digital record. When the CEO and COO visited Bangladesh, work hours were extended by an hour, and some employees were even required to come in on Fridays and Saturdays, again without any compensation for the extra hours. Lately, there have also been delays in salary disbursement.

post_title: Needs Serious Organizational Reform ‚Äì Not Recommended for Developers
full_review: The company lacks stability for tech professionals. During any investment challenges, the development team often faces abrupt downsizing, which severely impacts morale and continuity. Instead of offering increments or permanent roles to existing developers, the company tends to replace long-term employees with new hires ‚Äî a pattern observed specifically in the development department. Some senior individuals from departments such as Marketing, Product, and HR exhibit behavior as if they own the organization. Their involvement in favoritism, manipulation, and internal politics contributes significantly to a toxic work environment. Leadership in the backend team has been a major concern. A particular senior developer previously dismissed from Shuttle, Hishabee, and Codemoly has negatively impacted the team‚Äôs productivity and culture before eventually being let go. Basic workplace facilities such as lunch, snacks, prayer space, or any form of recreation are unavailable, which is disappointing in a professional environment. While the development team often delivers under tight deadlines and contributes to successful releases, recognition is disproportionately given to Sales and Customer Support. Developers remain largely unacknowledged for their hard work. Additional concerns include unrealistic deadlines, inconsistent salary increments, and the formation of team leader cliques that stifle growth and fairness.

post_title: Something is Wrong - Nobody Knows What or Pretends They Don't Know
full_review: Being a Marketer in a Dev-Centric Company Hurts You market a buggy product, bring in sales, then get blamed when refunds come in. Low retention? Your fault. Poor conversion? Also you. Outdated UI, broken features, unhappy users ‚Äî all somehow on marketing. But here‚Äôs the truth: the devs aren‚Äôt to blame either. They‚Äôre overworked and understaffed. It‚Äôs not laziness, it‚Äôs overload. They‚Äôre trying to keep up, just like you are. Meanwhile, the product suffers. User feedback gets ignored. And the blame game never stops. Being a marketer here feels like pulling a broken cart uphill. If we stop pointing fingers and start building together, we can fix this. Still hopeful. Still here.

post_title: Overall, my experience at weDevs has been very positive.
full_review: Friendly Work Environment : The work culture at weDevs is incredibly supportive and feels like a family. Everyone is welcoming and always ready to help. Career Growth Opportunities : I‚Äôve had great opportunities to learn and grow professionally here. There‚Äôs always something new to pick up, and the company supports that. Great Benefits : The perks are amazing‚Äîfree food, unlimited snacks, lunch allowances, and timely bonuses. These are some of the highlights. Supportive Management : Management is approachable and encourages collaboration. I‚Äôve found them to be very helpful in navigating challenges. Work-Life Balance : Flexible hours and a reasonable workload make it easier to maintain a healthy balance between work and personal life. High Job Satisfaction : I‚Äôm not alone in this‚Äîmost people here are satisfied with their work and the environment. Modern Workplace : The office is comfortable, with amenities like a gaming room, which makes the environment even more engaging and enjoyable. Slow Administrative Processes : One of the challenges I‚Äôve noticed is the delays in HR or administrative tasks. It can be frustrating at times. Mid-Management Issues : There are some inefficiencies with mid-level management. Sometimes things can feel unclear, and that causes delays or confusion. Limited Ownership for Juniors : As a junior, I sometimes feel like I‚Äôm limited in taking on bigger responsibilities. There‚Äôs a bit of a glass ceiling when it comes to leadership roles.

post_title: Finally Found a Team That Cares
full_review: Working at Friends Corp has been a refreshing and rewarding experience for me in a senior position. From day one, I‚Äôve felt genuinely valued not just for my skills but also as a person. This is something I truly missed in one of my previous companies. The team culture is warm and supportive, and there‚Äôs always someone ready to help or simply listen when needed. It‚Äôs not just about finishing tasks, it‚Äôs about growing together. One thing I really appreciate is the freedom to share ideas and try out new approaches. Mistakes are treated as part of the learning journey, not something to fear. That kind of mindset builds confidence and encourages creativity. Working with people from Japan and other parts of the world has also been a great experience. It has helped me learn a lot and grow both professionally and personally. In short, Friends Corp doesn‚Äôt just feel like a workplace. It feels like a place where I‚Äôm motivated to do my best every day while being part of a respectful and inspiring team.

The company severely lacks a professional work culture. The management is often preoccupied with issues from their other ventures, leaving little to no attention for employee development or organizational improvement. Employees are frequently overworked and undervalued, with treatment that can feel exploitative. One of the most concerning practices is that, upon resignation, the company withholds essential documents like experience certificates and No Objection Certificates (NOCs), which can seriously affect future employment opportunities. There is no structured environment for learning, career growth, or mentorship. The organizational structure is extremely weak, with no clear processes or support systems in place. Despite these serious issues, the company appears to be fabricating positive reviews to mislead potential hires, especially fresh graduates. I strongly advise job seekers, particularly those starting their careers, to exercise caution before considering this company.
Good 1. Good Management 2. Excellent working Environment 3. Good learning opportunity 4. Flexible Bad 1. Salary is not up to the mark but ok

post_title: Could Have been the the Best in BD, Ended up being Average because of poor Decisions
full_review: Strong Focus on Kubernetes and Cloud-Native Technologies Appscode operates deeply within the Kubernetes and cloud-native ecosystem, providing engineers the opportunity to work with cutting-edge and highly sought-after technologies. For developers passionate about infrastructure, automation, and distributed systems, this is a major advantage. Open Core Projects with Community Impact The company maintains open core projects that are tightly integrated with the Kubernetes ecosystem. This allows engineers to contribute to widely adopted tools, build a strong public portfolio, and gain recognition within the open-source community. Dedicated Time for Research and Development (R&D) Engineers are encouraged to spend time on R&D, often engaging with complex technical challenges such as scalability, distributed systems, and automation. This fosters deep technical growth and intellectual stimulation. Accelerated Learning and Growth Opportunities Due to the nature of the work and the technology stack, team members gain significant hands-on experience and exposure in a relatively short period. There's good number of stable and prominent clients like Nokia, Microsoft, GreenHouse etc. Collaborative, Developer-Friendly Environment The office culture, largely shaped and maintained by the employees themselves, is supportive and collaborative. The company has a strong engineering-focused culture, with many team members coming from competitive programming backgrounds. This shared technical mindset fosters mutual understanding and helps new hires adapt quickly. Competitive Local Compensation Salaries are well-aligned with the local market, and payments are reliably made on time. Risk of Burnout The high-paced nature of the work and the constant learning curve can lead to burnout if not properly managed by both individuals and leadership. Limited Project Rotation Engineers often remain on the same project for extended periods. While this can deepen expertise, it can also lead to stagnation or frustration, especially when moving on to a very similar project afterward. Understaffed Office Management The HR and administrative departments are relatively small and under-resourced, which can lead to miscommunication or poorly handled internal matters. Limited Recreation and Wellness Facilities There are currently insufficient provisions for physical activities, team-building events, or relaxation spaces. As the company scales, this gap is becoming more apparent and increasingly necessary to address. Inconsistent Performance Review Process Underperformance is not always addressed in a timely or constructive manner. Some employees receive inadequate feedback or support, which can lead to abrupt terminations or demoralization. Top-Down Leadership Approach Leadership often prioritizes their own strategic vision over team feedback. This can create a disconnect between management and employees and reduce the sense of inclusivity and ownership within the team. Lack of Mutual Commitment in Employment New hires are frequently expected to commit for the long term, but the organization does not always reciprocate this commitment. The dismissal of experienced team members has contributed to a higher-than-average turnover rate and organizational instability. Demotivating Work Culture Inconsistent managerial support and the absence of a strong, cohesive office culture can lead to disengagement and reduced morale across the team. Short Career Progression Trajectory There is limited visibility into long-term career paths within the company. Most engineers tend to leave within 2‚Äì3 years, often due to a lack of professional growth opportunities. Actively collect and review employee feedback‚Äîboth current and former‚Äîto identify areas for organizational improvement. Reassess company policies around work-life balance, employee well-being, leave structure, and office environment to better align with company growth and employee needs. Invest in clear career development frameworks and employee retention strategies to support long-term growth and reduce attrition. Foster a more inclusive and transparent leadership culture where feedback from all levels is considered and valued.

It‚Äôs not competitors damaging your reputation ‚Äì it‚Äôs your own biased practices, favoritism, and internal power struggles. You‚Äôve created a culture that values loyalty over merit, encouraging cliques, free mixing, unprofessional behavior, and ignoring genuine concerns. Instead of building a professional work environment, the focus has shifted to normalizing behaviors like drinking, drugs, promoting free mixing, party-like culture, and surrounding yourself with people who support your decisions, right or wrong, rather than those who are genuinely skilled. ‚ùå The CEO often uses his connection with Mr *sif Sal*h (ED of BRAC and Chairman of 8RAC IT) to avoid accountability, mentioning this link to suppress dissent. ‚ûïH*mel, despite having limited leadership skills, was being hired to a senior role at *RAC IT, largely due to his loyalty to the CEO and personal connections. His past behavior, including reported arrogance and unprofessional conduct, has created a toxic work environment where even female colleagues hesitate to speak up, fearing job insecurity. post_title: Leaders who made the company a living HELL
full_review: Port0n1cs was once regarded as a benchmark for company culture and developer experience in Bangladesh. It attracted top talent and fostered an environment where innovation and collaboration thrived. Unfortunately, that chapter seems to have come to a close. In recent times, the departure of visionary leaders has left the company in the hands of individuals who appear to lack both the technical depth and emotional intelligence necessary to lead. The current leadership seems more concerned with control than with growth‚Äîboth their own and their team‚Äôs. Rather than empowering developers, they push a culture of overwork, where 12‚Äì18 hour days for months on end are considered the norm. Refusing to comply with these unrealistic demands can quickly lead to one being labeled a ‚Äúlow performer.‚Äù Perhaps most concerning is the toxic internal politics. Developers are subtly (and at times directly) encouraged to undermine their seniors‚Äînot based on merit or professionalism, but because those seniors pose a perceived threat to insecure leadership. Only exception is the QA Lead , who is the OG member of Portonics and still carries the old essence of the company While the base salary structure remains competitive and annual increments are decent, the bonus system is poorly thought out and fails to reflect the contributions or sacrifices of the team. Developers who value integrity, a healthy work-life balance, and a culture of mutual respect may want to think twice before committing to Portonics in its current state. Talented individuals have already begun to move on‚Äîand unless significant changes are made, that trend is likely to continue. I was able to leave the company before it became unbearable. Can't say the same for my colleagues, who are still suffering . If you are Planing to join here, don't, trust me . If you are appearing for the interview, if your skill set is better than the leader, you will be rejected. If your skill is moderate and you are submissive, you will be surely selected

post_title: Egotistic and spineless: a combination for imminent disaster
full_review: Port0n1cs had a good reputation in the industry as having a good work culture and a tenacity to promote quality. These are the reason why I joined the company initially. This perception, when met with reality, was shattered as the company has fallen too far from grace. I didn't see any of the perceived qualities in my stay there. What I saw though was promotion of clueless individuals to leadership, long term employees being shunned and discarded like baby diapers (takes all the poop but not valued after use) and worst of all a tech leadership so spineless that the only commitment they care about is to please their egotistical leader. The only thing they can defend is their undying will to please the higher up, even if it means to disregard the suggestion of the team for completely irrational reasons. All of this is a result of an organizational leadership which is split between two individuals whose methods cannot be any different than each other. One is a methodical and strategic leader with a penchant for overseeing every aspect to the finish line, while the other is an individual who cannot do no wrong. Any and everything that he does is deemed as the best and the employees are just hindering his brilliance. Useless "team building" session of self gloating is deemed as "motivational" for the team from his eyes, while the rest of the team feels it as a waste of time. Overall majority of the departments are led by individuals who cannot be further from being qualified. The only criteria of being qualified is being favored by the man in charge. Honestly, the company can be so much better if they just figure out their issues instead of staying in denial and claiming supremacy and also make sure that qualified individuals are leading the departments instead of suck ups and loyalists. We all know how that helped BAL on the long run. Do not recommend this company, even to my enemies. And for those looking for a good work culture, look somewhere else or check if they have actually done something to make things better, instead of claiming it.

post_title: A company full of corrupted departments
full_review: I joined this company over 2 years ago. Here's my experience. Pros: 1. Timely salary. 2. You can learn skills for your own personal growth. That‚Äôs it. Now let‚Äôs talk about the cons‚Äîwhich honestly feel endless. 1. Managers: Completely unqualified and unprofessional. They don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing. Every developer knows how outdated their mindset is. Most of them can‚Äôt even keep up with basic trends in tech. Calling them managers is an insult to the word. 2. The management: Another clown show. No professionalism, no skill, just mood swings and yelling over petty issues. One of them randomly loses his temper like a toddler denied candy. To be fair, the CTO is a decent human being personally‚Äîbut as a CTO? Clueless. 3. THE SQA DEPARTMENT (yes, this deserves all caps): The most corrupted department in this entire company. A whole floor dedicated to this circus. Most of them joined with their face‚Äînot their brain or skills. Some don‚Äôt even know what automation is, let alone how to do it. I‚Äôve seen people‚Äîespecially the cuties‚Äîgetting in and climbing up just by being cute. SQA head‚Äôs hiring policy? ‚ÄúNo skills required, just be pretty.‚Äù And yes, I‚Äôve seen the SQA head and his favorites going office together in rickshaw like some 90s love story. This entire floor is a joke. Over 50 SQAs and barely a handful actually know what software is. 4. IT Department: These guys think they‚Äôre hot stuff. Reality? They‚Äôd be better off fixing routers in alleys or working in a local computer shop. Arrogant, disrespectful, and skill-less. If being rude was a skill, they‚Äôd be CTO by now. 5. HR Department: Let‚Äôs not even start. They‚Äôll ask you to submit the same document 5-6 times and still ‚Äúlose‚Äù it. Zero professionalism, no proper process, delay everything‚Äîespecially increments. Recruitment? Random. Accountant acts like he‚Äôs working at the Prime Minister‚Äôs Office. Pure garbage behavior. 6. DevOps: DevOps? More like ‚ÄúLaptop Dada.‚Äù They‚Äôre stuck in the 90s and scared of anything new. Every new tech = ‚Äúsecurity issue,‚Äù ‚Äúhigh bill,‚Äù ‚Äúnot needed.‚Äù Bro, if you guys are DevOps, then I can be the AWS CEO. I doubt the CDO even studied in this field‚Äîdoubt he even knows any new tech. There is a software architect I know in this company he actually knows nothing. His teammates researches and he tells management like he researched everything. But in reality he knows nothing just chapabaj. Skilled people = neglected. If you‚Äôre actually good, forget about recognition. You‚Äôll get 10k yearly increment and a pat on the back if you‚Äôre lucky. But if you‚Äôre good at shoe licking‚Äîcongrats, sky‚Äôs the limit. No skills? No problem. Just be a loud ‚Äúyes man‚Äù and you‚Äôll rise faster than inflation. I‚Äôve seen senior software engineers who don‚Äôt even deserve a trainee title. There are some genuinely talented devs here, and only because of them this company hasn‚Äôt completely collapsed yet.

We appreciate all feedback,positive or critical. As it helps us identify areas of improvement. However, when feedback turns into personal attacks, baseless allegations, and generalizations that are far removed from reality, we feel the need to respond clearly, factually, and respectfully to uphold the integrity of our teams and the company as a whole.
Let us address the claims raised:
Management & Leadership:¬†Our managers are selected through a rigorous evaluation process that includes not only technical proficiency but also leadership potential, experience, and the ability to guide diverse teams. Claiming that every manager is ‚Äúunqualified‚Äù or ‚Äúclueless‚Äù is not only factually incorrect but also deeply disrespectful to professionals who consistently work hard to ensure timely delivery, client satisfaction, and employee support.
We agree that not all leadership styles fit everyone, but we also encourage open-door communication. If someone had genuine concerns, they were always welcome to escalate them through proper channels.
SQA Department:¬†We strongly object to the personal and sexist remarks directed at our SQA professionals. Hiring based on appearance is a serious and unfounded accusation. Our SQA team includes ISTQB-certified engineers, automation testers, and experienced professionals who have delivered on enterprise-grade projects.
Disrespectful and discriminatory language towards a specific department‚Äîespecially targeted at individuals based on gender or appearance‚Äîis not criticism. It‚Äôs harassment. And we do not tolerate or entertain such behavior in our culture.
IT & DevOps:¬†Our IT and DevOps teams maintain the backbone of company operations. They work across challenging scenarios‚Äîfrom security compliance to cloud cost optimization and infrastructure scaling. Their cautious approach is a result of experience, not incompetence. Every tool or technology introduced is evaluated based on security, cost, and long-term viability.
We promote innovation‚Äîbut not at the cost of stability. This balance is intentional and necessary.
HR & Recruitment:¬†Our HR processes are ISO-audited and follow proper documentation protocols. If documents were re-requested, it was likely due to improper submission or verification compliance.
Recruitment is based on structured interviews, technical assessments, and behavior-based evaluation‚Äînot favoritism or randomness. Personal attacks on our HR, finance, or admin staff reflect more on the individual making such claims than on the departments themselves.
Recognition & Compensation:¬†We believe in fair and performance-based growth. Every increment and promotion goes through a review process. Recognition is not limited to vocal or ‚Äúvisible‚Äù employees‚Äîmany behind-the-scenes contributors are regularly rewarded.
However, expecting rapid promotions without aligning with organizational standards, behavior, or collaborative culture is unrealistic. We value team players, not lone rangers who disregard structure or process.
To Conclude,¬†We understand that not every workplace is the right fit for every person. If you‚Äôve moved on‚Äîwe sincerely wish you all the best. But if someone chooses to burn bridges through public defamation, slander, and disrespectful language, it reveals more about their professionalism than ours.
We remain committed to creating a respectful, merit-based, and inclusive environment for all‚Äîregardless of department, designation, or background.
For anyone currently struggling or having unresolved concerns, we encourage you to approach our HR team directly. Constructive voices are always welcome. Anonymous hostility is not.

post_title: From Potential to Pause: A Reflection
full_review: Not every company gets the chance to shape an industry. This one did. It had the right people, the right momentum, and a product that mattered. For a while, it felt like the sky was the limit. You could see the alignment between purpose and performance. It was exciting to be part of something that was clearly on the rise. But somewhere along the way, the clarity faded. Strategic decisions began to feel disconnected from reality. Senior roles were created without clear purpose, salaries ballooned in strange places, and the culture of merit quietly eroded. It became harder to see the logic behind who was being empowered and why. Today, growth has slowed, and morale seems to be chasing memories of better days. Upper management appears to be in search of answers, while the root causes- often sitting in plain sight - remain unaddressed. There's a hesitance to confront the real issues, especially around a mid management that no longer adds meaningful value. To be fair, the company still provides well. Benefits, flexibility, and a baseline of respect remain. And that‚Äôs not nothing. There‚Äôs a legacy here that many still hold affection for.

full_review: It's surprising‚Äîand honestly disappointing‚Äîto see misleading and exaggerated statements about our open environment culture at Vivasoft. As someone who loves coming to work every day, I can confidently say this company feels like home to many of us. Contrary to what was depicted, our teams‚Äîfrom management to interns‚Äîare filled with passionate individuals who enthusiastically collaborate, share ideas freely, and support each other professionally and personally. We prioritize openness, respect, and innovation. There's a reason we have one of the most motivated and happy teams in the industry. Our workspace promotes openness and collaboration, encouraging everyone to engage proactively. Instead of focusing on superficial judgments, we've built an inclusive environment that brings out the best in everyone. Anyone who's genuinely experienced our culture knows how supportive and uplifting our colleagues and leadership truly are. Additionally, if someone is genuinely unhappy, it's puzzling why they would choose to stay for 5-6 years. Nobody is forced or bound by a contract to remain here against their will. Our doors have always been open for those who align with our values and seek fulfillment. Let's celebrate what makes Vivasoft special: our unique blend of enthusiasm, innovation, and genuine camaraderie. It's the authentic joy of working here that keeps us moving forward‚Äîand anyone here would readily confirm this. #VivasoftCulture #TeamSpirit #LoveWhereYourWork #IfYouDontThenByeBye

post_title: Cod3m3n Solutions: A Cautionary Tale for Interns and Developers
full_review: A Harsh Reality of Cod3m3n Solutions ‚Äì More Like "Cod3m3n Intern Solutions" I want to highlight some of the major issues I‚Äôve witnessed at Cod3m3n Solutions: 1. Exploitation of Interns: The management at Cod3m3n Solutions often hires interns and places them under immense pressure to meet tight client deadlines. In many cases, entire projects are handed over to interns with little to no senior oversight. After 3-4 months of overwork, these interns are dismissed without any real consideration or offer of permanent employment. It‚Äôs no surprise that many people now refer to the company as Cod3m3n Intern Solutions 2. Unethical Work Culture: Interns are led to believe that good performance might lead to permanent roles. However, under the leadership of G*la* M*rsh*d, this turns out to be a false hope. Interns are routinely forced to work 12-15 hours per day, often handling the responsibilities of full-time developers. Despite this, they are paid only 6000 BDT, with no overtime compensation or weekend pay. 3. Lack of Accountability Among Senior Staff: Senior developers, particularly Frontend Lead D*ep*ta S*ha, frequently avoid their responsibilities. Common excuses like "no electricity" are used to skip workdays, while in reality, they go shopping or take naps during working hours. This behavior leaves junior developers and interns to carry the workload. When deliverables are delayed, CEO Ra*i *oula blames the remaining developers instead of addressing the root of the problem. 4. Toxic Team Dynamics: Developers like D*epit* Sah* P*ja, involved in component development, often waste significant time without producing results. Their inefficiency causes delays that impact the whole team. Yet, they escape accountability while others are pressured to clean up the mess. Final Thoughts: Cod3m3n Solutions needs to seriously rethink its values and treatment of interns and junior developers. If you're considering joining this company, especially as an intern, be very cautious. Don‚Äôt be fooled by empty promises. The management‚Äôs lack of ethics and the senior staff‚Äôs irresponsibility create an extremely unfair and demotivating work environment.

Of course, no workplace is without it‚Äôs challenges. The workload can get quite intense at time, we often joke that it feels like being inside a pressure cooker! But what make the difference in our CEO. Whenever he sense the pressure is getting too high, he steps out of his room and joins us in the workspace with jokes, casual chats and lighthearted moments that instantly lift the mood. It's these small but meaningful gestures that make AppDevs feel less like a company and more like a family.

post_title: Unprofessional Workplace with Poor Management and No Work-Life Balance
full_review: Poor Work-Life Balance: The company has an extremely poor work-life balance. There are no public holidays, not even on significant national days like December 16th, which is ridiculous. False Benefits & Mismanagement: Foods: They claim to provide fully subsidized coffee and tea, but it‚Äôs a scam‚Äîthe coffee is terrible, and the management is disorganized. They also mention Friday lunch, but the food quality is extremely poor, likely sourced at a very cheap rate. Lack of Personal Growth: There is no opportunity for personal or professional growth since the company doesn‚Äôt have any good projects. Job Insecurity: There is no notice period‚Äîthey can fire employees at any time, even telling them today that they don‚Äôt need to come in tomorrow. Unprofessional HR Policies: The HR policies lack professionalism and structure. Disrespectful Work Environment: Employees often use informal and impolite language (such as "Tui"), creating an unprofessional and disrespectful workplace. Poor Management & Decision-Making: The management is highly disorganized. For example, the CEO may request the implementation of Feature "A," but after completing half of it, the CTO may say that it is irrelevant to the project. This lack of proper planning leads to wasted time and effort. Advice to Management: Improve Work-Life Balance: Provide proper public holidays and ensure employees have a healthy work-life balance. Deliver Promised Benefits: If you advertise perks like free coffee, tea, and lunch, ensure they are of decent quality and not misleading. Enhance Job Security: Implement a proper notice period policy to give employees stability and confidence in their roles. Encourage Professionalism: Foster a respectful workplace by enforcing polite communication among employees and promoting a professional company culture. Revamp HR Policies: Establish structured and fair HR policies to improve employee satisfaction and retention. Ensure¬†Better Project Planning: Improve decision-making by aligning leadership teams. Avoid unnecessary changes that waste employees‚Äô time and effort. Invest in Employee Growth: Provide opportunities for learning, skill development, and meaningful projects to support career progression.

Pros: Great place to learn automation as an intern ‚Äî ideal for gaining experience within the first 6 months. Opportunity to work on real projects and gain hands-on experience . Cons: Frequent buffer time cuts due to unscheduled prayer breaks. High-pressure, stressful environment with unrealistic expectations. Interns and staff are kept in temporary roles for over 2 years without progression. Constant pressure to stay active in workflows just to increase log counts , even when there is no meaningful work. Build a real team with defined roles and responsibilities. Be transparent with salaries , and stop making promises you don‚Äôt intend to keep. Respect your employees‚Äô time and effort , and stop fostering a fear-based work culture . Establish a proper HR and management system to ensure growth, fairness, and professional development.

I would like to start with a well-presented story about my interview experience at W3. Between February and March, I applied for the position of Software Engineer (Backend). One day, a gentleman called me for a pre-screening interview. Although I had applied for the Backend position, he asked me if I knew JavaScript, React, HTML, and CSS. It was at that moment I realized that perhaps his background wasn't technical, or he didn‚Äôt have a clear understanding of software development. Later, I was invited to take an assessment. While it was supposed to be done online, I was asked to complete it in the office within two hours. The assessment had nothing to do with the job description they had provided. Next, I was selected for the interview. There were three people on the technical panel. One of them, who had a rather harsh attitude, was asking questions in a way that felt more like a university viva, with no courtesy whatsoever. Another person who was conducting the interview had a very unclear way of speaking‚Äîhe would just say "Answer the question" without explaining much. The third person kept asking the same question 4-5 times, and at one point, even asked about topics unrelated to the job description. After the interview, the HR told me they would let me know about their decision, but didn‚Äôt clarify if it would be positive or negative. When I later called the HR, the same person told me, ‚ÄúYou will be informed,‚Äù and asked me to wait. After 11 days of waiting, feeling frustrated, I withdrew my application. Sixteen days later, I received a call saying I wasn‚Äôt selected because the vacancy had been filled. They mentioned they would post job openings again in about a week. I couldn‚Äôt help but wonder how many openings they had each month. Had the HR been upfront from the beginning and informed me that only positive outcomes would be communicated, I wouldn‚Äôt have waited this long. This experience was highly disappointing and sends a negative message about their interview process and company culture.

These issues overshadowed any potential learning opportunities. Advice to Management : Treat employees with fairness and integrity. Transparent and ethical business practices are fundamental to building a sustainable and respected company.

Interview Experience Review ‚Äì Rob! Axiata (Infrastructure Role) I recently interviewed for a technical infrastructure position at Robi Axiata, and I‚Äôd like to share my experience for the benefit of other professionals in similar fields. The role was advertised as a technical position requiring substantial experience and multiple vendor certifications ‚Äî which set the expectation for a process focused on system architecture, infrastructure management, or vendor-specific technologies (e.g., Cisco, VMware, Red Hat, etc.). However, the actual interview process diverged significantly from this expectation. Format: Mode : Entirely online. The test was heavily focused on analytical reasoning and business-related scenarios. The content resembled something more aligned with a Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) curriculum ‚Äî covering topics like market strategy, cost analysis, and general business logic. Unfortunately, not a single question was technical or related to infrastructure, systems engineering, or enterprise IT operations. This was quite surprising, considering the role was pitched as one requiring technical experience and industry certifications. So I did not proceed past the assessment stage, likely because my background is more technical than business-focused. It was disappointing, as I was prepared to demonstrate my technical proficiency, but there was no opportunity to do so. Advice to Future Candidates : Unless the job description is revised, be prepared for a business-heavy initial screening ‚Äî even for technical roles. I dont know how that makes sense

post_title: Think Twice Before Joining This Company
full_review: This organization once had the potential to be one of the leading software companies in Bangladesh. In its early days, when it was smaller, the work environment was relatively healthy. However, with a headcount now exceeding 450, the situation has deteriorated significantly. Key Issues to Consider: Lack of Professional Growth: There are no structured annual reviews or clear career development plans for most employees. Promotions are rare, and feedback is often vague or non-existent. Toxic Leadership: The current Bangladesh country lead has repeatedly failed to deliver on promises. He lacks vision and technical expertise, often relying on buzzwords rather than real substance. Unqualified Senior Staff: Certain high-paid employees have been in the company for years without making any meaningful contributions. Their presence speaks more to internal politics than performance. Corrupt and Inefficient Management: Junior employees often suffer from micromanagement, lack of proper onboarding, and inconsistent workloads. Some teams experience unreasonable pressure, affecting work-life balance. QA and Product Quality Issues: Despite having a large QA team, product quality has noticeably declined. Basic functionalities are not properly tested, making system stability a recurring issue. Non-Technical Teams Mismanagement: Team leads in departments like Global, Marketing, Design, and Support lack professionalism. Misuse of office funds for personal or low-impact activities is a serious concern. Accountability and Financial Transparency: Unjustified salary deductions under the guise of taxes, without proper breakdowns, are common. Complaints go unheard or are dismissed without proper investigation. Poor Facilities and Benefits: The quality and availability of office-provided food are consistently subpar. Despite the company promoting a vibrant office culture, reality falls far short. Resource Misallocation: While cost-cutting is affecting employee benefits and raises, the company continues to invest in new buildings and unrelated business ventures. This raises serious questions about priorities. The work culture is marred by favoritism, lack of transparency, and minimal regard for employee welfare. If you're considering joining, do your due diligence and speak to former or current employees before making a decision.

post_title: My Experience at a Job Test for an Assistant Software Engineer Position
full_review: I recently took a written exam for Mi11enn!um Information Solution Ltd.'s Assistant Software Engineer employment. Since programming is the focus of the work, I naturally assumed that the test would have questions about it. I was shocked to see that there was not a single programming question on the test. Rather, it was jam-packed with multiple-choice questions that only addressed English grammar and mathematics. It was odd and frustrating that there was no evaluation of actual programming skills, even though I recognize the importance of logical reasoning and communication abilities. Should the position entail coding and software development, the assessment procedure must to take that into account. Candidates are not given the opportunity to showcase their technical skills or establish their suitability for the role in a test that contains no programming substance. I was a little disheartened by this encounter. In my opinion, employers ought to better match the duties of the position with the hiring evaluations.

post_title: Where Work Feels Like Family, and Every Moment Matters.
full_review: The work environment here is both supportive and friendly. One of the standout perks is the flexibility, especially during Ramadan and Eid-ul-Adha, when we get to work remotely for over a month. This allows us to spend more quality time with our families, which is deeply appreciated. Another unique benefit is the ‚ÄúWork From Tour‚Äù concept. We go on extended trips, sometimes for 7 to 10 days, and work just a few hours a day while traveling. It‚Äôs a rare blend of productivity and adventure. On top of that, every weekend ends with a sports session, fully sponsored by the company, which is a treat for anyone who loves to stay active and have fun with the team. Of course, no workplace is without its challenges. The workload can get quite intense at times, we often joke that it feels like being inside a pressure cooker! But what makes the difference is our CEO. Whenever he senses the pressure is getting too high, he steps out of his room and joins us in the workspace with jokes, casual chats, and lighthearted moments that instantly lift the mood. It‚Äôs these small but meaningful gestures that make AppDevs feel less like a company and more like a family.

post_title: A Supportive and Friendly Workplace That Prioritizes People
full_review: Working at Hubxpert for the past year as a mid-level UI/UX designer has been a truly positive experience. The overall vibe here is warm and welcoming‚Äîcolleagues are approachable, and collaboration feels effortless. The company fosters a balanced work culture that values both productivity and personal well-being, which creates a healthy and motivating atmosphere. One of the most memorable experiences was our winter retreat. I attended with my spouse, and she had an amazing time. She even remarked that it felt more like a fun university trip with friends and family than a typical office event. This reflects the genuine sense of community we have here. Leadership is both supportive and empathetic. I suffer from a back issue and needed a month of rest. Without hesitation, the CEO suggested I work from home to recover. Later, during a difficult period, I was planning an international trip to recharge. I was nervous to ask for leave, but the CEO not only approved it‚Äîhe encouraged me to extend it to enjoy the experience fully. He often reminds us that happy employees are essential to a successful company, and he truly lives by that principle. The work environment is comfortable and visually appealing. We also enjoy perks like unlimited coffee, which may seem small but is a real productivity booster. When I faced issues with high blood pressure, our HR lead brought in a monitoring machine just for me, and colleagues still regularly check in to see how I‚Äôm doing. That level of care is rare and means a lot. Outside work, we engage in activities like football after office hours, which helps us unwind and build stronger team bonds. I also learned to play table tennis here‚Äîsomething I really enjoyed, and although we had to leave it behind in the new office, I still miss it. Professionally, working with HubXpert‚Äôs diverse clients has sharpened my design skills and made me more efficient. It has also helped me build strong relationships with both the product and development teams.

post_title: W3llD3v: The Story of the TRINITY
full_review: Well! If you are an aspiring software engineer, it‚Äôs a good place to start off your career. However, you will not be properly valued even if you prove your capabilities well. The old ones will always get a lot bigger check than you! Now, comes the best part! If you are anything other than software engineer or not someone close to big trinity of the company, you will basically be slaves to the trinity and the software engineers! For the software engineers, I guess they are the ones who are bringing in money for the company! And the trinity!Well, THEY ARE THE TRINITY! Finally, the food is great! Kind of like an All you can eat buffet!

With a strong tech stack, good coding practices, and a welcoming environment for making an impact at scale, the company could have been one of the best small to mid-tier tech firms in Dhaka. But some outliers and caveats turn it into a claustrophobic hell for your mind. Tech Stack and Practices: Love it. It needs a bit of modernization. While traditional best practices are vital for foundational strength, adopting newer technologies wouldn't hurt. In fact, it might boost efficiency for both the product and the employees. HR & Admin: Supportive and professional. Their efforts are better than some other places I‚Äôve seen, though a bit more speed and organizational clarity would help. Management: At times, it feels like the office is run by a one-man army, not entirely in a bad way. You‚Äôll find ten solid reasons to align with the chief‚Äôs vision, but if there‚Äôs even one valid reason to disagree, it deserves to be heard and resolved. The commander-in-chief must show compassion and acknowledge that lives are asynchronous. without breathing space, it won‚Äôt be a sustainable place in the long run. Timing: Comparatively flexible, but there's a silent expectation that employees should stay until evening or beyond. The worst culture at IdeaScale is the invisible peer pressure to stay late or push serious work toward or past the end of the day to allign with some employee's schedule. A red flag. Perks: Okayish. No complaints. Now, let‚Äôs talk about red flags no one acknowledges: Support staff: which should‚Äôve been the least of anyone‚Äôs concerns, become more prominent than they should. Either train them properly or find better alternatives. Synchronization with foreign entities : As an employee, it‚Äôs a nightmare to predict what‚Äôs going on company-wide, how much you should care depending on your role, or what you need to do to stay afloat. And again, no one enjoys being stuck around the office with colleagues after 8 hours of work.

post_title: Unrealistic Expectations for Junior Designers: A Reflection
full_review: On the 30th of last month, I had an interview with a company named AlgoSoft. Before that, they gave me a task to complete. The day after I submitted the task, they suddenly called me at 12 PM and said the interview would be at 1 PM. I was just shocked‚Äîwhat kind of madness is this? Anyway, I attended the interview. They asked me if I was familiar with iOS design guidelines. I responded that I don‚Äôt know them fully but I do know some basics. Then they went on with some typical template-like questions such as: what is your design process, how do you solve problems, how do you handle file handover, and how do you manage when the same task gets repeated feedback again and again? Can you do this? Can you do that? Now regarding the work schedule‚Äî Their working hours are from 10 AM to 6 PM. Since I have my semester finals in May, I told them I would need around 3 hours off on exam days, but I would cover that time at night. Still, they asked how many hours I could work, especially on weekends. Basically, I‚Äôd need to work the entire week. In fact, working 24/7 would be even better for them! And the most ridiculous part is‚Äîthey expect all of this for just 10,000 BDT per month. They gave me a task, took my interview, yet didn't even bother to inform me whether I was selected or not. I just don't understand what exactly they expect for 10,000 taka. They don‚Äôt mention any of these excessive demands in the job post. They just give out tasks unnecessarily and waste people‚Äôs time with interviews. My question is: how much can you really expect from an entry-level junior designer? The design should be top-notch, problem-solving skills should be top-notch, and they want someone who‚Äôs mentally prepared to work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
