full_review: Nice workplace with a decent office environment. Good office lunch and snacks provided for employees. From day one, the company instills fear with constant threats of punishment, termination, or disciplinary action. Employees are monitored every minute, creating a suffocating, jail-like atmosphere. As a Japanese company, they view Bangladeshi engineers as low-cost labor, unable to afford Japanese engineers. Engineers are treated like garment workers, with little respect or regard for their humanity. The leave policy is highly intrusive and unfair. Sick leave requires prescriptions, or it‚Äôs counted as unpaid. Employees must publicly justify leaves in a WhatsApp group, and HR publicly shames those who don‚Äôt comply, forcing employees to prioritize work over personal emergencies. Office hours are strictly 8 AM to 5 PM, with a one-hour break for lunch and prayer. Any extra break time (even 5 minutes) must be compensated with overtime, with meticulous monitoring of every moment. The promised overtime pay is nearly impossible to obtain. Overtime is only recognized after working 2+ extra hours, rendering shorter overtime periods unpaid and unacknowledged. Salaries are delayed with no fixed payment date, sometimes arriving as late as the 6th or 10th of the month. Employees must submit monthly work reports to get paid, a rule not clearly communicated by HR. After 5 months of employment, I am experiencing mental trauma and pervasive negative energy due to the toxic work environment. The company‚Äôs teams in Japan and India, particularly the Indian team, dominate Bangladeshi engineers harshly, fostering a discriminatory and oppressive dynamic. Treat Bangladeshi engineers with respect as professionals, not as low-cost labor or slaves. Transform the workplace into a supportive environment, not a jail. Train HR to understand and respect the needs of engineering professionals.

post_title: Br0tec5 - From Promising Culture to Growing Challenges ‚Äì A Candid Employee Review
reviewer_role: Wellwisher Employee - Serving for a Long Time.
full_review: Br0tec5 once had a strong culture ‚Äî no politics, solid bonding, and some real talent. But recent internal changes are quietly eroding that foundation. The CTO needs to step in before more capable people leave and the company‚Äôs image suffers. Already, some ‚Äúfakibaji‚Äù local projects are about to onboard ‚Äî something unthinkable in the old Br0tec5. üîπ Overall Company Culture & Management Pros: Earlier, the culture was genuinely good CTO is a kind and well-meaning person Works with top-tier Fortune 500 clients Some teams still maintain healthy senior-junior dynamics Top management has an Islamic ethical mindset and has tried to uphold good values Cons: Office politics is growing across departments Management equates long office hours with productivity; remote work is often mistrusted Office space is extremely cramped ‚Äî feels more like a garments floor than an IT company, though some people think it‚Äôs ‚Äúexcellent‚Äù Salary structure is average, though a few delusional juniors believe it‚Äôs higher than Google‚Äôs üòÖ Career growth is limited and often not merit-based Internal team rivalries are quietly encouraged over real collaboration Wrong people are promoted to leadership, killing motivation among skilled employees The growing mindset seems to be: ‚ÄúThe company is running, so it‚Äôll keep running ‚Äî quality doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äù üîπ Team-wise Breakdown 1. Cloud Team Bad sides: Overloaded with seniors; many tend to show off Though juniors are being hired, the show-off culture hasn‚Äôt changed Occasionally engages in blame games with other teams Good sides: Supportive to juniors Strong team leader who knows how to defend and support the team Decent overall team bonding 2. App Team Bad sides: Deep blame-game culture within the team Maximum Most-seniors are unqualified ‚Äî surviving only by shifting blame Acting like a ‚Äúsenior‚Äù and pretending to know things is often enough for a promotion Promotion is more about image, good relation with lead than real contribution Good sides: A few truly hardworking and talented developers still trying to push through Team is culturally humble and quite active socially (team outings, workouts, etc.) Outwardly, bonding within the team seems good 3. QA Team Bad sides: Technically the weakest team in the company Lacks automation skills ‚Äî mostly manual testing Leadership given based on flattery, show off and politics rather than merit Leads tend to be chosen because they speak more, act busy, and ‚Äúlook‚Äù like good managers ‚Äî but actually ‚ÄúGhorar Dim‚Äù Many members lack common sense in assessing issue priorities Time estimates are often dishonest ‚Äî lots of show, minimal actual work. Internal politics and favoritism are present Good sides: The team tries to maintain unity 2‚Äì3 members are genuinely talented ‚Äî but they won‚Äôt grow unless they leave Juniors are tasked with most of the work, which at least gives them learning opportunities 4. IT & Management Bad sides: Too focused on rules, not enough on real productivity Over-regulated: emails required for basic requests, fines for minor device issues, etc. The new HR looks polished but lacks IT professional depth ‚Äî people can tell the difference Good sides: Top management has tried to maintain ethical standards CEO used to be very involved and kept things running well Recently, after the Management and HR expansion, there's been a visible power shift ‚Äî and the company has started to downfall üîπ Extra Observations In some teams, fixing a couple of UI bugs and talking smart is enough to earn a six-figure salary ‚Äî but real skill holders needs to hard -improve yourself in review room Just carrying a ‚Äúsenior vibe‚Äù can get you promoted ‚Äî no deep understanding or problem-solving needed The culture of chapabaji & telbaji > capability is quietly being normalized üîπ Advice to Management CEO should get directly involved again, like before Rebuild the old sense of family and fairness Promote based on skill, impact, and leadership ‚Äî not politics or image Stop rewarding those who only ‚Äúlook‚Äù busy Trust remote work and value output, not just time spent in the office Br0tec5 still has a chance to get back on track ‚Äî but only if these issues are acknowledged and addressed

Unlicensed Financial Activities: ‚ÄúNe> Use of Custom VPN for Operations: Our tech department was tasked with developing and maintaining a Virtual Private Network (VPN) infrastructure. This was ostensibly required to bypass national restrictions and surveillance, enabling access to foreign financial systems and platforms. The necessity of a private VPN in this context was a significant red flag, suggesting efforts to evade detection by regulatory bodies. Non-Transparent Ownership and Capital Flow: There was a notable lack of documentation and transparency regarding the source of funds and investors. Payments were often made using untraceable channels or through third-party wallets and platforms, circumventing proper AML/KYC procedures. Suspicious Ties with Government Official: The company had unusually close and informal interactions with ICT State Minister Zunaid Ahmed Palak. These associations often extended beyond professional boundaries and were not documented via official channels. The frequency and secrecy of these meetings raised concerns about possible influence peddling or corruption. Behavioral Red Flags During Operations:

post_title: Money hungry management, bad work culture, nepotism
full_review: This company would be perfect for people who want to work 2-3 roles while being paid a minimal amount for a single job position. The management will always try their best, ABSOLUTE BEST to pay you the minimal amount. So, negotiate üëèüèª negotiate üëèüèª NEGOTIATE üëèüèª. DON'T SETTLE FOR LESS. The MD promises a whole bunch of "benefits" but realistically, you'll have no access to those benefits before a year and a half of working there. Add 3 more months for those who join as an intern. Don't count on company rules because those rules the employees have to abide by, will change in a minute if the MD decides so. On the subject of interns, "Treat interns as developers" said the MD. He expects production ready, 10/10 quality, fully functional code from interns. He will try his best to get a whole system coded by interns. Unrealistic deadlines for development will be set and you'll be pushed, berated to meet those deadlines. Nepotism is on the rise, thanks to the MD. Employees from a certain organization can get in with barely any interview process at all. Meanwhile, legitimate candidates will get through several interviews only to be rejected in the end. Go look at the LinkedIn profiles of people who joined in the last one year time period, you'll see what I mean. The company culture is sinking down in the gutter real fast. I have heard many tales of a "great culture". I have yet to experience it myself. We have no sick leaves, only 12 casual leaves this year. On top of that, 1 leave gets deducted for every 3 day late count (10:05 am is considered late. Office starts at 10 am). The only REAL pro of a job in this organization is, salary paid by 28th. Personally, I think this should be the normal standard but I'm trying to be positive here.

full_review: Pros: Standard or medium-range salary. Officially hybrid, though most employees work from home. Muslim-friendly office environment. Free in-office meals, including lunch, and snacks. No noticeable office politics or toxic behavior. The company organizes a big annual tour for employees and their families. Opportunities to work with the latest technologies and frameworks. Colleagues and management are friendly and always willing to help. The company covers the cost of personal vendor certifications and regularly hosts tech talks, training program and other activities. Cons: Despite being in business for 12 years, the company's growth has been disappointing (only around 140 employees). The work schedule often starts late in the morning, and employees tend to work into the late hours, which negatively affects work-life balance. While the company has one of the largest business development teams in the Bangladeshi tech industry, their outcomes‚Äîsuch as online presence, marketing efforts, and acquiring new clients‚Äîdo not seem to be as impactful as expected.

post_title: What to and not to expect from Cefalo
full_review: Is cefalo a heaven? No, it is not. Like any other private job, it is not a permanent job. The company will care for you and give you flexibilities if you are dedicated to the company and to your role. All good things that was talked about Cefalo are true. There are some negatives vibes which I believe got explanations as well. But what should you expect and dont expect from cefalo? 1. Does cefalo care: Yes, it does. If you are sick and on leave they will keep on touch with you. You will get sick paid leaves. Is there limit? Yes, in paper. But they will show flexibility depending on your value to the company. It also encourages healthy work life balance. So it expects you to work 8h per day on average excluding 1h break. If client requests to work on weekends, you will get extra payment. 2. Is cefalo time flexible: Yes and no. If you don't abuse it and do your job properly it has no problem giving you that flexibility. For ex: we have flexibility for remote working 2 days per week. During this time, cefalo expects you will be available on office hour and clients can reach you. If you go to park or market and don't respond to your client, what should happen? Always be available to your client on slack or whatever medium you are using. If you are unable to join a meeting say that you will be available in few minutes or if you are in an emergency clarify that. You need to ensure that client is happy with you. 3. Does cefalo let go of employees: Cefalo always tries its best to keep their employees happy and keep them. But there are some factors which hinders it. Cefalo is a client centric company. So let's say you are hired for your special skills. But now the client went away. Cefalo will try to reintroduce you with another client. If it sees in the near future it can't, they will be direct with you and give you until your notice period to find another job. Sometimes clients complains about employees and if cefalo finds it true or employee isn't willing to change, then they will give you time until your notice period. Another thing is if cefalo told you to learn a different stuff because of client requirement (not too far away from what you know), but you are stubborn not to. Then if cefalo can't match you with existing or future clients in queue, they will give you time to look for another job until your notice period. 4. Will cefalo give me promotion based on experience and skill: This is the hardest thing to answer. It depends mostly on your client. If client is happy, you will get better raise. Salary is private but promotion is public. You also need to understand the depth of promotion. This is sometimes (as I am not part of management i can't say for sure but what i heard) used to get your appropriate value from the client. So if you are junior, but you are more valuable to the client, they will promote you. Promotion also means what client expects from you now and what you need to deliver. Cefalo gives promotion based on experience, client's feedback and your contribution (team mates will vouch for your contribution). So there are few factors here. Let's say you are experienced but you are not giving what the client wants or not doing as per client's requirements or not improving yourself, you may get promotion later and lesser increment. Are all clients good? The answer is no. Some can be stubborn, some may not what they want. But you need understand your role here. Your role is to give the best consultations possible based on clients requirements and domain. If client disagrees, still go with the client with a proper tone and finish your role. If you want to switch client or want different challenges, cefalo is always open to it and assign you one as soon as one is available. So you need to be patient with this type of work. 5. Does it always make the best decision: No. The initial decisions sometimes may seem difficult to comprehend. They do give a decision based on various inputs from different management but still it is not always good. But the best thing is that they are always open to hear from you and they can change their decision. The door to MD, EMs and Oslo Management is always open to hear your feedback. They know that if employees are not happy, the business wont survive. They constantly tell us that it is us that made Cefalo come this far. So for any query or explanation you can reach out to them. We also have some good colleagues and seniors, not officially part of the management but would stand up for us when they see anything unfair or some improvements can be done. So, if you keep yourself updated and do your job properly, you will be considered a valuable asset and cefalo will care. If not, cefalo will respectfully tell you that you are not fit for the culture. I think this same for all private companies. Your job is not permanent. You will need to grow your both tech and soft skills to reach higher. Don't take this job for granted and relax. Yes, it is a job with great work life balance compared to others. But at the same time, you have to keep yourself updated and worthy.

post_title: Toxic Leadership, Constant Micromanagement & Zero Work-Life Balance
full_review: Looking for a workplace where meetings last hours but productivity dies in minutes? Where job titles are meaningless, HR is fictional, and the "CEO" is whoever shouts the loudest? Congratulations! you‚Äôve found your match. Salaries are actually paid on time. If you're A$h!q‚Äôs favorite, you might even get a nod of approval ‚Äî just before being publicly humiliated the next week. Work from home? Sure. But don‚Äôt forget to attend 4-hour meetings and work on your weekend. Free of charge, of course. Let‚Äôs start with the elephant in the room: According to the script, Ar!∆í R@hm@√± is the CEO. Unfortunately, this man is more elusive than a unicorn ‚Äî no one‚Äôs seen him. Ever. In reality, A$h!q R@hm@√± calls the shots. But don‚Äôt say that out loud ‚Äî he ‚Äújust represents the stakeholders.‚Äù Cute. A$h!q is a masterclass in the Dunning‚ÄìKruger effect: high confidence, zero clue. Loves to micromanage every pixel while confusing control with competence. Need updates? Don‚Äôt worry, A$h!m the Deputy Director-slash-Personal Assistant-slash-Update Beggar will ping you 15 times in 30 minutes. Because obviously, constant interruption equals progress. There is no SDLC, no documentation, no planning ‚Äî just chaos in bulk. Agile? Waterfall? No, we practice Tsunami ‚Äì wash away everything weekly and start again. Senior devs? QA leads? Doesn‚Äôt matter. If A$h!q‚Äôs chosen parrot reports something you didn't do (or did too well), you‚Äôre out. Loyalty is measured by how many times you say ‚ÄúYes Sir‚Äù per day, not by actual skills. The HR department? Exists in theory. In practice, it‚Äôs just a loudspeaker in human form who specializes in zero conflict resolution and 100% gaslighting. Want to learn? Perfect! You‚Äôll learn how to survive on 12-hour days, skip weekends, tolerate verbal abuse, and still be blamed for things you weren‚Äôt told about. Real-life Hunger Games. The project knowledge is hoarded by a few ‚Äúspecial ones‚Äù like it‚Äôs the One Ring. No knowledge sharing, no documentation ‚Äî just vibes and confusion. Stop pretending Arif is CEO ‚Äî at least own the dictatorship. Give A$h!q a break from ‚Äúrepresenting stakeholders‚Äù and maybe send him to a leadership course. Or therapy. Remove the throne from under A$h!m and maybe assign him a calendar instead of a whip. Fire yourselves and start over. Give employees the basic dignity of structure, respect, and actual HR. No one is asking for magic ‚Äî just a little professionalism and fewer breakdowns. This place isn‚Äôt a tech company. It‚Äôs a corporate reality show where power trips, micromanagement, and gaslighting are daily episodes. You don‚Äôt build a career here. You build trauma. So if you‚Äôre a masochist looking for a masterclass in how not to run a company, welcome aboard! Otherwise, run. Fast.

I had an extremely disappointing experience at D0tp0t IT. The work environment was toxic, and there was a clear lack of professionalism from the top down. Despite my contributions, I was not paid my due salary upon resignation, which is a serious breach of employee trust and ethics. Moreover, leadership behavior was highly concerning. The CEO displayed inappropriate and unprofessional conduct, including substance abuse within the office premises ‚Äî something no employee should have to witness or tolerate. I strongly advise others to consider these issues before associating with this company.

post_title: Tired of Injustice and Nepotism in My Workplace
full_review: Sometimes it's not the workload that breaks you ‚Äî it's the sheer unfairness. I've been tolerating a lot of internal injustice at my bank. Whether it's favoritism, uneven workload distribution, or silent expectations to just ‚Äúadjust,‚Äù I‚Äôve somehow kept going. But something happened recently that really shook me. A junior colleague, R@bbin@, seems to have her path paved by privilege. Her mother, who works at Bangladesh Bank, called in like a panicked guardian ‚Äî not for anything serious, just to ensure her daughter gets extra benefit or soft treatment. And what happens? My supervisor, clearly intimidated by the caller‚Äôs position, bends over backwards. Even asked me to go easy on her. Just like that. Not because she earned it. But because her mother holds influence. I can take a lot ‚Äî but nepotism like this, where someone skips the line because of a phone call, while the rest of us grind in silence? That crosses the line. It sends a clear message: merit doesn‚Äôt matter, connections do. I know this post won‚Äôt change the system overnight, but I needed to put it out there. For anyone who‚Äôs silently enduring similar nonsense ‚Äî you‚Äôre not alone. #UnfairWorkplace #Nepotism #DeshiMulaTruth

post_title: Great learning for freshers, but management & work culture are a nightmare
full_review: Pros: 1. Steep Learning Curve for Freshers: If you're a recent graduate, you will get exposure to real-time projects from day one. This can be overwhelming but also offers a chance to rapidly develop your technical and problem-solving skills. 2. Hands-on Experience: You'll often find yourself working with new technologies and unique challenges, which helps build confidence and resilience early in your career. 3. Responsibility from Day One: While not always a positive, having full project responsibilities immediately does push you to grow‚Äîsink or swim style. Cons: 1. HR Management is a Joke: Easily the worst HR experience. Policies are inconsistent, lack transparency, and often change arbitrarily. There's zero empathy for employees‚Äîleave 10 minutes early and be ready to justify it the next day or fill it in later. Flexibility is non-existent. 2. Toxic Senior Developers (Worse than bad management): Some of the senior developers at Astha IT are not just uncooperative‚Äîthey're actively toxic. They reject new ideas from juniors without even listening, stick to outdated or inefficient methods, and refuse to accept feedback. If a junior suggests a better solution, they‚Äôll shut it down just to assert dominance. It‚Äôs less about what‚Äôs right and more about who‚Äôs in charge. Worse, they humiliate juniors in team meetings making work feel unsafe and demoralizing. Constructive discussion is replaced by ego battles. Even if they make a mistake, they‚Äôll deflect it or dump the responsibility on someone else‚Äîusually a junior who had no part in it. If you speak up, you‚Äôll be the topic of backroom gossip. Some seniors go as far as to badmouth their teammates behind their backs ü§£, creating a toxic, distrustful environment. There's a clear culture of favoritism and sycophancy. If you flatter the right people, you‚Äôre safe‚Äîregardless of your performance. If you challenge the status quo, even respectfully, you‚Äôre targeted or excluded. This environment is not only unhealthy but also deeply discouraging for anyone who wants to grow through open collaboration! 3. Strict and Irrational Timing: Zero flexibility. You're expected to clock in and out like a machine. Forget about a flexible or stress-free work culture. Deviate from the routine, and expect HR or seniors to hound you. 4. Micromanagement Culture: Rather than focusing on productivity or creativity, the company culture revolves around surveillance, blame-shifting, and rigid rules, maintain the time, senior will also involve if you are not filling the time ü§£ if you leave early. 5. Terrible Food: The food provided is of very poor quality. If you're a fresher looking to get your hands dirty with real work and can tolerate a toxic work culture just for the sake of learning, maybe you'll survive a year here. But long term? Not sustainable. Don‚Äôt let the fake positive reviews mislead you!

full_review: My initial experience at the company during the first month was positive ‚Äî I was assigned tasks aligned with the role I was hired for, and the work environment seemed promising. However, over time, the situation changed significantly. There is a severe lack of work-life balance, and transparency is virtually nonexistent. Policies often shift without proper communication, and expectations are not clearly defined or consistently upheld. One major concern is the misleading nature of certain financial and role-related commitments ‚Äî agreements made during hiring or internally are often altered later without accountability. The notice period policy is also unreasonable. Even employees under probation are required to serve a two-month notice, which is highly unusual and restrictive. Additionally, getting approval for time off ‚Äî including sick leave ‚Äî is unnecessarily complicated and often discouraged. Employees are frequently expected to work on weekends and public holidays. Overall, it feels like employees are used primarily to meet project deadlines rather than being valued as long-term team members. Based on my experience, I would not recommend this company to others seeking a fair, transparent, and balanced work environment.

post_title: All the good they built was undone by their shameless neglect of those they let go
full_review: !nfo1ytx had the potential to become one of the top-tier companies in Bangladesh ‚Äî offering a good work-life balance, learning opportunities, and an almost zero-toxic work culture. However, all of that has been overshadowed by their recent actions. Despite everything they‚Äôve built over the past years, they failed to provide layoff benefits for the last two months and instead created confusion and uncertainty for the affected employees. The promises made during this time were vague and insincere, completely undermining the credibility and goodwill the company once had. The salaries owed to the laid-off employees are not substantial ‚Äî especially for a company like ACI, which was involved ‚Äî yet the CEO of Infolytx proved to be a poor negotiator. His incompetence is evident: he couldn't bring any clients, collect dues from ACI, or stand up for his employees. The solutions developed by the tech team were exceptional and timely, but the CEO‚Äôs inability to sell them rendered all that effort meaningless. He deserves an award for sheer incompetency. If you ever need a case study in failed leadership, look no further ‚Äî Badrul Husain embodies everything a CEO should never be: incompetent, indecisive, and indifferent to the people who built the company. Even companies known for toxic cultures typically uphold basic responsibilities like offering severance after a sudden layoff. What Infolytx's management has done is nothing but pure evil and injustices. No amount of good work culture in the past justifies such a shameful neglect of employee rights. If they had been honest from the beginning about their inability to pay the affected employees and had sincerely apologized, the CEO might have retained at least some respect from the team. But instead, they created uncertainty and made false promises. It has been over a year now, and there is still no trace of the money they promised. The management should be deeply ashamed of their actions.

post_title: A Mixed Bag for Developers, Great Perks, but Senior Dev Looks Elsewhere
full_review: 1) Timely Salary. Salary plus other financial benefits are decent, but on average 20-30% lower than other similar statured software companies. 2) Two yearly increment. Again 2 generally less than one increment from other similar statured software companies. 3) Fully subsidized lunch. Provided by catering. Catering does change a lot. So quality flactuates. 4) Office environment and sitting arrangement is good. 5) Flexibility in office timing and work from home opportunities 6) Good leave policies. Leave encashment is available for unused annual leave. 7) Office politics is at extreme level. Mogoj has a lot of employees, so to get promotion or decent increment you have to stand out. My first team lead said "‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶ú‡ßá‡¶∞ ‡¶¢‡ßá‡¶æ‡¶≤ ‡¶®‡¶ø‡¶ú‡ßá ‡¶™‡ßá‡¶ü‡¶æ‡¶®". So people try to stand out and also try to shit talk about teammates to managers to get ahead. Absolute shithousery in this aspect. 8) HR's make lot of promises. But rarely keep it. Can't rely on them or their words. 9) Lots of employees actually work from client's premises. In that case 3,4,5 is not applicable. Generally client's premises environment is horrible. 10) Medical insurance and provident fund. Insurance is upto 25k in a year. In case of any emergency I doubt that will help. 11) Good learning opportunities. Office will provide training material or pay for it. You have to convince your sbu head. Generally not that difficult. You can get great guidance from seniors if there's any in your team. 12) Project management is total lottery. If team lead is great, you will have good time. If not sorry for you. 13) There is lot of praise about mogoj that they don't fire employees. That's because hr will tell you to resign. No firingüòÅ Overall I will say, it's a mixed bag. In perspective of bangladesh, there are not many software companies that has the pros like them. If you are a senior developer, If you are decent at what you do, you will probably look at other similar statured companies and you will think why should not I go to those places and get paid 20-30% more ! Probably this is the reason why senior developers don't stay here. That is why Mogoj has a scarcity on senior resource. Blend of appealing benefits and frustrating realities. For junior developers, this can be a valuable stepping stone, but for experienced professionals, the lower pay and lack of senior retention make it hard to ignore better opportunities elsewhere.

full_review: A Family-Owned Disaster Masquerading as a Tech Company 1. A Family Drama, Not a Company This company is essentially run by one family ‚Äî the MD, CEO, CTO, HR, CFO, all of them. If you're not part of the inner circle, you're treated like you're disposable. They micromanage every detail, expect availability during holidays, and behave as if they own your time and energy. 2. Salary? Delayed, Cut, or ‚ÄúPending‚Äù Forever Timely salaries are a myth here. Payments are irregular, often split in parts, and justified by vague "fund issues." Raises, when granted, are frequently withheld or delayed. While staff waits for months ‚Äî sometimes over a year ‚Äî to receive what they‚Äôre owed, leadership continues to spend on vanity projects and internal politics. 3. No Growth, No Respect, No Fair Pay Underpayment is standard across all levels ‚Äî whether you're a junior or senior. Long-serving employees are edged out for cost-cutting, and career growth is practically nonexistent. Promotions and learning opportunities are rare, replaced by a culture of favoritism and arbitrary decisions. 4. Total Chaos, No Real Management There‚Äôs no structured planning or project management. Tasks change randomly based on someone's mood. One day you're praised, the next you're accused of slacking ‚Äî even with evidence to the contrary. It‚Äôs reactive, inconsistent, and ultimately a toxic work environment. 5. HR & Admin = Unprofessional and Unaccountable HR and Admin, managed by family insiders, are among the worst offenders. There's no formal policy ‚Äî only personal bias. Rules change daily, favoritism is rampant, and accountability is nonexistent. Instead of offering support, they often create more problems than they solve. Bonus: Run Now, Regret Later ‚Äî Trust Me If you're thinking of joining, think again. You‚Äôre better off elsewhere. The promise may sound good, but the reality is far worse ‚Äî chaotic, demoralizing, and unsustainable. Advice to Divine IT Management: If you're serious about turning this company around and building something truly sustainable: Pay salaries on time ‚Äî fully and consistently. Stop citing "fund issues" while continuing to spend in other areas. Replace the current HR team (especially family member) with qualified professionals. Create a fair, transparent HR policy ‚Äî and actually implement it. Hire an experienced CTO like Zubair Bhai or Abir Bhai, and give the current engineering manager the autonomy to lead without constant interference. Bring in real problem-solvers ‚Äî developers and engineers who can think independently, lead, and grow without being micromanaged. Appoint a capable COO and Business Development Head ‚Äî someone like Mr. Ashraf or the late Mr. Baharul (may Allah grant him Jannah) ‚Äî professionals with real experience, not just family ties. Replace the current System Head with someone who understands modern infrastructure, scalability, and sound system design. Treat employees with respect. They're people, not machines. Support them, listen to them, and value their time. Late hours don't always mean hard work. Rebuild a healthy workplace culture ‚Äî because right now, it's broken. Bring back the spirit Divine once had ‚Äî before 2020 ‚Äî when it felt like a place worth working for.

post_title: If wants to Destroy Carrier go to Alin Food Products limited
full_review: Salary delays of up to 2 months , with no proper explanation or timeline. Employees are terminated without prior notice , often unfairly and without reason. Government holidays are not granted , and employees are expected to work without compensation. Toxic work environment , filled with pressure, fear, and unhealthy competition. Frequent misbehavior by senior staff and management ‚Äî including rude, insulting, or humiliating language . No action taken against those who mistreat others, creating a hostile and unsafe culture. Widespread dishonesty ‚Äî false promises, manipulated information, and broken commitments. Lack of job security , with no written clarity on roles, responsibilities, or duration. No final settlement after resignation or termination ‚Äî dues are not paid or even acknowledged . No respect for employee rights ‚Äî overtime, leave, and fair treatment are routinely ignored. Unprofessional conduct from HR and management ‚Äî employees are often disrespected or misled. Zero transparency in payroll, deductions, and internal decision-making.

I'm writing this review after seeing key-board warriors and bootlickers trashing the company, HR, Engineering Director unnecessarily. Like all companies, Opt!m!zely has some not-so-good things. Health insurance can be better, we do not have dental and vision coverage, increment is inconsistent based on departments. All public holidays are not covered. Does it mean it's a terrible company? NO. This same company supported us and did not deduct our salary when we could not work for over a week. My Manager called me to see if I'm okay. My colleagues in London covered for me. My friend in another company lost his job. If a holiday falls on a weekend, we get the next working day as a holiday. Engineering Director is new. It's normal for him to take time to get used to our tech stack and contribute. He's a social person, enjoys spotlight; our previous director did not. What is the problem? HR - sure there are questions on referral bonus. But are they all bad? NO. I was in urgent need of medical visa, I got one on the same day. I too thought 4-5 days for a document means they are incompetent, but one of them explained in a townhall the why. Clearly people do not listen. I wonder if Optimizely is everyone's first workplace. HR works on leave policy, salary, but they are not decision maker. Whenever I've reached out to HR, they were available and spoke with kindness. My previous company's HR was so shitty, maybe you do not know local company HR that's why you look for events and farewells from HR and do not see all the things they do right. I've found the HR team here very professional and doing their best. All the people talking shit -have you ever spoken with them or are you parroting what the sacked Finance Director and now bideshi Product Director filled your heads with. Engineering Director Bhai, you are intelligent. Maybe you mix with the fokinni gang because of limelight. Oita baad den, amra apnar theke shikhte chai. We respect you, please do not lose that.

post_title: Not perfect but still among the best
full_review: Is C3fal0 perfect? Absolutely not. C3fal0 has faced some criticism regarding its culture in this platform which is surprising. Very few companies in this country can match the culture of C3fal0. I personally feel that the negativity C3fal0 receives from some employees is not deserved. When you work in a company, interpersonal issues may arise. The best way to deal with them is by being open and discussing them - not by bashing your colleagues on anonymous platforms. In all my years at C3fal0, I have never felt unwelcome when expressing my views to my colleagues, especially the management. The Oslo management has also been equally supportive. Perhaps we should be more open about our concerns and work to solve them together, rather than posting anonymously and avoiding our responsibilities. That said, C3fal0 does have some issues , particularly around the evaluation process, which seems like a mystery to many. It‚Äôs creating a lot of friction, and hopefully, C3fal0 will address this matter soon. Peace ‚úåÔ∏è

post_title: Is it the place someone should stay in for more than a few years?
full_review: The sky's the limit here. If you play your cards right, youll get to learn a ton of things here as an Engineer. From Software to Infra, the expertise here is mind boggling. Knowledgeable people all round. If you are a new grad, sorry to burst your bubble but I stand with the CTO here that work-life balance should not be your priority right now. You must give your all to learn what there is to learn and extract as much real-world knowledge as possible from the highly experienced people here. Both foreign and domestic. Communication is the one soft skill that is highly appreciated and lets you grow beyond your immediate team bubble. You MUST engage with your collegues and management if you want to be valued here. High salary blah blah, you've seen the other reviews and the list of cons that come with that. I'd like to highlight a few things though: CTO is "sad" about it. Does nothing. And gave false assurances. Big mistake. No one believes his assurances anymore regarding management decisions. The level of respect he has for his huge depth of technical knowledge is tarnished by poor management decisions. (Him being a core founder has a lot to do with it) Another conscious decision that is constantly being talked about in the office these days along with delayed salary and has lead to low morale and concerns regarding company future. We are joking around now, but people have started looking elsewhere to find more stable companies. Yeah it seems like leads feel uncomfortable vetoing stupid management decisions. Planning week? Its a joke. Its frequently suggested to us by the CTO that team leads decide on things to do and plan according to the capabilities of engineers under them. But nahhh. No one believes that crap. Decisions are top down and sudden. "Need this now because CEO wants this " is very common and everyone's life is made shorter trying to push those deadlines. Most of Planning week is spent trying to finish last 2 week sprint's work. Bootcamps at Jashore? Literally makes you work from morning to midnight, sometimes for a week or two. WITHOUT any additional compensation. What the hell?? And that too, not for some imminent threat to business, but just because they can? Are leads making the decision here? Nope, its all CEO and CTO and some other folks. And they laugh about it during sprint meetings. Yeah, no one outside of management is laughing. They are bitching about you and your lack of compensation and delayed salaries. Yeah, no one will ever buy your " We dont work like other companies who gives lots of leaves and are really slow to achieve anything ". That doesnt make the company a fast moving one, just makes it what it is: 12 something years in and still having cashflow issues? Its understandable, really, we can have bad periods, but cmon, lets stop with with this fancy " we are better than others " business and just allow your employees some basic time offs that almost all white collar job holders IN BANGLADESH enjoy. Stop aligning yourself with the US holidays, being a company in BD. Act like a company in BD . You are not achieving any major business goals other than constantly disgruntled and abused and demoralized employees who will eternally hate your leave/holiday policies and your disrespect of work-life separation. Domestic Engineering managers and leads also have no option but to push/ask juniors to work overtime to avoid upper mangement disapproval. Literally everyone i've talked to who left Chaldal Engineering, see it as a relief when it comes to having a life outside of work . That says something about how traumatizing and deeply flawed the culture is. Is that really the kind of culture you want to keep around? The CTO is a workaholic and understandably so, he's a founder and in general a super-talented geek. But he should dial his expectations down when it comes to his overworked engineers who dont get to spend holidays with family. The company is a PLC now. Shares were promised, I assume as a way to align the engineers more with the company goals, where are those? HR is one of those resources that should be working for the employee interest rather than against them. And in here, HR is a joke. Filled with people who are used to constantly hiring, fining, firing,¬† warehouse folks. Not one engineer thinks we should have to share the same policies as the warehouse folks. We understand (and also are against some of) the limitations and policies that have to be in place for ground staff. But as an engineer, in an engineering focused company, we shouldn't be held to the same standards and policies, but rather be on par with other engineering-focused/engineering companies. There are a lot of exceptions made for engineering just because CTO is a co-founder. And it is genuinely appreciated. But this is also the "norm" in other engineering companies outside and not the exception, so while its appreciated, a lot of talented individuals had to leave the company/were about to leave the company for them to consider these. And the pessimist in me thinks more people need to set their boundaries for management to consider any meaningful change. The reason i'm giving a mixed review is because after all of these, you get to grow a lot here and be solidly prepared for an engineering life with confidence that you're so traumatized, most things outside you can handle. Be it Google or Amazon or any other company, foreign or domestic, you can carve your space with confidence if you want and if you focus, your communication skills would improve due to the english-focused management. So as it stands now, Cha1da1 is one of the best place to start your career . Not sure about the rest. Not sure if management even wants to build a loyal, genuinely content, long-term employees with deep interest in the company future. Or we are just contractors, needed for a few years, until the next batch of fresh grads come.

post_title: Great people. Great place to work. Terrible last month.
full_review: I don't want to say much because I have already left this company (thankfully) and have a much better role elsewhere. I miss Optimizely and all of the people there. Honestly, I do. I loved the work. I loved the engineers, the pms, the sales teams, the solutions guys, the commercial people, and even the support team. I see all of these complaints on DeshiMula and I can't vibe with them because back in our times, they were not there. But I also hated it the last few months. The way HR spoke to me once I told them I am planning to leave still has my ears ringing. The way they forced me to resign even though I had already communicated in advance that I am waiting for an update on something and would resign later. The way a guy on their team was absurdly rude to me. The way I could not even ask a question about the financial issues. The way they asked me to sign paperwork then and there immediately almost as if I am a criminal for deciding to accept a better offer. The way they weren't giving me a release letter and were chilling in some other country when it was important to me. I will never forget that. It was odd how HR suddenly turned on me the moment I told them I found a better role! There was no proper exit debrief (shouldn't that be standard?) or else I wouldn't be writing it here. But I was hurt. And I will carry that feeling forever that this company treats you like shit once you leave. Just speak to some other people who have left and you will understand. Some of the guys who were in newscred had it different. It wasn't the same experience for us. Man, it wasn't even my manager. It was a bunch of sore losers who didn't even know me properly. I just wish I was in a financial position to throw the money in your face and walk away instead of having to go through that.

full_review: It was the company where I started my career as a fresher. To be very honest, my experience with this company was truly great. The environment was friendly, they always encouraged the little things, celebrated small achievements, valued employee opinions, and maintained transparency. I still remember the days when I worked there. My parents were going through several health issues, and The TL, other seniors and even the CEO (Ron bhai) personally kept in touch with me to check on their condition. He even offered help to arrange my mother‚Äôs check-up abroad, online! This is what i call the beauty of a good workplace. I‚Äôm not sure about the current situation there. One thing I did feel was that the salary was a bit low compared to the current market standard. I also gave some feedback when I left. There were a few other things to mention, but I wouldn't call them "major." They were still a new company with limited resources, so I believe some of the challenges came from that. Perhaps not all resources had adapted to the positive culture yet. There were many perks too (you can find them on their JD) To be very frank, this place showed me what "good culture" and "employee value" truly mean. I‚Äôm currently working at other companies, but I‚Äôll always be grateful to them for introducing me to "the culture of a truly employee-friendly company." I‚Äôve been seeing a lot of complaints about the HR recently, which made me a bit sad and confused based on my own experience. So, I felt the need to share my honest review here. I have so many good memories. I‚Äôll always wish you all the best. Advice: Please give proper attention to the salary structure, and also seriously consider the complaints you're currently facing.

post_title: A Year of Change: What I‚Äôve Really Seen Inside AGT
full_review: I joined the company 11 months ago, back when it was still in its early stages. Things were a bit rough around the edges at the time ‚Äî as you‚Äôd expect from any new company ‚Äî but I‚Äôve seen consistent improvement in how processes are handled, how communication flows, and how the overall structure has matured. I applied directly through their HR link without any referral. Shortly after, I got a call to schedule an interview. One area that could be improved: I received that initial call at 9 PM, which is quite late ‚Äî HR could definitely be more mindful about contacting candidates during reasonable hours. Interview Experience: The interview itself went well. I was nervous and stumbled over some answers, but the interviewer was incredibly kind and understanding. He could tell I was anxious and even gave me a moment to breathe and collect my thoughts. That kind of empathy during interviews is rare these days and really stood out. Onboarding: The onboarding process involved the usual background verification steps ‚Äî nothing unexpected. I was later asked to take a final call with management on a weekend, but I had family commitments and requested to reschedule. Again, scheduling could be improved, but they were flexible and understanding once I asked. In the final call, the manager took time to ask how my day was going and provided detailed feedback on my interview and areas for growth. It felt like a genuine conversation, not just a formality. Work Culture & Benefits (based on my experience): Unlimited sick leave Fully remote (there‚Äôs an office, but in-person engagement could be more frequent) 14 days PTO ‚Äî would love to see this increased, especially for those based in Bangladesh Up to 100% bonus based on performance No formal festival bonus Equipment reimbursement (40k BDT ‚Äî available post-probation) Probation period feels long; could be shortened Monthly trivia contests with 10k‚Äì20k BDT cash prizes Paid interviews Overtime is paid at 1.5x the standard rate Management communication has been consistent and respectful in my experience Addressing the Negative Feedback: I‚Äôve seen some negative posts lately, and while everyone‚Äôs experience is valid, I genuinely haven‚Äôt had those issues. The company sends out monthly anonymous surveys where anyone can share feedback directly with leadership. If you‚Äôre facing challenges, I encourage you to use those tools and voice your concerns constructively. Posting frustrations in public forums might feel like an outlet, but it doesn‚Äôt lead to meaningful change. If you want something addressed, let upper management know directly ‚Äî from what I‚Äôve seen, they‚Äôre open to feedback and willing to take action when something‚Äôs not working. To sum it up: this is still a¬†young company finding its rhythm, but it‚Äôs come a long way in just a year. I‚Äôve personally felt supported, respected, and heard. That may not be everyone‚Äôs experience, and that‚Äôs okay ‚Äî but I wanted to share mine.

post_title: The Downfall of a Department ‚Äî Caused by One Person
full_review: I have been a part of Pa7ha0‚Äôs marketing department for over 3 years now. I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work under various managers in my career, and throughout this time, I‚Äôve truly appreciated Pathao‚Äôs culture and values. However, what once felt like an admirable workplace now often feels like a daily struggle ‚Äî and the reason, unfortunately, lies in one toxic individual: my brand head. Let me be clear ‚Äî our marketing department head is someone I respect deeply. He is wise, strategic, and genuinely invested in our growth. I‚Äôve felt valued whenever he directly engages with me and conducts meetings with my team, offers insights, and encourages growth for my service vertical. But this sense of value is quickly shattered by the toxic leadership of the person leading Brand. Despite having several years of work experience, our lead consistently displays insecurity, power abuse, and emotional instability. She often prevents us from collaborating directly with senior leadership, fearing it might undermine her control over us, brand subordinates. Rather than empowering her team, she chooses to dominate and belittle. She lashes out over the smallest issues, often screaming in meetings‚Äî sometimes so loudly that it echoes through our entire floor. She insults managers infront of us juniors, which is humiliating for them, and as well as for us to witness such toxicity. During campaigns, she severely messes up and blames us for it. She will assign us unrealistic deadlines without much direction on what needs to be done, and then attack us for not fulfilling the output she expected. She will commit projects to higher ups, without aligning us and then blame her own misalignments within our own team, when we are unable to deliver to the external stakeholders. Then she will present us, even the most skilled professionals, to be incompetent. Her leading our team is based on fear and humiliation, not guidance or support. Behind people‚Äôs back, she mocks and criticizes everyone, be it the CEO or VP or any colleague senior or junior. Yet to their faces she maintains a false charm, with her fake smiles and deceiving tactics. She formed our work group titled ‚ÄúPeacekeepers‚Äù ‚Äî ironically, she is the biggest threat to our peace of mind. While we work weekends and holidays by her forced orders, she spends that time partying, having fun and posting stories we send ‚Äòlove‚Äô reacts to. As a result ‚Äîwe do the hard work, she takes the credit for it infront of top management. She regularly boasts to other departments that ‚Äòmarketing department‚Äô can‚Äôt achieve anything, it‚Äôs a failure department, and that ¬†without her we cannot do any project‚Äî yet spends more time demoralizing us than building us up. If she finds our office so horrifying, why is she still here with us for over 2 years? If someone doesn‚Äôt follow her absurd instructions, she says, ‚ÄúTui korbina? Onno manush diye kore feli tor kaaj‚Äù, no matter if you‚Äôre a manager or executive, we are treated as slaves by her rather than educated corporate professionals. These constant threats of replacement have us severely demoralized and demotivated. Several team members have taken their concerns to HR and higher ups, yet no action has ever been taken against her. She‚Äôs heavily protected because she goes clubbing with them. She faces no consequences for mistakes at all, and wasting our company‚Äôs big budgets. Once a female executive from PMT resigned after repeated verbal abuse from her. One of our talented senior designers left due to her abusive tone and attitude towards the design team. The brand team has seen mass exits after her arrival and fresh hires were from her own cohorts. The pattern is undeniable, yet overlooked with excuses. To cover up her damage to us, she provides us with superficial ‚Äúteam bonding‚Äù gestures ‚Äî gifts, drinks, casual outings. But beneath that, she resents anyone smarter or more capable than her and continues her tyranny with us. She body shames our male/female colleagues and told one of my team girls to dress better and wear makeup ‚Äî a humiliating remark, especially coming from someone who claims to champion women‚Äôs empowerment on her socials. Her hypocrisy runs very deep! At the beginning of this year, she posted her new year resolution as: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let your ego stop you from communicating with empathy‚Ä¶ Power shouldn't come at the cost of someone‚Äôs dignity.‚Äù But every day, she conducts office in the opposite way ‚Äî threatening our team with arrogance and cruelty. She can‚Äôt control her tantrums and bad temper at her workplace at all. And humiliates us in unimaginable ways. Her LinkedIn is filled with posts like: ‚ÄòFor me, multitasking isn't about doing everything at once-it's about knowing what to prioritize, staying adaptable, and keeping a cool head.‚Äô But none of it reflects in how she practically functions as a professional. In reality, she can‚Äôt keep a cool head herself, nor smoothly run multiple projects, nor lead us in the proper direction. I am speaking up, in the hopes that there is a change. The department is suffering. Morale is low. Growth is stunted. One person‚Äôs unchecked toxicity is ruining the entire department‚Äôs success. It‚Äôs time someone takes this seriously ‚Äî for the future of Pathao‚Äôs brand.

post_title: A Company Built by Its People Deserves Better.
full_review: I have recently come across several posts on DeshiMula. Initially I was not following them very closely. It is not that I am indifferent. I just did not have the time or energy to go through everything being said. However I do appreciate the purpose of this platform. Giving professionals a voice and allowing them to reflect on their work experiences is a valuable initiative and one that deserves recognition. Regarding Opt!m!zly I want to start by saying that no company is perfect. Every workplace has its strengths and weaknesses. I have read a number of the recent reviews and some of them make fair points. Constructive feedback is important and when offered with good intent it can help leadership identify areas for growth. Whether or not those insights lead to actual changes is up to the people in charge. What pushed me to write this post is not disagreement with criticism. It is the way some of the criticism has turned personal. It is disappointing to see posts targeting individuals with hostility. Many of the people being criticised have spent years building the very environment we now benefit from. I have had the chance to interact with some of them both professionally and informally. Despite their seniority they have always treated me with respect and made time to support when needed. That level of professionalism deserves to be acknowledged. Of course nobody is perfect. Not the leadership. Not the employees. Not me either. We all have flaws and yes we all sometimes complain or gossip. But there is a difference between sharing thoughts with a colleague and publishing personal attacks on a public platform. If someone genuinely caused harm by blocking a promotion or creating a toxic experience I hope that it was addressed with a manager or through HR before being made public. If not then it raises the question of whether the goal was improvement or just public venting. Life is always about trade-offs. To offer an analogy consider the residential area of Bashundhara R A. It has many challenges. Some say there are not enough mosques. Others mention the distance to grocery stores or the nearby university students' lifestyle that might not appeal to everyone. Still many people choose to live there. They might have a child studying in a nearby school or university. Or maybe it is closer to work. Or maybe it provides a better security then other areas. And those who cannot adjust simply move somewhere else. No one forces anyone to stay. The same applies to workplaces. If the culture or environment does not suit someone they have every right to leave. But leaving with grace is very different from trying to tear down what remains. Especially when others still work there and appreciate what has been built. Opt!m!zly is a global company. We work with colleagues from a wide range of cultures religions and personal backgrounds. Naturally there will be differences in lifestyle and beliefs. But our purpose here is not to push personal ideologies. It is to perform learn grow and contribute within a global professional setting. I also want to point out something important. The job market is connected in more ways than we often realize. When someone speaks negatively about their workplace online it creates an impression that may follow them. If I were hiring and I saw a organization name associated with public hostility towards from their employees, I would hesitate and think carefully before bringing that person into my team regardless how talented that person is. Talent is valuable but team culture matters too. I am not defending every decision made by leadership. This message is not about taking sides. It is simply a call for professionalism and perspective. Respect your workplace. And if it does not feel right anymore seek opportunities that align better with your long term goals. Do it with maturity. To the leadership team at Opt!m!zly both past and present I want to say that there are many of us who see your effort and dedication. We may not always say it out loud but your contributions are noticed and appreciated. To everyone reading this I hope this comes across in the spirit it is intended. If I have unintentionally offended anyone that was not my intention. I am simply offering a viewpoint from one professional to another. Wishing you all continued growth and success in your careers and lives.

post_title: Don‚Äôt Let Anonymous Noise Define Reality
full_review: Let me start with this: Anyone can post anything here. No verification, no fact-checking, no accountability. That‚Äôs what this platform allows ‚Äî and while it gives people space to speak up, it also opens the floodgates for personal attacks, fake reviews, and straight-up lies. That one review going around about the SQA lead? Come on. You don‚Äôt have to be a detective to guess where it‚Äôs coming from. Ekhane jodi keu truly kaaj kore thakto, tader tone onek balanced hoto ‚Äî not full-on personal rage and unverified drama. If you had genuine feedback, you‚Äôd go through a proper channel, not write a hate post I‚Äôve been part of this company long enough to know that not everything‚Äôs perfect ‚Äî but jader theke feedback ashe, ora at least specific hoy. Ei dhoroner ‚ÄúX person is a moron‚Äù type post bolbe na. Real talk: Ei forum e verification nai. Ami-o ekhon ekta review post kortesi ‚Äî amakeo keu verify kore nai. So let‚Äôs not use this platform as the judge, jury, and executioner. Company te jodi problem thake, monthly surveys ache, HR ache, escalation path ache ‚Äî use those. Bhai, ei shob personal grudges diye review likhle company r naam na dube ‚Äî amar, apnar, shobar naam dube. We all work in the same industry. If any future company wants to come to BD with their offshore jobs, things like this will deflect them. If you didn‚Äôt make it in the company or got removed for performance, boro manush er moto accept koro. Next e better koro. But ei type namer opor attack kore kichu hobena ‚Äî it makes you look worse, not them. And let‚Äôs talk about Syed for a second ‚Äî I personally worked with him. He‚Äôs one of the hardest workers I‚Äôve seen. He taught the team tools, set up reporting systems, and handled responsibilities that clearly rolled up to a QA Lead level ‚Äî responsibilities that I‚Äôm pretty sure most of you never even got exposure to. He works efficiently, helps others without hesitation, and brings nothing but positivity to the team. If you think that‚Äôs a problem, that‚Äôs on you ‚Äî but I‚Äôve seen the kind of person he is, and he‚Äôs genuinely one of the most wholesome and capable people in this company. Take your petty drama somewhere else. And seriously ‚Äî kon team e layoff nai? In a team of 3, if 1 person is let go for performance or alignment reasons, how does that automatically mean the whole company is a mess? By that logic, every org in the world is a disaster. Let‚Äôs be real, numbers matter, context matters. I don‚Äôt know who needs to hear this: Grow up. Move on. Do better.

post_title: You can do the job without salary then join the company. just busthi ekta compnay
full_review: Salaries are often delayed for up to two months without any clear justification or communication about when payments will be made. Employees are dismissed without prior notice or valid reasons, making terminations abrupt and often unjust. Public holidays are routinely ignored, with staff expected to work without any form of additional pay or compensatory time off. The workplace culture is toxic ‚Äî driven by fear, constant pressure, and harmful internal competition. Senior staff and management frequently behave inappropriately, using disrespectful, insulting, or degrading language. Management fails to address abusive behavior, allowing a culture of intimidation and hostility to thrive. There is a pattern of dishonesty ‚Äî including misleading information, broken promises, and misrepresentation. Job roles and employment terms are unclear and undocumented, leaving employees with no sense of security or protection. When employees resign or are terminated, their dues and final settlements are often withheld or completely ignored. Employee rights are routinely overlooked ‚Äî with no regard for fair compensation, overtime pay, or leave entitlements. HR and management display unprofessional behavior, often misleading or disregarding employees altogether. Payroll processes and internal decisions lack any transparency, creating confusion and distrust.

full_review: Let‚Äôs be real‚ÄîWe11Dev used to be a decent place to work. Now? It‚Äôs a dumpster run by clueless management who‚Äôve turned it into a stress factory. Employees have to beg for their own salaries while management acts like it‚Äôs no big deal. Unprofessional? Absolutely. Disrespectful? You bet. # Fresher Exploitation: The We11Dev Special Their entire business model? Hire cheap, burn out fast. You‚Äôre expected to sell your soul just to meet their unrealistic demands. #HR: The Joke That Writes Itself The recruitment process is a circus. HR schedules endless interviews, wasting everyone‚Äôs time, then hires based on who knows what. The HR manager? A walking disaster. His English is so bad, even Google Translate would cringe. He‚Äôs late every single day but loves lecturing others about punctuality. This person‚Äôs brain operates at the speed of a rusty bicycle wheel. You ask a simple question, and he just... freeze. His face goes blank as his overworked brain cell struggles to process even the most basic logic. By the time he finally spit out a response, you‚Äôve already aged five years, and whatever he say is usually nonsense anyway. post_title: We11Dev's Financial Failures: When Paychecks Become Optional
full_review: Forget everything you've heard about professional workplaces - We11Dev has rewritten the rulebook on how to mistreat employees. Over the past year, they've established a disturbing pattern of financial negligence that would make any respectable company blush. After particularly egregious delays earlier this year, management attempted to buy silence with a one-time 25k BDT "goodwill payment" while making hollow assurances. Predictably, nothing changed. This isn't about cash flow problems - it's about priorities. The fact that certain offices always get paid on time proves We11Dev could fix this if they cared to. Instead, they've chosen to treat Bangladeshi staff as second-class employees, maintain a culture of broken promises, hide behind pathetic excuses rather than solve problems, prioritize preaching over payroll. Any company that can't master basic payroll fundamentals doesn't deserve your talent. We11Dev has shown repeatedly they view timely compensation as a privilege rather than a right. Until they demonstrate fundamental respect for their workforce through consistent, on-time payments across all locations, no employee should trust them with their livelihood.

This platform allows anyone to share their opinions‚Äîunverified, unchecked, and sometimes driven by personal emotions rather than facts. While it‚Äôs important for employees to voice concerns, we should also recognize that anonymous posts can sometimes be misleading, exaggerated, or even false. I‚Äôve been with this company for a while, and like any workplace, it has its challenges. But if we truly want to improve things, the best approach is to provide constructive feedback. Public rants, especially those fueled by personal grudges, don‚Äôt solve problems; they only spread negativity. We all share the same industry, and our words shape perceptions. If every frustration turns into a public attack, it doesn‚Äôt just hurt the company‚Äîit affects all of us. Future investors and global employers looking at Bangladesh might hesitate if they only see hostility instead of professionalism. Let‚Äôs aim for solutions, not just venting. If we have real concerns, let‚Äôs raise them constructively. That‚Äôs how we grow‚Äîas individuals, as a company, and as an industry.

full_review: Aiming for Excellence: The Managing Director (MD) is truly determined to make Cefalo the best company in Bangladesh. Strong Management: The management team‚Äîespecially the admin department‚Äîis exceptionally active and efficient. Best in My Career: In my 12-year professional career, I have found Cefalo's management to be the best I‚Äôve ever worked with. Positive Response to Challenges: I once had a very unpleasant experience with an HR head named Zakaria. However, I received a very satisfactory response from top management. Eventually, he was removed from the company, which showed that the leadership listens and takes action when needed. Client-Based Culture: Cefalo is a client-oriented company, so you must satisfy both the client and Cefalo. Since not all clients are the same, you need to be prepared to adapt to new projects or adjust to different client expectations. Satisfying Cefalo is fairly straightforward‚Äîif you follow at least 60% of the office rules, management will be quite happy. Healthy Work Environment: I‚Äôve been with the company for about 2.7 years and have never experienced any toxic "vai-brother" culture. Of course, like any company, there are always a few old-timers who live in their own world‚Äîbut that‚Äôs natural. Excellent Engineering Managers: I‚Äôve worked with four Engineering Managers (including one former EM), and all of them were highly skilled and approachable. Each has their own leadership style, but they are all genuinely good at what they do. Prompt Support: I‚Äôve never faced delays when requesting anything related to my office life. The support system is efficient and responsive. Gratitude and Realism: Nothing is permanent‚Äînot even my own tenure at the company. But I will always hold the best wishes for Cefalo and its management. FYI: My English is not good. I took help from GPT to make good English btw.

post_title: False Promises, Zero Growth: My Experience with Dijitech ICT
full_review: The ICT department at Digitech gives false hope to its employees. They promise permanent employment after six months, but in reality, it often takes over a year ‚Äî sometimes even longer. Employees stay silent out of fear of losing their jobs. What are their goals? Their plans? Their mission? Honestly, even they don‚Äôt seem to know. Most of the staff are beginners with very limited industry experience ‚Äî and to be fair, that's not their fault. But the lack of proper guidance and mentorship only makes things worse. While a few in-charges genuinely try to support their teams, most of them lack even the basic experience to handle real projects. They often withhold important information, avoid clear communication, and some seem to receive special treatment from upper management. As a result, the employees working under them struggle to grow ‚Äî and even worse, their hard work is often taken credit for by those leads. Incentives? Forget it. No one hears that word in this department unless they‚Äôre among a ‚Äúfavored few.‚Äù Yearly increments are just as disappointing. In some cases, it‚Äôs as low as 500 BDT. Sometimes, the only ‚Äúreward‚Äù you get is a new designation ‚Äî with no actual benefits. Ironically, those who get the most out of the system often have little to no understanding of what CSE, EEE, ETE, or even basic engineering really means. On the other hand, I‚Äôve heard good things about Walton Hi-Tech ‚Äî at least they seem to value and support their people. If you‚Äôre considering career options, avoid Digitech ICT. It‚Äôs not worth your time or talent.

It‚Äôs a bit concerning that we‚Äôre not receiving the official Bangladeshi government holidays. Additionally, the removal of the unlimited vacation policy‚Äîreportedly due to non-compliance with Bangladesh‚Äôs labor laws‚Äîhas been quite unexpected. We raised this issue several times in the group chat or with HR but they always come up with a global operating model etc etc. But there are so many other multinational companies giving full govt holidays with better benefits! Another point, no criticism is taken here properly. Management either doesn't pay attention or gives a toxic reply as a solution to the criticism. There is no way Opt!m!zely will get ‚ÄúGreat place to work‚Äù this year with this toxic management.

post_title: My Experience with Station & n0pStat!on (eCommerce SBU)
full_review: I wanted to share my honest experience ‚Äî highlighting both the positives and areas where improvement is needed. Timely Salary ‚Äì No need to worry about Salary, you will get it before month end. Appraisals Twice a Year ‚Äì A rare and motivating benefit. Quarterly Bonuses (4 times a year) ‚Äì If you are just doing your job you will get good reward! Two Eid Bonuses ‚Äì As per your basic Provident Fund ‚Äì You can even take loans from it with 0% interest. Gratuity Fund ‚Äì A solid step toward long-term financial security. Flexible Office Hours Growth-Oriented Culture Strong Job Security These truly make a difference in day-to-day work life. Lunch & Snacks Quality ‚Äì Needs urgent attention. Salary Structure ‚Äì Needs to be more competitive. Medical Insurance ‚Äì Need to be more comprehensive. Training Opportunities ‚Äì More structured upskilling initiatives would help. Senior Talent Drain ‚Äì Many seniors are leaving, and honestly, it‚Äôs not right. One major reason is the salary structure ‚Äî it‚Äôs not attractive enough to retain or hire experienced people. Another important point is that the company‚Äôs growth spiked suddenly, and senior resources didn‚Äôt scale up with that growth. Food Quality ‚Äì This must be taken seriously and improved immediately. Salary Recognition ‚Äì High performers should be rewarded based on contribution, not just years of experience. The company should also invest in hiring mid-level resources at better compensation. üí¨ Final Thought: This is my personal experience ‚Äî others might have different perspectives. But one thing is clear: this is a service-based company that values those who genuinely add value, If you're just looking for a typical 9-to-5 job without pushing yourself to grow or contribute meaningfully, this might not be the right place for you. It rewards doers, not seat-fillers. I often notice that people who struggle with performance tend to be more vocal about negatives, while overlooking their own improvement area and the many unique benefits the company already provides. üéØ In today's market, it's rare to find all of these positive elements in one place ‚Äî and that deserves acknowledgment.

post_title: All I want to say is that they don‚Äôt really care about us
full_review: All I want to say is that they don‚Äôt really care about us - MJ This line resonates deeply with what many current and former employees are feeling at 8RAC IT. Concerns around nepotism, toxic leadership, internal politics, and even basic infrastructure issues like inadequate seating continue to go unaddressed. These are not isolated incidents, they‚Äôre echoed across numerous reviews on platforms like Deshi Mula. What‚Äôs more concerning is the apparent indifference from management. Despite repeated feedback, there has been no visible effort to acknowledge or address these issues. Instead, the focus continues as if nothing has happened, the same routine, the same distractions, and the same avoidable problems being ignored. Internal events are still being organized as usual, which, while perhaps well-intentioned, feel tone-deaf when the real challenges remain completely unaddressed. Employee engagement is important, but it cannot replace the need for a healthy work environment built on fairness, transparency, and respect. When HR prioritizes surface-level activities over real concerns, it sends a clear message, one that aligns all too well with that song lyric. For the 600+ employees, there‚Äôs an underlying fear, if the situation continues unchecked, they may ultimately be the ones to face the fallout, while those leaders benefiting from the current status quo remain unaffected. Real change starts with listening, and then acting. Until then, the silence speaks volumes.

post_title: A Rollercoaster Ride Worth Taking-Flexible Working Hours and Competitive Salaries with cons
full_review: I won't lie!!! Starting at this company truly felt like being thrown into the deep end without a life jacket. The onboarding process was minimal, leaving me to navigate complex projects with little guidance. Communication from management was sporadic, and expectations often shifted without notice. However, I came to view these challenges as valuable opportunities to develop and refine my communication skills. Facing these initial hurdles pushed me to become more resourceful and self-reliant, qualities that have significantly contributed to my professional growth in my opinion. The flexible working hours: while a perk, sometimes blurred the lines between work and personal time, especially when collaborating with international clients. This isn't unique to this company; similar dynamics exist in global top agencies. I was sad about this but then doing a little research i found we are better than more famous agencies in this country. It's a reality of working in a globally connected environment. Over time, I came to appreciate the unique opportunities this environment offered. The company's commitment to growth meant I was constantly exposed to new technologies and methodologies, significantly enhancing my skill set. The team, though remote, was incredibly supportive and collaborative (there are a few exceptional people which you know no one loves it happens in Google too so why should i complain), creating a sense of community despite the physical distance. Moreover, the compensation was competitive while i joined , and the company made efforts to recognize hard work through timely payments and occasional perks. While the journey had its bumps, the growth and experience I gained here were invaluable. To be honest It's a place that challenges you, pushes you out of your comfort zone, and, in doing so, prepares you for greater heights in your career. Advice to senior management First off, I want to express my appreciation for the strides the company has made in creating a flexible and dynamic work environment. The commitment to timely compensation, exposure to diverse projects, and the autonomy provided to employees are commendable and have positively impacted many of us. However, I've noticed that communication is an area where we could elevate our game. Some team members have mentioned challenges with clarity in expectations and feedback loops. Enhancing our communication channels could foster a more cohesive and supportive atmosphere, ensuring everyone feels heard and aligned. By investing in structured communication strategies and perhaps regular check-ins or feedback sessions, we can bridge gaps and reinforce our collaborative spirit. This not only benefits our internal culture but also positions us to be a leading agency in Bangladesh, known for both our innovation and our inclusive workplace.

I do not fully agree with the issue regarding the termination. I have been working at Silicon for a long time, and from my experience, terminations are very rare. In most cases, such actions are taken only when there is significant indiscipline or repeated failure to perform responsibilities properly. Even then, only one or two individuals have been let go, and there were valid reasons behind those decisions.
As for the food, it‚Äôs important to understand that preferences vary from person to person. Not everyone will have the same taste. While I wouldn‚Äôt rate it a 10 out of 10, I would confidently give it an 8 out of 10. It's not unusual for a few individuals to occasionally find the taste unsatisfactory, considering the food is prepared for a large group of people.
Also, I would like to point out that the management team is very supportive and understanding. They consider personal situations and offer considerable flexibility to employees in various aspects. Therefore, it is unfair to place the entire blame on the company just because one or two individuals were terminated due to their own mistakes.

This company rarely fires anyone unless their performance becomes truly unsustainable. I‚Äôve seen developers who struggled, given years to improve.
