Of course, not everyone is able to maintain that trust due to their own carelessness. Still, I‚Äôve seen the office provide sufficient support and counseling to them. However, if someone repeatedly fails to fulfill their responsibilities and continues to show negligence, then it's natural for them to receive a notice from the company. Isn‚Äôt that fair?And from what I‚Äôve seen, even these notices are issued in compliance with Bangladesh‚Äôs labor laws.
I consider myself fortunate to be part of such a supportive team‚Äîsomething that is truly a blessing for any developer. A strong team can handle even the toughest projects with ease, and I‚Äôve personally witnessed this.
Now, regarding the food issue‚ÄîDue to work, I‚Äôve had the opportunity to spend some time at several leading giant companies in Bangladesh, where I‚Äôve experienced their breakfast, lunch, and snack offerings. Compared to them, SOL actually provides fairly good food.Of course, not everything is perfect every single day, but I would rate SOL‚Äôs food quality as follows (on a scale of 10):Breakfast: 8, Lunch: 7.5, Evening Snacks: 8.5 (on average).Even though this food is completely complimentary, I don‚Äôt quite understand why there‚Äôs so much dissatisfaction about it.

From my experience, the office environment is friendly and stress-free. Breaks are relaxed, and there‚Äôs no micromanagement ‚Äì you‚Äôre trusted to get your work done at your own pace, which I truly appreciate. The flexible work schedule is a significant advantage, making it easier to maintain a good work-life balance.Even when there‚Äôs no client project for some time, they don‚Äôt just fire the employee. As far as I know, no one has been fired simply for not being able to perform. If someone was let go, there were likely other reasons behind it.
As for the food, it‚Äôs decent. Everyone has different tastes, so it's hard to please everyone, but for me, it‚Äôs a nice-to-have, not a dealbreaker. What stands out here is the supportive team, positive culture, and the trust you‚Äôre given to handle your responsibilities independently.

I‚Äôve been working here for quite some time, and overall, it‚Äôs been a good journey. If you‚Äôre responsible with your tasks, you‚Äôre trusted to manage your own time. It really helps when you have personal or family stuff to handle.
The office environment is friendly and stress-free. Break times are chill, and no one is standing behind you or pressuring you unnecessarily. You can focus on your work in peace.
About the food ‚Äì it‚Äôs decent. Tastes will always vary from person to person, but I see it as a bonus. It's not something I expect to be perfect every day. For me, having supportive teammates, a flexible schedule, and a relaxed environment matters more.
Please hire some project manager, business analyst. Don't push developer to doing all role task.¬†¬†

I had been working SOL¬† for 2 years. Food habits vary person to person.¬† But I found (from my view , please don't take it personal) there was truely lack of technically expert person as Lead or RM. If anyone have no knowledge about how to make a system design but know the tools name and try to use them that's make the problem. So I think it is one of the reason for recent incidents like lossing projects.Also previously they had the requirements problem. There was no fixed requirements for a project.

I get that everyone has different experiences, but just wanted to share mine.
I‚Äôve been working here for a while and honestly, I‚Äôve had a pretty good experience overall. The work schedule is super flexible, and we‚Äôre trusted to manage our time ‚Äì which makes a big difference. Break times are also chill, no one‚Äôs micromanaging or breathing down your neck.
And Food is a subjective matter, office meals are meant to be a complementary benefit, not a core metric of work experience.
Agreed with you. They give you advise to bring food from home. but not making it better. ha ha.üòÇ

I‚Äôve seen SOL take good care of employees, even over a year after they‚Äôve been terminated by the client. The recent firings were only of those whose negligence directly put important projects and the company‚Äôs reputation at risk. Some client relationships were damaged, and we even lost a few onboarding projects because of those issues.
As for the work environment, it‚Äôs genuinely supportive. The company provides breakfast, lunch, and evening snacks. There‚Äôs unlimited coffee at your desk. What more could you ask for?
Even on remote working days, if I need to be at the office, the company always covers meals, and I often order platters from Mad Chef and similar types of places. Today, I asked them for home made lunch, they shared: grilled chicken, a small grilled coral fish, veggies, and rice. If the food isn‚Äôt to your taste, you‚Äôre always free to order your own. I do that from time to time.
I also take long personal breaks during office hours, and management never asks any questions. Often, I travel for weeks to months and work remotely. If you perform your responsibilities well, you have unlimited freedom here!
Why don't you bring your own food if you don't like it? Hudai pechal

post_title: Toxic Workplace with Rude Management and Unprofessional Senior Staff
full_review: This company is an absolute nightmare to work for. The management is shockingly rude, dismissive, and completely unprofessional. Instead of fostering a supportive work environment, they create unnecessary stress through their arrogant and disrespectful behavior. Even worse, some of the senior software engineers lack basic manners and professionalism. They are egotistical, condescending, and make collaboration unbearable. Rather than mentoring or guiding junior employees, they belittle others and act as if they are above teamwork. The office culture is toxic, morale is low, and there is zero accountability for poor behavior. If you value respect, professionalism, or a healthy work environment, avoid this company at all costs.

Well, first of all, I‚Äôm grateful to the company because I was struggling to find a job. This company gave me the opportunity to start my career with zero salary. I left the company years ago. Pros: If you have skill issues or can‚Äôt manage to get a job or internship, you can start here. Of course, don‚Äôt expect any salary during your internship period. Cons: 1. Your job can be terminated at any time without notice. 2. Poor management. 3. No work-life balance. 4. If you plan to resign, don‚Äôt expect to receive your pending salary. Honorable mention: Raja Vai, the Operations Manager. Sometimes, he doesn‚Äôt behave like a civilized person. In the end, I just want to say ‚Äî this company could have been one of the best in Bangladesh. They had the financial backup. But the original owner, a Saudi man, has no idea how this manag ement is ruining the company.

post_title: I don't care if you call me DALAL
full_review: 2-3 years of experience e kon company manual QA k 45-60k salary pay kore, sai company k dekhte chai. I have been working at AGT for around 7 months. I received MacBook Pro 16" to use as my office device (Jodio job here dile return kora lagbe). But ekhon 45k pay kortasa device er jonno (1 year AGT te thakle taka return kora lagbe na) Ami recruitment post dekhe e apply korsi j night shift. So no complaint. Ami contract paper a 1 year e same salary te kaj korar jonno raji hoisi. Amar 1 year complete hoile contract renew hobe. Ami chill mode e kaj kori, client meeting sob attend kori. So amake niye reporting manager r client side er positive vive ase. Ami tel mari kaj kori na. kaj na thakle free time e movie dekhi. Even Sakib bhai o ei bisoye jane. Ami Ratul bhai er sathe kaj o korsi. He is not a bad guy. If you complete your assigned task, it is okay for him. Kono pera dai na. Ami kichu manus k terminate korte deksi. Sobai k tader kajer karonei terminate korse (Rabab bhai er case ta different) I will say, if you know how QA works, then you will survive here. Kaje gafiloti korle chient side theke complaint asbe. And you will be assigned to another project, or you will be fired. For me, the Overall management is okay. 5-6 tarikh e salary deposit hoy. AGT is a staff augmentation company. If the client needs you, you have the job otherwise, you will be terminated.

post_title: Work-Life Balance Done Right! One of Bangladesh's Best Companies
full_review: I can confidently say that Monstarlab Bangladesh is one of the few companies in the country that truly upholds international standards in the workplace. Unfortunately, due to a series of poor decisions at the international management level, the company underwent significant downsizing. But that‚Äôs life. That said, I sincerely hope the company finds its way back. Even during the toughest times, Monstarlab Bangladesh remained committed to its people, trying to provide fair compensation and support to those affected by the layoffs. I miss MLBD. Thank you, MLBD ! and best of luck on the road ahead. To everyone still working hard to keep it going: kudos to you all ‚ù§Ô∏è A suggestion to the higher management: Perhaps it‚Äôs time to consider a new CüçµO !!! Recently, a number of vulgar and inappropriate reviews have been posted here. While I do not support the use of such language, I also understand that some of the underlying concerns may be valid. Th3rap is still a good company, and many of us appreciate the opportunities it provides. That said, I would like to respectfully request the management to show a bit more consideration‚Äîsimilar to how things used to be not too long ago. Please try not to normalize working overtime or assigning work on government-declared holidays. If a release is urgent, perhaps only the directly involved team can be asked to handle it, rather than occupying everyone. And if that‚Äôs not possible, could we at least be given a compensatory day off? I understand that, as a large US-based company, it's not feasible to shut down for 10 days. We do appreciate getting work-from-home on June 11 and 12‚Äîbut June 5 was a government-mandated holiday, and we wonder why that wasn‚Äôt respected. Not all 10 days off are necessary, but why not from June 5 to 10? That seems like a reasonable compromise. I truly believe that the leadership at Th3rap is doing their best. But being too strict won‚Äôt silence people's frustrations‚Äîespecially when even those who don‚Äôt speak up feel the same way. I hope this message is taken as a humble request to be a little more thoughtful in such situations. We care about our work and the company‚Äîbut we also need understanding and balance.

As a Tech grad from BD, most of us know Eno5i5 is a well-known company. So, I was very interested in working there. I always heard about the referral system there. But from the beginning, I have a thing of self-respect and am kind of adamant that I won't grab any job with others referring me.Though I know few seniors at eno5i5 who will gimme me refer if I request them but I applied through LinkedIn in usual way. TBH I knew there's very little chance I would get the interview call as huge applicants apply. After 1.5 months they mailed about the assessment. HackerRank test-> Technical Interview ->Final HR Interview passed all the steps. Technical Interview: A team Lead vai took the assessment on Google Meet. I did my best. And at end part he gave me vibe that he is convinced about almost all the answers. HR Interview: After 7 days HR meeting took place. He asked stuffs about me and about prev job experiences. And bit of other casual talks. He was very friendly and gave me vibe like he was convinced with me too. (I gave a lot of interviews in my life XD I kinda know now the signs interviewer likes the candidate or not ). interviewer told me they will mail the decision within 2 weeks. So I was very happy with the whole process. I worked very hard to prepare myself for the interviews of Eno5i5 and gave my best effort. And after the phases I was kinda sure they might choose me . I kept my fingers crossed and really hoped I might get the job. After 14 days of no response so I mailed about follow up . No Reply After around two months, they replied that vacancies have been filled up for the position. It was very sad for me. It's ok, it happens. At this time I finally reached out to a senior vai of mine who works at Eno5i5 and asked him if he could gimme any info about my situation. He got back to me after few days telling "You passed all phases, but among other candidates few of them had direct referrals from very senior positions like Senior/ Team lead etc. So they had to pick them " That was like breaking my heart into pieces. I know it's just a job and I moved on. I believe ALLAH wrote my riziq somewhere else. But I really worked hard for the interviews and had high hopes. From a famous company like them, I did not expect that. I could have managed a refer, but did not, as I was confident I could ace it. Never going to apply again at Eno5i5. If any job candidate reading this, I would suggest applying at eno5i5 with a reference or dont. Not saying they don't hire ppl without refer but nowadays they mostly give preference to referred ppl.

post_title: Reflections on My Time at C3fa1o: Strengths and Opportunities for Growth
full_review: I am a former employee of C3fa1o, having left the organization before the recent management restructuring (specifically, the introduction of Engineering Managers ‚Äì EMs). Therefore, my feedback does not reflect the most recent changes that others have mentioned in this platform. Positive Aspects: The management is empathetic, kind, considerate, and genuinely employee-centric. There is no culture of micromanagement. Employees enjoy autonomy in managing their work and can operate independently with a great deal of freedom. Similarly, leave policies are flexible. The management respects personal time off and does not question leave decisions. The clients I worked with were polite, respectful, and professional. Salaries are competitive and always disbursed on time. Areas of Concern: The pace of work and overall progress can sometimes feel average or, in some cases, below average. For those who are highly ambitious and eager to contribute beyond expectations, opportunities may seem limited. Career progression tends to be slow. Even for top performers, advancement does not necessarily follow performance. While salary reviews are better in such cases, the differnce are often marginal. Value creation is primarily based on individual contribution, and over time, opportunities for growth may plateau, making it difficult to continue adding value beyond a certain point. While senior titles such as ‚ÄúLead Software Engineer‚Äù or ‚ÄúSenior Software Engineer‚Äù exist, in many cases, the responsibilities remain similar to that of a regular Software Engineer. This can lead to a lack of clarity and recognition for role differentiation. Criteria for promotion are not always transparent. At times, it appears that tenure is weighed more heavily than merit or impact. Moreover, job titles and salary levels do not always correlate. Performance management is often reactive rather than proactive. If a client does not raise concerns, performance issues may go unnoticed for extended periods. In some cases, known team challenges or productivity blockers are acknowledged internally but are not always addressed with effective action. Team structures can occasionally become unbalanced‚Äîfor instance, having five QA professionals in a team of fifteen engineers. If a client reduces team size or exits, reallocation of resources becomes difficult and stressful. Suggestions for Improvement: Monitor individual and team performance more actively without resorting to micromanagement‚Äîit is possible to strike this balance. Provide regular, structured feedback to employees, highlighting both strengths and areas for improvement. A quarterly or biannual system would be beneficial. Address substandard work ethics constructively. Allowing poor work habits to go unchecked can be demotivating for committed team members and may affect overall team morale. Raise the hiring standards to focus once again on experienced and proven candidates, as was the practice in earlier years. Make the career growth path and promotion criteria more transparent and performance-based, so that employees understand how to advance.

post_title: Let's discuss what makes a company worthy of receiving a good review in Deshi Mula
full_review: Here is my opinion: On-time salary, work-from-home option, good food and snacks Balanced salary (People need enough to live, not just survive, jodio manusher pet koborer mati chara vorbe na) Balanced team knowledge. A good team lead who is willing to listen. (Sometimes juniors feel ignored if their ideas aren‚Äôt heard, but it‚Äôs also the team lead‚Äôs responsibility to explain decisions. If your knowledge doesn‚Äôt make you humble, you need to reflect on that vai!) No HR drama (please!), Meme > Text > short video insturction > short physical meeting > long Teams call (please avoid this, time is money) Flexible hours (No unpaid overtime in the name of flexibility. If someone starts late, let them finish their 8 hours or complete their tasks.) Respect and good behavior. Dedicated prayer zone. I see companies keep room for biri, sports, but not for the most important thing in humans life. Proper training after joining, opportunities for learning and skill development (sessions by other teamleads, courses etc) Proper penalty system for slackers (e.g., a 100 taka fine for unprofessional behavior or taking two days to change a button color, unless you‚Äôre actually doing R&D with Pantone üòÜ). Also zero tollerance about people who is toxic. (durjon biddan hoileo poritajjo) Job security, in some cases, profit sharing Please share yours, be neutral and unbiased.

post_title: Welcome to the Twilight Zone of Tech
full_review: Nothing happens here. Literally.¬†No engineering culture. No innovation. No real decision-making. People show up, follow orders, and go home. That‚Äôs the cycle. There‚Äôs no push for improvement because no one believes change is possible‚Äîor even worth trying. Leaders who don‚Äôt understand the work make the decisions.¬†They estimate timelines without knowing what‚Äôs involved. No technical input, no reality checks‚Äîjust made-up deadlines that lead to unnecessary stress, overwork, and sleepless nights. Then they act surprised when things fall apart. There‚Äôs no collaboration, no constructive discussion.¬†It‚Äôs a one-way street: top-down instructions with no room for feedback. Engineers have become passive executors, not builders. No one challenges anything, because nothing ever changes anyway. Even with 130+ employees, there‚Äôs barely any real work.¬†The office vibe is somewhere between a ghost town and a waiting room. The company hasn‚Äôt laid people off, but it also hasn‚Äôt moved forward. It‚Äôs just stuck‚Äîexisting for the sake of existing. This company doesn‚Äôt know what it is.¬†Is it trying to be a tech company, or just live off the reputation of its parent brand? There‚Äôs no clarity‚Äîjust confusion, masked with buzzwords. If you‚Äôre an engineer who wants to grow, make an impact, or feel like your work matters‚Äîthis is not the place.¬†All you‚Äôll find is a paycheck and the slow, soul-crushing realization that absolutely nothing is happening here, and probably never will.

post_title: Management Old wine in a new bottle
full_review: As an employee, I want to share some feedback about what I have seen in the company under the new management(Different name, same game) Culture and Work Environment The work culture has not improved. It feels more outdated every day. There is no effort to build a modern, positive work environment. Revenue Growth and Stability Revenue has not grown much. Without help from 8RAC, the company may not survive more than a few months. It is not building its own strong base. Leadership and Employee Growth Leadership quality is going down. Many important roles are given to people based on personal connections, not skills. This is hurting team performance and growth. Technical Progress Technical growth is slow. Compared to other local IT companies, 8RAC IT is falling behind. There is not enough focus on new technologies or improving technical teams. Recruitment Process The hiring process is weak. It lacks structure. Skilled people do not want to join because they don‚Äôt see career growth or a good work culture here. Vision and Direction The company has no clear long-term vision. Many top leaders focus only on keeping 8RAC happy, not on building real value. They often make promises that are not realistic. Project Sustainability Many projects start with big hopes, but they fail to bring long-term results. After two years, they often cannot generate revenue. These turn into "in-hours" projects that don‚Äôt grow or scale. The same mistake is being repeated with new projects. Project Management Standards More than 100 people work in project management, but many do not have the right skills or technical background. Most of them do not follow standard methods like Agile or Scrum. This causes delays, confusion, and poor project outcomes.

post_title: Utter Chaos ‚Äì The Worst Company I‚Äôve Ever Worked For
full_review: 8evy Commerce is a textbook example of how not to run a tech company. From top to bottom, the organization is plagued by incompetence, dysfunction, and toxic leadership. Management is completely disconnected from reality ‚Äî they micromanage when they shouldn't and disappear when you actually need direction. Decisions are made arbitrarily, often driven by egos rather than data or common sense. Transparency is non-existent; you‚Äôll often find out about major changes after they've already happened‚Ä¶ and usually because something has gone horribly wrong. The culture is toxic and demoralizing. Bullying behavior by senior staff is tolerated, even rewarded. Constructive criticism is taken as a personal attack, and there is zero psychological safety. If you‚Äôre not a yes-person, your days are numbered. Workload expectations are brutal, with last-minute deadlines constantly dropped on employees due to poor planning. Burnout is rampant, and HR is either powerless or unwilling to address the issues. Promotions and recognition are based on favoritism, not performance. This is not a company that values its people ‚Äî it uses them and burns them out. Avoid 8evy Commerce at all costs unless you‚Äôre desperate or want a front-row seat to a slow-motion implosion.

However, despite my significant contributions, I received no recognition or promotion during my tenure due to nepotism and my outspoken stance against corruption in procurement, recruitment, and other areas. Instead, my subordinates who lacked potential and worked under my supervision were promoted because they cultivated good relations with senior management. This was apparently done to mentally harass me and pressure me into resigning voluntarily. Although I was pushed out, the organization did not terminate my contract, instead recruiting different supervisors to manage me individuals who lacked knowledge and visionary planning. They merely used my work to showcase their own achievements. The main culprits behind this toxic environment were the Head of Monitoring, Finance Manager, IT Manager, HR Manager, Country Director, Program Manager (W**H Project), and the Coordinator (Mechanical Engineer). They have a very good syndicated in that organisation. Therefore, I would not recommend this organization to those who are career oriented and seek professional growth. However, for freshers, older employees, or those primarily interested in a good salary without strong ambitions or potential, this organization might be a suitable choice.

post_title: Loving the culture, tech, and leadership at 52 Digital ‚Äì proud to be part of it
full_review: Working at 52 Digital Ltd. has been an incredible experience. It's a denmark based software consultancy service provider where we provide technical support to our Danish clients, and the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technology makes the job both exciting and fulfilling. The work environment here fosters excellent work-life balance, with flexible working hours, a supportive leave policy, and on-time salary payments, learning and growth which together create a strong foundation of trust and stability. The management is transparent and genuinely focused on employee retention and well-being. There's a clear culture of respect and recognition, especially towards the engineers and tech team. The company takes care of its people with thoughtful perks like tours and delicious breakfast, lunch, and snacks provided daily. One of the most standout aspects for me is the leadership ‚Äî particularly the CTO, who is not only technically sound and visionary but also incredibly approachable. He appreciates even the smallest efforts, recognizes good work, and continuously motivates us to bring out our best. That kind of leadership is rare and deeply valued. The seniors here are helpful, and the team culture is friendly and collaborative. Working with our Danish partners has also been a great experience ‚Äî it's rewarding to contribute to an international setup that values quality and professionalism. I'm truly enjoying every bit of my time here and feel grateful to be a part of such a thoughtful and dynamic company.

Th3rap came to SUST this year for campus recruitment. There were 11 mid to easy level leetcode type coding problems. But the time was only 1.5 hours. Because the code was written in hand this time is not enough. Many of my friends had to write pseudo code or plan for solution only. But most of them were correct. But this interview was a joke. All the questions were given from the previous year. They did not even bothered to change the questions. And the HR chose the so called talented bd students that just wrote down memorized code. I mean these people knew they did not change the questions. Shouldn't they atleast check if the answers were genuine or even ask them a bit more different and difficult on site interview questions to judge them? If this is the interview process? Why even bother just do lottery.

post_title: The Internship That Shouldn't Have Existed
full_review: 1. Disorganized and Disgusting Work Environment The office environment was poorly maintained; desks were broken, and the overall setup was highly unprofessional. Coming from a well-known university, transitioning to this office felt like entering an unpleasant and disorganized space. 2. Lack of Basic Facilities It was an unpaid internship, and interns were required to bring their own laptops. No lunch was provided‚Äîonly a single cup of tea for the entire day. Washrooms were filthy and difficult to access. 3. Unrealistic Work Expectations Despite being an intern, I was assigned tasks equivalent to those of a full-time senior employee. I was even asked to train other employees who were permanent hires but lacked basic skills. 4. Unprofessional Management The managing director ignored me on my first day and didn‚Äôt bother to acknowledge my presence. By contrast, my current company introduced me to the team, and the MD personally welcomed me and gave me tips, highlighting the stark difference. 5. Poor Interview and Onboarding Process They bluntly refused parking facilities during the interview and suggested using public transport, showing no consideration for employees. Other companies at least offer alternatives, but this company lacked basic courtesy. 6. Client Handling and Ethics The company showed no willingness to accommodate client requirements, insisting clients accept the software as it was. Client support was appallingly inadequate. 7. Oppressive Contract Terms The offer letter included a clause stating I wouldn‚Äôt be allowed to work for another software company for two years after leaving, or they would take legal action‚Äîthis was for an unpaid internship! 8. Mental Health Impact The toxic environment and lack of professionalism were enough to drive anyone into depression. Final Thoughts: I joined this company out of necessity to avoid a semester gap but left within a day. Within 17 days, I joined a better company out of three offers I received after leaving this place. This company is in no way a professional software firm. Avoid it at all costs!

post_title: A Workplace Where Working Feels Fun
full_review: I‚Äôve worked at quite a few places, but honestly, this one was the most fun. Not just flexible, but the overall vibe was so chill that you never felt pressure going to work. Say something happens at home‚Äîthey sometimes let you work from home with a proper reason. There's even the option to take half-day leaves if needed. For me, I didn‚Äôt mind working extra hour when there was pressure. This kind of mutual understanding just makes working feel better, doesn‚Äôt it? When it comes to salary, they pay on time. I‚Äôve seen people get their full salary even if they left in the middle of the month. That kind of fairness is rare nowadays. The salary might feel a bit low to some, and honestly, I can‚Äôt compare it properly with the Bangladesh job market. But one thing‚Äôs for sure‚Äîyou get huge opportunities for R&D. If you‚Äôre eager to learn or try something new, they provide time, resources, and support. I even worked on R&D projects during office hours, which is not common everywhere. The environment here is super friendly and open. Once you join, you get a strong ‚Äúfamily‚Äù feeling. I‚Äôve seen many former employees come back just to hang out. Of course, no place is perfect. One thing I noticed is that they really watch how enthusiastic you are about learning and improving. This might not feel good to everyone. If you join and they don‚Äôt see enough passion in you, you might get fired. At that point, you could feel like the company isn‚Äôt treating you fairly. Still, from my experience, this has been the best place I‚Äôve worked. The increment amount is not acutally based on performance rather it's the inflation rate adjustment. I have been working here and burning my a** off for many years. Recently I came to know that the increment percentage that I have been getting yearly is actually inflation rate adjustment not performance salary hike. My performance and feedback from my team lead seems to be positive but the yearly increment is not satisfactory. The management should provide better increment amount to the current employees rather than hiring new ones in bulk. 8-10% increment every year is not enough, considering the way prices of everything is going up

All concentration on displaying positive vibes in social media, zero effort towards employee engagement. Indirectly banned sick leave without doctor's note, even for cold/cough/seasonal fever. Head of HR comes up with policies with no employee benefits and impose them without any consent. Nobody knows anything about company roadmap, only update comes from zoom channel updates. No path for future progress in terms of learning and self improvement. Hoping to move on asap. Career killer!!

When I interviewed for Opt!m!zely, I was not even sure what the role exactly does, let alone what the company does. The products built here blew me away in terms of their general stability and maturity, so I am happy that I am now working on sensible stuff instead of a 7 person startup whose C3O is a ADHD patient. The culture is great. Inspite of what deshimula has me believe these days (yes me too), I have found everyone at office to be really receptive, supportive, and great prospect for growth. My Manager is on a global role and I see a lot of scope for me to grow into that in the future. There isnt really any barrier to that as a local employee and I love that. I am seeing people posted and sent to different countries on roles and that to me is positive. Although I am not on the engineering track, I feel it can be a good stepping stone for my career. I intend to stay here and gain some expertise before moving abroad for my masters and I even told my manager and they were perfectly okay with it instead of telling me "tomake hire kora to amar loss tahole" like the others. I also found a good community of people here who are working on their masters application and helping each other even at office which was pleasantly surprising. And one more thing I would like to point out is that having Optimizely on my resume has brought a lot of value to it. I now get called to random interviews where they would filter out my CV even a year ago. So I like that the brand stands out. Working on multiple local startups actually didn't have that for me and I am enjoying the sunlight lol. Office is situated in a great location. Transport is provided. There is a culture of gaming in the office. Lots of keyboard enthusiasts which I love. Even a book club! Very lovely set of people that I enjoy spending time with even beyond work. And oh, negativity o ache. Good teams bad teams. Good managers bad managers. Eigula thakbei. I guess I just got lucky.

post_title: New, so have to do office during EID. No holiday
full_review: I just started my job as a Junior Front End Developer here at this company and it's been around a month. So as we know EID is coming up after 2 days . So every one was preparing to go home so as me . We very much excited. It was my first income and Baught a Goat from my very small amount income. Planning buy ticket for going home . i am the onky child my parents have there is no one else in my family . Long story short ... The government has announced 10 day holiday for the EID yet our great great company honoured us with just 3 days of holiday 6 th - 9th July ! Where 2 says will take everyone just to reach home ... any ways I was given home office for the EID and I had no problem .. Now they are saying there will be no home office 2,3 of ¬†you has to so be at office and this is no request this is must . ¬†Because I was new I was honoured with the opportunity to stay at Dhaka and do the Office work where some of our team leaders already left for home today where there is 1 day left still for vacation to start... Just imagine.. you buy your first Kurabani and yet you can't even go to your family for the ...Allahamdullilah allah knows better .. If anyone sees this from the Company please have some common sense..
Pros: Cons: My opinion is, "Its beginner friendly. 1-2years here is good. For further growth I would recomend you to switch."

post_title: Still the best tech company of BD despite some management failures
full_review: So I'll start with this, what Optimizely was 2-3 years back, it's not the same anymore. I'll come to the negatives. But first, the positives. Hands down, the best people you can share your work life with. Most people are friendly, open minded and very helpful (except for some lowlife morons of course). The work process is well designed, OKR is set with reasonable expectations, and you can have a work-life balance (unless your manager is toxic). The pay package is good if you have just started your career or got 2-4 years of work experience. If you reach your midcareer phase, the package won't be competitive enough anymore. The work exposure is amazing. You're working with a global team, with company's own products, which most Bangladeshi tech companies doesn't offer. So it does add to your portfolio. Company is providing free transportation and lunch, where you're actually saving a lot of money if you're a regular office goer. Now the negatives, the quality of new hires dropped drastically in the last few months/years. Most of the new hires aren't culturally fit, thinks this is just a ''Chill'' place, and be with their own circle or bubble. The reason is, most of them has friends here working from before. And the whole blame goes to the TA team. Why everyone's boyfriends, girlfriends, childhood friends and their mother is joining this company? This is a pathetic practice. The company should immediately drop the referral policy. Another thing is, I wouldn't blame the new TAs entirely, because they're very young, they don't have enough experience, doesn't have much industry knowledge. It's their department head's fault who failed to understand, that a global company like this shouldn't rely on youngsters for their hiring process. And the major fallout, the company is not caring much about employee dissatisfaction anymore. It's all 'Business Needs'. I just hope the management understands their shortcomings very soon and take necessary actions to keep the great reputation that we have (I don't think it's already gone yet).

post_title: Talented colleagues, nice office, decent benefits, but shifting culture
full_review: have been here a few years, and thought I would give an honest feedback positives: negatives i prepared a lot and worked very hard and was happy to finally join optimizely after a long interview process, but after getting in i realized there are many different teams, and not every team is same. different teams also have different work culture sometimes. not saying good or bad, sometimes i talk to different engineers and notice some differences. but its ok, a large company will have this i guess. but overall i am enjoying my time here, working with talented colleagues, and learning a lot. for anyone applying for a job here as an engineer, i would recommend to ask questions about which team, what is the role or kind of work and tech stack, how is the manager and team structure, etc. because it varies a lot. so make sure you are applying for the team or stack you are interested in.

post_title: Toxic Culture and Unethical Practices at 3WN Bangladesh
full_review: Toxic Culture and Unethical Practices at 3WN Bangladesh Review: As a current employee, I can no longer stay silent about the deeply unethical and exploitative practices at 3WN Bangladesh. If you're considering working here, I strongly advise you to think twice. What you see from the outside‚Äîa fast-growing company promising innovation‚Äîis nothing but a fa√ßade hiding a deeply toxic, mismanaged, and morally bankrupt organization. 1. Zero Accountability at the Top: Leadership is opaque, autocratic, and entirely unaccountable. Decisions are made without consultation, transparency, or foresight. The higher-ups often delegate blame and take credit for others' work. Constructive feedback is dismissed, and questioning unethical directives is treated as insubordination. 2. Unethical Employment Practices: The company routinely violates labor standards‚Äîforcing employees to work well beyond legal hours without proper compensation. Contracts are often ambiguous or misleading. Promised benefits, such as bonuses or paid leave, are frequently denied or "forgotten." 3. Toxic Work Culture: Bullying, favoritism, and gaslighting are rampant. There is a culture of fear, not collaboration. Those who speak up about abuse or unfair treatment are sidelined or quietly pushed out. HR is either complicit or powerless to act independently. 4. Data Privacy Concerns: I‚Äôve personally witnessed questionable handling of client and employee data. There‚Äôs no clear protocol or ethical concern when it comes to user privacy, which is a huge red flag‚Äîespecially for a tech-oriented company. 5. Misleading Clients and Partners: Sales and project teams often overpromise, knowing full well the company can't deliver. There have been multiple instances where clients were misled about the scope, functionality, or progress of work just to close deals or secure funding. 6. Zero Growth, Zero Learning: Forget professional development. There is no mentorship, no training, no roadmap for progression. The moment you‚Äôre in, you‚Äôre on your own. Talented individuals are often burned out and leave within months. Final Thoughts: I‚Äôm sharing this not out of spite, but out of concern for future employees who might fall into the same trap. 3WN Bangladesh needs a massive ethical overhaul, starting from the top. Until then, stay away‚Äîfor your own sanity and career.

post_title: They take interview just to time pass
full_review: I gave Trainee Software Engineer Interview at We11dev. This took almost 4 months. First MCQ round. Then there consist of three rounds : First round: 1 hour consist of problem solving, OOP, DBMS. 2nd Round: almost similar, problem was little bit harder(Leetcode medium). Then In the last round, it is considered to be COO round. But before that, I was given three easy problem by HR(Leetcode Easy I guess). I easily solved them within 20-22 minutes. full_review: Let's start with the good thing, they'll allow you 22 days' casual leave. Generally, there's no hard restriction on taking those leaves. However, you'll have to inform the office around 25-30 days earlier, unless there's an emergency. & There's no office politics, the environment is professional, you'll have mental peace and a good vibe from that side. The office allows 13 public holidays, chosen by the office, but some of them will surely be eaten up by weekends. And, they'll not reschedule, even if it's on EID. So this time, there's only 1 Day Eid Vacation + 2 days Weekend. That's it! Almost the same thing happened on the last EID; one day of the EID vacation was eaten up by the weekend. So, if the plan is to provide 10 holidays, it should be declared so, and the major occasions should be prioritized. There are more things to discuss, but let's keep those for some other time. In general, BD software firms treat engineers as sugarcane and try to produce as much juice as possible, without wasting a single drop. I think this trend has increased in recent years.

post_title: Feedback on the current Dir3ctor of Engineering at Th3rap‚Äôs BD office
full_review: There is an individual currently serving as the Dir3ctor of Engineering at Th3rap‚Äôs BD office. He has been disconnected from hands-on team management and coding for several years. He is a key source of resistance to adopting new ideas or technologies and frequently offers opinions on matters beyond his expertise, often impeding progress. In meetings or discussions, he dominates the conversation, ignoring the context and the fact that others may not need to hear everything he says, especially when it‚Äôs unrelated to their work. He often pressures team members to conduct research for him, without recognizing that they have higher-priority tasks that are scheduled for production. He lacks a realistic understanding of how long tasks take to complete, often setting impractical deadlines and even expecting people to work on holidays. His instructions are frequently unclear, and if any detail is missed, he responds harshly. Overall, he lacks the empathy necessary for effective collaboration.

They just ruined the career of potential staffs. They just like oiling rather than performance. The CMT memebrs are the main culprit of every syndicate related to recruitment and procurement. But if you are fresher, beginner,¬† or aged person with no potentiality of growth you can choose this organjsation.

This company is suffering due to poor leadership‚Äîand even worse, it‚Äôs an engineering company led by HR, where sometimes technical decisions are made by HR people. üòÄ Someone with no real skills was given a leadership role, while experienced leaders were pushed aside. Top management, especially HR, values personal connections over actual performance. There‚Äôs even a rumor that a senior leader was removed from a client meeting due to repeated failures. Tasks are pushed down without guidance‚Äîif it goes well, leaders take credit; if it fails, you take the blame. The hiring process is a mess. Many people avoid interviewing here altogether. HR is biased‚Äîsalary reviews only happen on time if you‚Äôre close to them. Even in HR team hardworking HR are ignored, while inactive ones are promoted through connections. There are no real benefits‚Äîjust the salary. You might work holidays or weekends, but there‚Äôs no bonus. Even taking earned leave is a struggle, and sometimes public holidays require permission. Sometimes, HR invites only certain teams for lunch (usually chicken biryani), while others just watch. HR and finance leaders go on foreign trips‚Äîlikely using company money‚Äîyet engineering teams are denied even the most basic requests. Occasionally, snacks are given, but only to those who stay at the office late like 8PM or 9PM. Job roles are unclear‚Äîyou‚Äôll do everything while others do nothing. Promotions depend on who HR likes, not your work. No clear goals, no growth plans, and no proper training. Some employees asked for platforms like Udemy, but HR created a copy-paste version, assigned after office hours, and even marked wrong answers as correct ü§£ In the end, you‚Äôre treated more like a factory worker than a tech professional. Hard work doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äîonly office politics does. This place is a textbook example of leadership hazard.

post_title: Toxic Culture and One-Man Show Leadership | Not recommended ‚Äî unless you‚Äôre fine playing politics and staying silent.
full_review: My time at M0nstar1ab Bangladesh was, unfortunately, one of the most disheartening professional experiences I‚Äôve had. While the company tries to present itself as a global, standard-setting workplace, the reality on the inside was deeply concerning ‚Äî and at times, downright toxic. Let‚Äôs start with the work environment. It was anything but healthy. Office politics were a daily survival game. Favoritism, cliques, and inner circles determined your career path ‚Äî not your talent, not your dedication, and certainly not your performance. If you weren‚Äôt aligned with the right group or didn‚Äôt conform to certain personalities, your chances of being recognized or promoted were slim to none. The CT0 ran the show like a one-man army. All decisions ‚Äî from technical strategy to performance evaluations ‚Äî were driven by his perspective alone. Constructive disagreement was not welcome. If you didn‚Äôt echo his thoughts, you were sidelined or worse, subtly labeled as a ‚Äúnon-team player.‚Äù The performance metrics used to evaluate employees were entirely set by the CT0 ‚Äî vague, unrealistic at times, and constantly shifting based on mood or bias. Appraisals were a joke. Promotions and salary revisions had less to do with achievement and more to do with which group you belonged to or how often you agreed with upper management. It was an environment where speaking up meant putting your career at risk. Worst of all were the internal communications. Some emails sent by leadership ‚Äî especially during restructuring and layoffs ‚Äî were incredibly unprofessional and, frankly, toxic. Instead of showing empathy or transparency, they felt accusatory, defensive, and borderline threatening. It was hard to believe those messages came from a so-called international company. M0nstar1ab Bangladesh had the potential to be a standout tech employer in the country. Sadly, that potential was buried under ego-driven leadership, unhealthy politics, and a complete lack of ethical culture. I truly hope the company takes a long, hard look inward before more talented people walk away feeling the same way I did.

post_title: Six years. Still unpaid. Still carrying the trauma.
full_review: They owe me five months of salary ‚Äî and after all this time, nothing . In those six years, they‚Äôve raised funding , relaunched their product , and reinvented their brand more than once. They moved forward. We ‚Äî the ones who built it ‚Äî were left behind. They only paid those who could force them . I wasn‚Äôt one of those people. I asked, waited, struggled , and got silence . Worse, they went out of their way to keep me from quitting ‚Äî making false promises, delaying, manipulating. It wasn‚Äôt mismanagement. It was intentional. To this day, I don‚Äôt know if they‚Äôre still operating. Maybe they vanished, maybe they just changed their name. But I do know this: they left people like me with real scars ‚Äî financial, emotional, and professional. I‚Äôve moved on . I‚Äôm doing well now. But what they did ‚Äî the stress, the betrayal, the toll it took ‚Äî still haunts me. And no success I achieve now will ever justify the way they treated those who gave them everything. If you're building a company, remember: how you treat people matters more than any launch, funding round, or PR win . Your team is not disposable.

company_name: Int3grat3d Bus!ness Sy5tems & Solutions Pvt Ltd
full_review: During my time at !BSS, I encountered several challenges that significantly impacted my overall experience with the company. One positive aspect worth mentioning is that salaries are paid on time, which offers a sense of financial reliability. However, this is overshadowed by a number of critical issues. The company lacks a defined office culture, and there are no established best practices for software development. Projects are often managed without proper planning, code review standards, or structured workflows, leading to confusion and inefficiency. Another major concern is the mismatch between roles and responsibilities‚Äîemployees are frequently hired under one title and assigned unrelated tasks, with little to no alignment with their expertise. The increment process lacks transparency and consistency, with no formal evaluations or commitments from management. Furthermore, there is no active HR policy, no internal communication or notices, and no acknowledgment of employee milestones, such as farewells or achievements. Facilities are also below standard‚Äîoffice lunch is poor in both quality and variety, contributing to an overall lack of care for employee well-being. In summary, while timely salary payments are appreciated, the absence of structure, support, and professionalism makes IBSS a difficult place for personal and career growth. Caution is advised for anyone considering a long-term role here.

full_review: I know there might be some harsh comments on this post ‚Äî many people have shared the negative sides of Div!ne IT. And perhaps some of them are true. Since I‚Äôve only worked here for a short time, I can‚Äôt speak about everything. But I still want to highlight the good parts I personally experienced. I joined Div!ne IT as a Trainee Software Engineer in the Java team , and I had the privilege of working with an amazing group of people. One thing I truly appreciated was how much emphasis our team put on learning. Our team manager often visited us, asked about our progress, discussed various technologies, and guided us on what and how to learn. As a junior developer, I wasn‚Äôt pushed into production-level work right away. Instead, we were encouraged to focus on learning ‚Äî and that made a big difference in my growth. Whenever I got stuck on a task, I never felt hesitant to ask for help. The team would immediately say things like, "AnyDesk e asho... bolo kothay atkaiso?" ‚Äî and not once did I feel like I was bothering them. They helped me out like big brothers would, always with patience and kindness. I‚Äôll definitely miss the little things ‚Äî like our coolest team lead saying, ‚ÄúBoys, cholo ajk baire lunch kori‚Äù , and the casual chats under Moin Bhai‚Äôs shop after lunch. Those moments turned our team into more than just coworkers ‚Äî we became friends. And, "Kothy? Niche namo...." After six months at Div!ne IT, I can confidently say that although I had decent problem-solving skills, I lacked technical depth. But being in that team helped me overcome that. The tech discussions, the guidance on what to learn and how ‚Äî all of that prepared me for bigger things. Today, when I crack interviews at companies, it‚Äôs because Div!ne IT laid the foundation. Some might ask ‚Äî if it was so good, then why leave? To them, I‚Äôll say: maybe if I had a better opportunity earlier, I wouldn‚Äôt have come here at all. But now that I do, and with some family matters as well, it feels like the right time to move on. I won‚Äôt deny that others may have had difficult experiences ‚Äî my journey was short and I was still junior, so I may not have seen it all. But I believe in giving credit where it's due. For me, Div!ne IT gave me knowledge, growth, friendships, a relaxed team culture, and lots of memories ‚Äî all in a short time. I‚Äôve left the company, but I‚Äôll always carry forward the good I received. If people want to share negative experiences, I respect their stories. But this is mine ‚Äî and I‚Äôm thankful for it.

post_title: A toxic workplace disguised as a corporate office, where survival depends more on bootlicking than merit.
full_review: Alright, I‚Äôm going to tell you the real story now. So, how will you be treated once you‚Äôre enrolled there? The reality is: if you‚Äôre not a true bootlicker, this place might be hard for you to survive in. Only the genuine bootlickers can sustain themselves here. They‚Äôre given special treatment‚Äîlike getting to sit next to the team lead, working ‚Äúexclusively‚Äù with them, and other perks. And the rest of the team members? Who cares what they do? They have to go through an intensive 3‚Äì4 round exam process just to get into the company, so clearly, anyone who makes it is qualified. But in reality, not everyone is treated the same. The bootlicking culture I mentioned? It‚Äôs very real here. Office hours officially end at 7, but if you work past 7, congratulations‚Äîyou‚Äôre safe from getting fired. They claim to play everything ‚Äúby the book,‚Äù but every day there‚Äôs a new shenanigan. You‚Äôll see it when it happens. Oh, and don‚Äôt expect any transparency‚Äîthey‚Äôll fire you at the last minute, in the last hour, of the last month. You won‚Äôt even see it coming. DON‚ÄôT FALL FOR THEIR ‚ÄòHAPPY SOCIAL MEDIA‚Äô CAMPAIGN! This is just a warning to anyone who‚Äôs thinking about joining that godown of a company. I genuinely wish everyone a happy and fulfilling career elsewhere. There are certain managers who act like they know everything‚Äîwhich is a blatant lie. The Chief Operating Officer? Doesn‚Äôt have much to do except monitor CCTV cameras. You‚Äôd expect to feel tired after working 8 hours straight‚Äîbut there‚Äôs no real break. When you're bored, there‚Äôs nothing to do. You can‚Äôt go anywhere except the toilet. Maybe grab a cup of bland coffee from the canteen‚Äîbut even that is monitored: how long you take, how often you go. This doesn‚Äôt feel like a company. More like a garment factory‚Äîexcept you‚Äôre stuck with a computer instead of a sewing machine.

post_title: Good company with Big Vision. Bold Code. Bright Future
full_review: There are plenty of great things about working here, from timely salaries and top-tier leadership to a culture that supports learning and trusts you to deliver without micromanagement. Salary is always paid on time, not even a day late. Competitive salary compared to the Bangladeshi market. Annual salary reviews are conducted on time. Leadership is amazing, top-notch quality. Generous salary increments, among the best in Bangladesh. Full flexibility for learning, exploring, and R&D with new technologies. Management focuses on your work, not micromanagement. There‚Äôs no tracking, you‚Äôll only be noticed if you consistently fail to deliver. If you lack certain skills, the company and management will give you time and support to learn and improve. Nothing is perfect, and of course, there are areas where management can make improvements: Update the bonus policy to offer 50% yearly bonuses for permanent employees. Efforts are being made to reduce work pressure and improve work-life balance , especially in certain projects. As far as I know, all projects except Bangladeshi ones are currently maintaining a healthy balance. Consider adding additional employee benefits , such as gratuity , health insurance , and leave encashment . Arrange at least one national or international team trip each year to boost team bonding and motivation.

post_title: Best for Civil Engineers, Not the same for Software Engineers
full_review: If you're a Civil Engineer considering to join, this is a great company for career. If you're a diploma engineer joining, the pressure is a bit high but overall good growth. But if you're a software engineer, you experience will vary across teams. If you work in Re##a team, you have the best side of this company. Team leads and teammates are super helpful, you will use the latest technologies with best enviornment. If you work in AI Team, remember this is truly not AI team. It's actually automation team. You will make life of Civil Engineers easy whether through python script or ML model. If you want independent work that will challenge you, this is pretty neat team. Teammates are helpful. But get ready to get roasted by the dutch owner of the company. Dont take it too personally and you'll be fine. Sometimes you might have to work a bit longer but not too frequently. Then there comes the core team. There are two parts of this team. Both are shit. Shitty team leads. Older technologies. Longer work hours. No good planning. Seniors will criticize you whatever you do. The codebases are super messy. No career progression. Seniors dont take feedbacks. Only what they think right are right. Only good thing about this team is your job will be secure as no one will be able to understand this shitty legacy codebase (especially the BGT team codebase). Also get ready to use SVN. Some other overall stuff: 10 sick days, 10 casual leaves. Leave will depend on team lead a bit. Decent starting salary and increment. Never got late salary, sometimes got early salary during eid season. Has provident fund. Provides lunch and snacks. 9 hours time is 1 hour break (30 min lunch, 2 breaks of 15 mins for tea and snacks)

The atmosphere at P!xmat3ch quickly turned toxic, draining the morale and motivation of every talented individual who once believed in the company‚Äôs potential. It became a place where politics thrived, while talent, transparency, and hard work were dismissed. To anyone considering working with or for P!xmat3ch Limited ‚Äî proceed with extreme caution. This is not a tech company built on innovation or vision; it's a house of cards run by individuals unfit to lead, manage, or even understand the basics of the industry they claim to represent. full_review: Reality check for the ‚Äúcost cutting‚Äù #R genius ‚ÄúWhat are your salary expectations?‚Äù ‚Äú 40k.‚Äù ‚ÄúGreat, you seem like a good fit for us‚Ä¶ unfortunately we can‚Äôt afford that. We can only offer 25K for now even tho the job description says something else‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay, I will start with 25k then‚Äù ‚ÄúWhen can you start?‚Äù Congratulations, Bhombol das! You just high fived yourself for ‚Äúnegotiating‚Äù a 25k hire while the actual budget line for the role sat at 50k . Here is the price tag on your little victory lap: The moment the new hire learns coworkers pull more for the same job, their motivation drops faster than your linkedIn leadership quotes. Pay inequity is a neon sign that says ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt value you, just your discount price tag.‚Äù People don‚Äôt go the extra mile when they feel short changed. 6/12/24 months in, the underpaid talent gets an offer elsewhere. They leave. You spin up the hiring carousel again: ads, screenings, interviews, stupid COO interview, onboarding, lost productivity, fractured morale - all for ‚Äúsaving‚Äù 10k up front. Everyone sees what‚Äôs happening: the exits, the disrespect, the favoritism, the lowball offers.People don‚Äôt speak up. They just quietly update their CVs and wait for the right offer to bounce. At WellDev, we are not building a team. We‚Äôre surviving a sinking ship, one resignation letter at a time. You didn‚Äôt negotiate. You devalued. You didn‚Äôt save money. You lit it on fire in slow motion. You just proved you don‚Äôt understand long term value, team health, or basic human motivation. Great companies pay better cause retention is cheaper than replacement, loyalty outperforms churn, and respect outlasts spreadsheets. So next time you‚Äôre tempted to shave a few thousand off an offer just because you can, remember: The talent you lowballed will be the talent updating their linkedIn headline to ‚ÄúOpen to work‚Äù and your competitors will thank you Your team will keep paying the compound interest on your short sighted ‚Äúwin‚Äù Stop penny pinching people. Start valuing them. Pay people what the role is worth the first time. Anything less is corporate self harm. And for god‚Äôs sake, Bhombol. Being an #R isn't about polishing the CEO‚Äôs shoes with your tongue. it‚Äôs about protecting people, not power. Try remembering that.

post_title: The Curious Chronicle of a Simple Soul
full_review: They say the corporate world builds character. They never warn you what it might break first. I joined the company with modest hopes, a quiet desk, some decent work, and the promise of a timely paycheck. Instead, I got ghost bosses, vibe-based engineering, and more strikes than a baseball season. Here's my story. The boss seemed decent at first. Talkative, but respectable. I figured he was just busy; he rarely interacted with the devs, so I kept my head down and did my job. Then, one fine day in August, he disappeared. No messages, no meetings, no "Out of Office" auto-reply. Just radio silence. Two weeks later, he resurfaced on a random Google Meet call from the U.S., like some mythical tech nomad. I was relieved. ‚ÄúAt least I still have a job,‚Äù I thought. That was my first mistake. The very next week, we had a ‚Äúrequirement session‚Äù that lasted over four hours. It could‚Äôve been handled in fifteen minutes, twenty if someone needed a coffee break (coffee break? How can someone take a coffee break without any coffee or tea?). Any question we raised was met with the ultimate black hole of decision-making: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll think about it later.‚Äù Thus began our journey into Vibe-Driven Development‚Ñ¢ . A project built entirely on gut feelings and blurred ideas. Our ERP had no roadmap. Just vibes. The workday officially ended at 7 PM. Reality said otherwise. Meetings bled into 9 PM regularly. And if you survived the evening, there was always the dreaded 11 PM call, featuring Boss‚Äôs late-night philosophical breakdown of some other company‚Äôs ERP features, which went nowhere. Eventually, I drew the line. I stopped picking up calls after hours. I even politely brought it up. Strike one. Two weeks later, my team lead asked me to apologize to "maintain harmony." I did. Then came my probation review. I asked, ‚ÄúHow am I doing?‚Äù Strike two. Apparently, I was the first person in his 15-year career to ever dare to ask that question. He told me loudly that, by labor law, he could keep me on probation for a year. After his mini meltdown, he calmed down and admitted: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have a way to measure performance.‚Äù A 15-year-old company. No metrics. The very next day, he had us install Time Doctor. The twist? We never got company emails. So, using personal ones felt invasive. We made new emails for work use. To this day, not a single email has been sent to them. Ah yes. The silent sport of middle management: blame ping-pong . HR: ‚ÄúBoss didn‚Äôt approve the salary.‚Äù Boss: ‚ÄúHR didn‚Äôt send the salary sheet.‚Äù Meanwhile, my team? Blissfully uninvolved. We stuck to our work. Which irked him. Deeply. At one point, after another of his clashes with our team lead, he randomly called me, showered me with praise, and said he‚Äôd finally make me permanent. After ignoring it for 20 days. It was bait. He wanted me to turn on my lead. I didn‚Äôt. Shadow strike unlocked. ‚ÄúIf I start learning Golang today, I can complete user, authentication and authorization service in 4 hours.‚Äù I chuckled. ‚ÄúIt may be funny to you, but it‚Äôs the truth.‚Äù ‚Äú‚Ä¶Yes, boss.‚Äù This is the same man who thought backend done = project done. API integration? Testing? Parallel universe problems. He once refused to pay for a Postman because: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nighttime there.‚Äù Time zones apparently affect SaaS. He had no concept of backend complexity, timelines, or reality. He believed motivation was more powerful than logic. Our timelines were born from his ego, not estimates. Twelve months. Never once was salary paid before the 10th. Most often? close to 25th. He‚Äôd shrug and say: ‚ÄúDid we miss the month?‚Äù At one point, on the 20th, HR said: ‚ÄúBoss asked you all to make other arrangements. Salary will be delayed.‚Äù I replied, ‚ÄúThis is my arrangement.‚Äù Strike three. After my confirmation, the new salary didn‚Äôt reflect in the following month. HR said the papers weren‚Äôt signed yet. A whole month had passed. When I asked again? Strike four. He got furious. Said HR could revoke my confirmation at any time. Oh, and if you earned more than 50K? You were automatically bumped to post-15th salary club. Translation: See you on the 25th. Six months in. Four+ strikes. The boss was hinting at hiring new people scare tactics. I finally snapped and resigned. His tone flipped. ‚ÄúWe were about to increase your salary. Why resign? Let me know your preference.‚Äù Right. The truth was, I was resignation #4 that month. No one wanted to join. My PM and lead talked me into staying. So I did, for them. Post-Eid-ul-Fitr, boss cornered me: ‚ÄúAre you okay with me firing the rest of the team? If not, I‚Äôll fire you too.‚Äù He tried to make me choose my job over four people. I didn‚Äôt. A bonus strike in the spirit of Eid. Eid-ul-Adha approached. No salary. No bonus. We voiced our concern to HR. Next morning: termination letter . Everyone else in other companies got a salary, bonuses, and gifts. I got boxed. My PM called that night. Said HR miscommunicated. The boss didn‚Äôt mean it. He wanted to walk it back. But no one said a word about salary. I stood firm: ‚ÄúI have my dignity. I‚Äôm not continuing.‚Äù I finally received the salary that everyone got before Eid on June 18, only after I threatened not to serve my notice without it. I‚Äôm not sure how many strikes I collected in total, five, six, maybe more. What I do know is that some companies don‚Äôt need a villain. They build entire ecosystems where mismanagement, ego, and passive aggression do the job. I stayed longer than I should have, not for the job, but for the people beside me. That‚Äôs the only thing I don‚Äôt regret. And that, dear reader, is the curious chronicle of a simple soul.

The work he is showing off to the management and the management be like - Wah plasmid Wah ! How many of you can do that? While you worked hard on your desk for his task, he went to the management, shared his ideas, took other's efforts as his success. With zero engineering knowledge or capabilities, someone can reach to manage the employees, have you ever thought how much talent it would need? How many of you can do this? His communication skill with the management is excellent but not with the resources he manage but that is the most important part of his job. DS! needs more of this type of people in it's company to be the Titanic. Okay it's getting that 20 page essay that we used to write on Bangla 2nd paper exam. Let's end this point here by sharing his most extraordinary work in my eyes - while everyone is bashing him for being solely dependent on chatgpt for everything, he replied on one post using chatgpt to defend himself. I am asking again, can you do that? Just ask yourself. If not, then this is the reason, he is managing you. 3. Now coming to the employee benefits. I believe DS! has most of the employee benefits but not all that a good sustainable company should have. Apart from the good benefits I would like to suggest introducing Performance Bonus, Profit Share, Provident Fund, 100 % Eid Bonus and Gratuity. Not all of them together but at least start implementing one by one. Like have you ever thought, you are firing people for the future benefits of the company but where are the benefits for your employee's future? Why are the employees in fear due to the layoff? What is their motive to serve you with his hardwork? I mean why would they work for you if they think you are going to fire him when you will think he is not competent to his job? Currently what all benefits you provide, it's all beneficial to their present only, it's not about their future. post_title: Best IT Company In Worst Way
Let People Disconnect. It‚Äôs Not That Hard
full_review: Does anyone here actually understand what being on leave means? When someone shares their leave dates in advance, that time should be respected ‚Äî no calls, no pings, no surprise meeting invites. This isn‚Äôt a one-off issue. And when everything falls apart, the default response is to drag others in, regardless of whether they‚Äôre on leave or not. This is not okay. Stop treating employees like 24/7 support agents. Respecting someone‚Äôs time off is the bare minimum. If this company values people, then prove it ‚Äî not through words or slogans, but through actual behavior. People are exhausted. Not because of hard work, but because boundaries mean nothing here. This needs to change ‚Äî not eventually, but now.

post_title: Our team lead had limited knowledge
full_review: I worked in the creative team at K!te Game Studio for about 3 years. The company atmosphere was generally supportive and colleagues were always ready to help each other. However, unfortunately, the behavior and attitude of our team lead had a negative impact on the atmosphere of the entire team. Our team lead had limited knowledge of design and often copied the work of others, forcing team members to do the same. Whenever a project brief came from management, he would change it to his liking, which led to a bad reaction to the project. However, he never admitted his own mistakes in these changes, but instead blamed the team members. He created an atmosphere of fear within the team, as if everyone was afraid of him. He could not tolerate anyone's success and often spoke badly about team members behind their backs. He showed no sympathy or support for anyone. Also, he criticized managers behind their backs, but when he was in front of them, he flattered them. There was no employee he did not criticize. He was quite lacking in competence. And I can confidently say that he was an unfit person for his position. Today, due to the influence of a few individuals due to negativity, the official environment of K!te Game Studio has been tarnished, and many employees are now suffering from depression. The most unfortunate thing is that he has dismissed many capable employees from their jobs by providing false information to the management. I have personally witnessed this incident. This company is a good organization, but because of one negative individual, many team members have suffered. I hope that in the future, more awareness will be raised in the leadership of the team and qualified people with real leadership qualities will be placed in such positions.

post_title: What It‚Äôs Really Like Working at MG# Group ‚Äì A North Korea-Inspired Nightmare
full_review: We can‚Äôt begin talking about MG# Group without mentioning its notorious MD ‚Äî let‚Äôs just call him Ani$ ‚Äî the so-called ‚ÄúKim Jong-Un‚Äù of the office. This guy named the company after his father, and you'd think, ‚ÄúOkay, maybe he wants to make his dad proud by building a good organization with solid values.‚Äù You‚Äôd be dead wrong. Everything revolves around the MD. For example, you can‚Äôt even leave your phone on your desk unless it‚Äôs on silent ‚Äî if it rings and disturbs His Highness, you might be shown the door. Yes, people have literally been fired for taking a bathroom break longer than 5 minutes. Ani$ was once on the radar of the Anti-Corruption Commission, but after August 2024, all charges mysteriously vanished ‚Äî despite clear signs of tax fraud. Employees don‚Äôt receive proper payslips or proof of tax submission. Yet, a significant chunk of salary is deducted every month in the name of income tax. This guy walks into the office whenever he pleases. Managers treat him like a god ‚Äî praising him like he blessed their families personally. There's constant bootlicking, and it‚Äôs painful to witness. In IT, certain employees (you probably know who, both their name start with S) act like his personal assistants in more ways than one. They accept every unreasonable demand from him and push all the grunt work onto regular employees. For instance, backend developers are often assigned completely unrelated work ‚Äî like finding vendors for non-tech-related tasks ‚Äî all in the name of saving face or hiding mismanagement. Outsourcing, even with a strong in-house team, is common. Why? To dodge taxes and funnel money elsewhere. An audit would reveal just how much money has been laundered through ‚Äúnew projects‚Äù every year. Now, it gets worse. There‚Äôs a clear bias in hiring and favoritism based on disturbing personal preferences. Whether you're a skilled professional or not, if you don‚Äôt meet certain ‚Äúvisual standards,‚Äù you might not pass the final interview ‚Äî which, by the way, is always conducted by the MD himself. Here‚Äôs a summary of what a general employee at MG# Group typically faces: Extreme micromanagement from the MD. Toxic work culture. HR is ineffective or complicit. False promises of incentives ‚Äî managers take credit for your work and blame you for theirs. Employees are taught never to question the MD, even when decisions seem criminal. Promotions and job security are based on blind loyalty, not merit. Drug use among top management is rumored and widespread. Late-night work calls at 2 AM ‚Äî for tasks that no one touches for months. Real work happens only when a report is due for the MD. Writing an email to the MD takes days because even a typo can lead to public humiliation or termination. Dual documentation practices ‚Äî different sets for government vs. clients ‚Äî to commit tax fraud. If you‚Äôre currently working here, consider this a wake-up call. If you‚Äôre thinking of joining ‚Äî unless you're planning to give up on mental peace, think again.

Meanwhile, the ones who do the least‚Äîfakibaj gulay who spend more time pleasing their bosses than working‚Äîget praised, protected, and promoted. Real talent is ignored, silenced, or eventually pushed out. Most HODs act like tyrants, shouting, blaming, and micromanaging everything except what really matters. There are so many useless staff in the HR, Admin and Accounts sections (especially Accounts). I wonder why and how they still survive there! I‚Äôm writing this review with deep frustration and disappointment ‚Äî not out of emotion, but out of necessity, to warn freshers and job seekers before they make a decision they‚Äôll regret. This company once had a great reputation, but things have taken a steep downhill turn ‚Äî especially for those of us working in the Bangladesh branch. üö® The biggest red flag? Salary is never paid on time. You work hard, meet deadlines, handle pressure ‚Äî but when payday comes, there‚Äôs always an excuse: ‚ÄúThe client hasn‚Äôt paid yet.‚Äù Strangely though, this only seems to affect the Bangladesh team. The Switzerland and Canada branches always receive their salaries on time. This clearly shows it‚Äôs not a financial issue ‚Äî it‚Äôs a matter of priority. Employees in Bangladesh are treated as second-class, despite doing the same (or more) work. üá≤üá∫ And then comes the Mauritius branch. The company has recently expanded to Mauritius ‚Äî despite not being able to pay its existing employees in Bangladesh on time. Instead of solving internal salary problems, they‚Äôre focused on international expansion. This isn‚Äôt ambition ‚Äî it‚Äôs poor judgment and mismanagement. Meanwhile, work pressure stays consistent ‚Äî only your salary doesn‚Äôt. You‚Äôll be expected to perform like a full-time, top-tier employee, but without the basic respect of getting paid when you should. Management is a mess. No transparency, no communication, no real solutions. Just a cycle of delays, promises, and disappointment. And to all freshers: Please don‚Äôt join. The company continues to recruit trainee software engineers, but the reality will hit you after a month ‚Äî no salary, no appreciation, just stress and regret. A shiny offer letter means nothing if your hard work is ignored and you‚Äôre left wondering when (or if) you‚Äôll get paid. In the end, we work for one thing: to get paid. If a company can‚Äôt even guarantee that, your time and talent are better spent elsewhere ‚Äî no matter how desperate you are for a first job.

post_title: LayOff Coming so be Careful to Join Here
full_review: You may have seen @GT hyped up on social media platforms like Facebook, and LinkedIn, showcasing explosive growth and success. But the reality is far from what‚Äôs portrayed. post_title: A place where potential goes to die!
full_review: Joined with high hopes. Left with lessons. WebAppick hires smart, potential people ‚Äî then fails to guide or utilize them properly. When things go south, blame is pushed on employees instead of reflecting on weak leadership or planning. Termination processes? Unprofessional at best. There's no solid HR policy, and the culture is led by flattery, not merit.¬†Talented employees get demotivated, while bootlickers thrive and silently ruin the core. Pros: Cons: Bottom line for newbies: Think twice before investing your potential here. Advice for the CEO: Be a leader, not a "Boos." Open your eyes to the people around you. Those who constantly flatter you and feed your ego are not helping the company ‚Äî they‚Äôre hurting it. They hide problems, silence real talent, and slowly kill the organization from within. Be rational: If you truly care about the company‚Äôs future, identify the bootlickers who manipulate you ‚Äî and start building real connections with your employees. Open your eyes. The skilled ones are leaving. The "Ji bhaiya" types are staying. That should scare you more than anything. Thank you - A well-wisher

Working here was one of the most demoralizing experiences of my career. The Managing Director (MD) has a deeply ingrained habit of publicly humiliating employees ‚Äî not in private, but loudly enough to ensure everyone, from interns to admin staff, is forced to hear it. Respect is a foreign concept in this company. Even more disturbing is how he treats his own wife, who also works here. Shouting at her in front of the team is not uncommon, and it's impossible to ignore the discomfort it creates. If that‚Äôs how he treats family, you can imagine what he‚Äôs like with staff. Dress professionally and you‚Äôre met with degrading remarks like, "Too bad your brains don‚Äôt match your clothes." This is not banter ‚Äî it‚Äôs persistent, intentional belittling. Workloads are dumped on you without any structure, guidance, or support. Unrealistic deadlines are the norm, and there is zero regard for human limits or mental well-being. You‚Äôre expected to deliver without question, regardless of burnout or clarity. To make matters worse, the MD lacks even the most basic understanding of professional etiquette. Client meetings are a cringe-worthy affair; he‚Äôll casually scroll through Facebook mid-conversation, showing utter disregard for the client and the company's image. If you value your dignity, sanity, or career growth, do yourself a favor and stay far, far away.

Dear CEO bhai, here is the english translation:
My husband works at We11Dev. Yes, that famous company that has offices in Switzerland, Austria, Canada, and now in Mauritius! The foreign branches get paid on time, "May their lives be blessed."
And us? The wives of the Bangladesh branch have now learned the new calendar. Our January 1st is January 15th. And the full moon for salary rises on the 20th, if the planets and stars are good.¬†
We11Dev is now a philosophical company that believes: "You should be happy if you get 50% in life."
So they pay 50% of the salary on the 12th, and the remaining 50%? Ah! That's like a kind of Eid moon, sometimes visible on the 20th, sometimes not.
But the problem is, our landlord doesn't believe in this philosophy! He wants the full rent at the beginning of the month. I said, "I'll take 50% of the rent now, the rest on the 20th!"
He said, ‚ÄúAm I an engineer at We11Dev?!‚Äù
Meanwhile, I hear in the company that hiring is going on, expansion is going on at full speed, but my engineer husband‚Äôs salary seems to be stuck in the horoscope of the astrologer.
If this misery continues like this, then after a few days there will be no need to rent a house. I will go straight to We11Dev. The office desk will be my bedroom, and their lunch will be our main meal. The rest of the month will be spent in the hope that ‚Äúclient payment‚Äù will actually be dinner.
